VJrlA1Fb6qf-NJrIv1GwTQ.review_text: The lady is SUPER nice, and we had a GREAT time tonight.  Just a few minor complaints  1) The drinks are pretty God damn watered down.  Seriously... I got a Jack and coke and it's more like jack and COOOOOOOOOOOKE!  2) Can we have japanese and chinese songs in there too?  Just Korean and English just isn't satisfying.   3) What's with the children in the videos?

go45_agzpmuSmqMyqj199g.review_text: Gun Bae!  Playground is a Korean drinking joint and No Rae Bang (private karaoke rooms).   Grab some Soju and Anju, and a bottle of Hite (a 1.6 L bottle, that is, cuz 40 oz just won't due...) and prepare to enjoy yourself.    If you've come for karaoke, there are a few rooms, which are clean and well maintained, and offer food and beverage service (which you can't get next door at Do Re Mi).  On the other hand, the English song selection is not that extensive...  The food is decent , but you can't really do this place justice by evaluating it's component parts.  It's all about the vibe, and here the vibe is drink and be merry.    Bottom line, this is a great, lively place to eat, drink and have fun with your homies.

8Q0xnxT-KrvCl2pQF1qsFQ.review_text: hooray!!!  that is what i scream out whenever we come here.  same old routine...drink, eat, drink, sing, eat, drink, sing, drink...(word to the wise- keep hydrated with water not just soju)  on this particular evening received extra warm k-love from jin (coolest dood evar) and janet (hawtest mama-sita) cause we had one of those inner circle seoul-peeps with us..come on you know the difference peoples!!  (hint: if you don't get a grand serving of incredible fresh fruit delivered during ur karaoke session that makes you think you are royalty of zamunda, well you are not soo kewl)  as usual noticed a young couple making out downstairs on a bench, then a moment later dan pointed out how she was puking and then a few moments after that they were making out again...and yes you guessed it, another round of spewage.  i felt guilty from all the laughter and tears and well maybe a bit of fear, cause i saw the young cat looking up at us and well you know most of the peeps come here packin' so i took a shot of liquid courage and walked down with a glass of water in hand.  made the peace offering and almost a show of pearly offwhites from our young, new friend. check this out...janet said they got their own froyo machine!!  hhhwwwat?!  gonna try it next time.  we actually didn't end up singing cause i was swayed across the street to the good ole snaku..and yeah, hooray!!!!

205YvQhP0Jdgdwq6sGsrWA.review_text: A night at playground means you will most likely walk out a little bit hazier than when you first stepped in.   If you are to come here, either come super early before the crowd comes or book a karaoke room upstairs. There have been times where my friends and I waited for more than an hour for a table. When people start drinking, they usually don't want to leave.   When you finally do get a table, first thing you should do to start off your night is by ordering rounds of soju and beer. Then when you slowly get hungry as the night progresses, take a look at their food options. It will look 100x yummier, I promise. Just be careful and push away the impulse to order the whole menu.   Some things I recommend ordering - 1. Kimchi Fried Rice - A MUST. It comes out on a sizzling platter too!  2. YANGYUM CHICKEN - Fried chicken on a whole new level.  3. La Bokki - Ramen AND rice cakes? Yes please!  2-3 hours of drinking and eating, and STILL want to stay? Book a karaoke room upstairs and sing the night away...with more drinking of course..... ;]  RECIPE OF A GOOD... NO, GREAT... NIGHT

MvlKo-sk5nye0us4Czon4A.review_text: Yogurt soju, me love you long time but Playground you lose a star for not having "Baby Got Back" on your playlists.  Everything else.  Perfection.

hRtfbpm_A1AYCfYJ5HEP-g.review_text: over indulgence of soju, hite and food. this  is where kidneys die

gZU1WfPtSxcG-VTqfFCGLA.review_text: It's a cool place because they are open late, the staff is helpful and you can sit basically as long as you want.  I don't get the hype about the canned corn dish at all though...Asian food just shouldn't have cheese in it!  I ate a bunch of other random food that was pretty tasty, although I have had better elsewhere.  The soju flows, there's always a good crowd and parking isn't too bad.  I have yet to try the karaoke action upstairs so perhaps I'll return at some point.  In the meantime, there are a few other Korean places I'd rather hit up for food.

_IIIPlfcJq66EomA4904Lw.review_text: Nice place with private karaoke rooms. The rooms have a base fee of about $30 each and then another food/drink minimum of about $20 pp. they are one of the few karaoke places in SF that serve alcohol (I hear Milo also serves alcohol) - they have an okay song selection - the downside was the AC was broken in our room and even though they brought a fan - it was steamy to say the least.. Haha and the song books were a bit sticky with all the alcohol that had gotten on them.. But overall fun times with fun company  Great soju cocktails - love the yogurt soju cocktail!

XBA4XWhYOCiEVH7NnV-cVw.review_text: Bring on the lychee and yogurt soju! (Then, pass me one of the mics becauss I'll own it for the rest of the night.)  Private rooms are great for parties, especially if the group has shy friends that won't sing openly in public.  Extensive and current song choices.  The food is good too.  Why not grub on some fries or mozzarella sticks after a few drinks?  Or better yet, something from their Korean menu!

8hvXl0oJmU61l17LG9aDag.review_text: the constants in your life are usually the best things.  (if the constants are bad things, you need to check your self)  playground is a constant.   good eats, good drinks, good people, good friends. of the literal hundreds of times ive been here, i cant remember a bad night. of course there were many "one too many drink" nights, but thats all on me! hahaha i think i stumbled down those dennys stairs one too many times.   you come to playground expecting to drink, eat and enjoy yourself and the company of your friends. you always run into people here because they love this place.   you dont come on busy weekend nights expecting a quick meal. and theres a reason you have to wait, people love this place.   six years of being a fan. to sixty more! cheers!

ZTSeu3WILb-nBDbZmUFASw.review_text: 2.5 stars.  I really wanted to like this place.   I saw Playground featured on Check Please and thought that it looked like an awesome place to celebrate my graduation so, on a whim, I decided to have my party there. Ehhh.  The plan was for us (20 of us total) to have dinner, and then enjoy 2 hours in one of their private karaoke rooms. We ordered a ton of food which was all average quality at best. Their banchan was limited and boring. The corn and cheese appetizer reminded me of something you would eat if you were super broke and were scraping up random things in the kitchen in hopes of creating a meal. I understand that this is a karaoke joint, and that I shouldn't have expected authentic, delicious Korean food but simply put, most dishes were flavorless and bland.  After an unsatisfying (but reasonably priced) dinner we headed upstairs for 2 hours in their larger sized private karaoke room. Although the TV was small and outdated (I mean it's 2011, why no flat screen?), the room was huge and comfortable which was nice. I found their song choices to be seriously limited which was a disappointment. None of the songs I had secretly practiced at home the week beforehand were available. Boo.  The biggest disappointment however came when the bill for our karaoke room was presented. They charged us for an extra hour in the room because we were there 15 minutes after we were supposed to depart. The kicker: they didn't even bring us our bill until then!  Based on my experience I would NOT go back. With authentic Korean food available around the corner and plenty of karaoke bars in town why would I?

BCHyzFtX1R5eZ5AoOkuONQ.review_text: Good Korean restaurant for a night out with your friends. Yummy traditional korean food. Flavored sojus and other alcoholic beverages. I haven't tried their karaoke rooms yet and I love the place already.

WoDSAQPRN7BmHVea5YAO5A.review_text: This place is fun! We didn't even do the karaoke, but the restaurant/bar area has music videos playing and it's a good time.   The four stars are not necessarily for the food exactly, but for the experience. I probably shouldn't even being rating Korean food since I don't really know what good Korean food by any standard. We got some chicken wings, seafood pancakes, and the big soup consisting of like 20 things including tofu, hot dogs, spam, ramen noodles, rice cakes and I don't know what else. It was $30 for the whole thing, but 5 of us didn't come close to eating all of it (with all our other food) and it was pretty good, although i can't believe I was eating a soup with hot dog, spam, and ramen. I feel like I should have been drunk first, not getting drunk at the same time as eating it.   As far as drinks, we got 5 small pitchers of soju (buy 4, get 1 free) - lychee, yogurt, strawberry, mango, and pineapple. Yum! Also, enjoyed some yung ju(?) shots - some combination of a shot of coke, a shot of soju and beer like a bomb. It's fun and not the worst tasting thing.  Good times at Playground. Servers are great too - served our soup for us and mixed it up at the table.

VKpgvnSIAtKkiTIXn-UsbQ.review_text: The only issue I would ever have with Playground is that occasionally, the food comes out very slowly.  But that's more of a factor of the place being busy or the people I bring ordering way too much food.  That and the banchan is not always the most delicious, but... that's usually not why you come here.  Playground has surprisingly good food.  Korean food in SF is generally pretty poor.  Playground's got good anju, good jambong, and good jjajangmyun.  I definitely enjoy coming here every so often.

i9l8TT6Bz63W-PZl8ph53w.review_text: Ah, playgound. the memory of my boss banging the tambourine on the wall with his head down, eyes closed for half an hour while the rest of us were laughing at HIS manager singing "Material Girl" with his own background dancers...oh that memory will be with me FOREVER.  Playground is a super cool spot with a few private rooms for karaoke. It's open until 2 Thursday-Saturday and is a great spot to throw back a few drinks and exercise those vocal chords! One of the great things about Playground is that they serve alcohol in the rooms (unlike other places like Do Re Mi who disallow alcohol). They have a phone in the room for you to call down and order both food and drinks (and the occasional cup of water)!!  As for their food, I've only had it while in the karaoke rooms, but they do have full service dining. They offer Korean/American food. The chicken wings were pretty good (but somewhat pricey), potstickers were pretty standard. The owner of the place is a super cute Korean who sometimes works behind the bar. She was soo fun and even took a couple of shots with us :)  5 stars for fun and good times, +1 star for having "A Whole New World" (Aladdin), -1 star for not having "Part of Your World" (Little Mermaid) nor "Blister in the Sun" (Violent Femmes), -1 star for making me spend a pretty penny (several hours in the karaoke room gets a tad pricey).

_OpVivevjEFl2rwEPPX-XQ.review_text: playground is one of the nicer korean bars in the bay area. they're located across the street from the Japan Town center, upstaires from a room bar. I have yet to travel upstaires to playground's karaoke room, but it looks very private and a bit expensive since theres a per person charge.   playground has a nice ambience, and the place is pretty clean, especially compared to the oakland korean bars. its nice how this place serves other alcohol other than soju and beer. there is limited seating at the bar and table seats are avaliable. they serve food, typically bar food. I'm a huge fan of flavored soju, the strawberry wasnt that great, but the aloe was pretty good, contained a nice amount of alcohol. highly recommended if you're looking for a nice place to chill late night.

M9FHUPMUcnH82P-qUYCZLg.review_text: its oooook lah. the Song Books are a bit outdated and not to mention, sticky!  $45 per hour...  not sure if its worth all the $45. the music videos don't match the song, so you'll see New Zealand over and over again..

czJjUvuzfil0agvji1C6qA.review_text: Solid Korean food with really large portions.  Their spicy notations are pretty accurate.  Service was a little slow, but friendly.  I liked the regular black-bean noodle dish better than the Playground version, but that was preference.  Definitely a good way to get your Korean food fix.

uRQl6yvg9Bt6uYC_AqN0zg.review_text: My favorite! The freebie appetizer steamed corn with cheese is my love! The fried chicken and stews are really tasty and good for a party with more than 4 ppl. Btw, the MTV is sexy too!

YLfyhDaQBs_2bfJBNLBt_w.review_text: Food is good and relatively cheap, as well as the mixed soju. Reservations for the private karaoke rooms book fast, so plan ahead.  Nothing beats belting out "Against All Odds" after a generous dose of chamisul.

53YmRCuL3JEXK9s3Bs62Mw.review_text: Going to Playground has been one of my worst eating/drinking experience at a Korean Restaurant ever.  I made reservations for a certain time days in advanace, and they even called me the day before to confirm.  However, when I arrived to this place, there were no tables available and we had to wait 15+mins. The atmospher of this place was pretty boring and bland.  The music was on ultra low the tv's were non-functional, the decore was pretty sad and they use cheap plastic chairs and tables from IKEA.   When we finally were seated down, it took another 10+mins and a lot of flagging down waiters/waitresses to take our order.   The drinks came out pretty fast; however, the Flavor Soju we ordered had no taste of SOJU at all.  In addition, they filled the pitcher of Flavor Soju with lots of ice, which really watered the flavorless Soju even more down. We finally got our food and it wasn't anything specatcular honestly, probably couold have gotten better tasting food from Denny's right below and at a more resonable price. Due to the lack of service and crappy drinks, we deciede to ask for the bill, but this was no easy task.  The waiters/waitresses would just keep passing by our tables, telling us they would come right back for about 10+mins.  I finally got annoyed and just yelled out "CHECK PLEASE" and from the tone of my voice, they finally reazlied I wasn't going to wait any longer. When we got our check, surley enough they MESSED UP ON THE BILL.  There were items on the bill that we didn't order and we were charged for it.  So I advise anyone who decides to go to this abysmal place, review your BILL!!!  Sucks that tip was included for the size of our party, because they DO NOT DESERVE A DIME!  In conclusion, if you want: 1) Flavorless Soju 2) Seat on plastic chairs 3) Slow service 4) High Prices 5) Boring atmospher 6) Chance of being ripped off Then Playground is for you!

NDDgvl-JbJTQzpTUrgODHA.review_text: went here last night to celebrate karen l's big two-nine.   the good: -large variety of soju cocktails that are sweet and delish -huge selection of songs -private kareoke rooms -good room service -food (though we only had the finger foods) -good location -not kicking us out for being too rowdy (which i am very surprised because someone ended up booting on the stairs at the end of the night. but i think they were used to it, because when told about the incident, someone rung a bell and a mop boy came-a-runnin!)  the bad: -soju cocktails that creep up on you -sticky songbooks, seats, floors (though this may have been people spilling, but i'm pretty sure it was sticky when we first got there) -microphones that intermittently worked. -after explicit instructions not to put additional drinks on the credit card we put down, there were multiple carafes/pitchers of beer that were ordered and added onto the tab. -advertising a room that could fit 20+. but really could only fit 12.  all in all though, it was an EPIC night which resulted in a lot of debauchery. (everyone's facebook status the next day was "what happened last night?" or "effing soju")  i'm thinking it's the soju cocktails that creeped up on you about an hour after consumption. those things are effing sneaky.

emM85DHULF4jyWNxzrpvvg.review_text: I came here for my birthday with a large group of people. We reserved a room ahead of time, and were promptly escorted up. Though it was the largest room they had, it did not fit everyone in our party.  Sound quality was pretty good, as we couldn't hear people in the other rooms - but that might have been due to the fact that our group was quite loud... Their song selection seemed large, but they mostly had oldies in Chinese, Korean and English. Their song books are also sticky. Gross. Also, it's the same generic videos playing in the background, which can get kind of annoying. Food was also good, and they have a phone where you can call down your orders. Service was prompt and the wait staff was all very friendly. No complaints in that department. Yogurt soju is a must, and they have a lot of flavors.   Finally, the price. They have a food/drink minimum for the rooms ($25pp), so we had to order a lot more bottles of beer and yogurt soju to meet our minimum. I thought that was a hassle, and also unnecessary, as they're already charging a hourly rate for the room rental ($35/hr).   I think I'd be back, but probably not for the karaoke.

5SUbE_jiHjpYMCkk2L7C4g.review_text: Food is good. Service is a kinda slow, but it's really busy so it wasn't too bad compared to how many people were there. I thought the kalbi was a bit fatty. Yogurt soju was yuuummy!

nKc8PzdtPV3Hlh55FEwrYg.review_text: A bunch of friends went there last night for drinks and snacks. I personally am not impressed. We ordered yogurt and lychee soju and dried fish. Soju tasted very water down. I strongly suspect they add water to it. Yogurt flavor is not strong enough. Dried fish is editable but will never order it again. The table was sticky. The place was getting loud once the clock hit 10pm. So I had to lean over to hear my friends and that's how I got my leather jacket stained with some unknown red color sauce on the side of the black table. There's no way u can tell sauce was there and avoid it with the dark lighting and the black color of the table... sighing...

DCZDwTs2Cxd2kZVokH7cFQ.review_text: I'm giving it 4 stars for the fun and drinks - I've never had the food so I can't speak to that.  The rooms I've been in have all been fine. The song selections are pretty good, especially compared to some other noraebang joints in this town. The servers are good, with booze at least, and it's a really fun time. I've been there three times and all three times, we have closed down that joint.   I will admit, it would be helpful if could speak/read Korean, as the karaoke machine remote is written in Korean. But get someone to tell you what buttons do what (change the pitch, search by artist) and you're good to go (or take a Korean friend that can do that for you!). While the music books don't have all the songs (and, I will grant you, they get sticky), sometimes you can search by artist or song title and find it, even if it's not in the book!  Yogurt soju is, of course, good (a little weak) and no one has complained about the other drinks. Anyway, it's fun, it's reasonably priced (but make sure you read the fine print on the contract), and you'll be surprised at how fast 2-3 hours go by! Have fun!!

p6brsHcvoY6q46mKHAlg-w.review_text: This review would have been better had it not been for the most horrible service experience I've ever had!!! I've been to playground a total of 4 times and the first 3 times was great!  Great food, great service, went home satisfied.  However on my fourth visit..... 1.) We were seated almost immediately, however we were put in the corner with a fold out table that actually had to be pulled out so I could sit and then scooted back in place because it was so crowded that I couldn't even get the chair out from under the table.  We would have waited to be seated at a real table but they seemed to want to get us in and out. 2.) It took the waiter 10 minutes to get us water and longer than that to take our order 3.) THEY FORGOT OUR FOOD!  I watched a group of girls get seated and get their food almost immediately.  What pissed me off more was that it was the same plate we ordered 20 minutes prior. We had to flag down our waiter who brought our first dish, wait another 10 minutes and get our second dish and then flag him down a 3rd time just to get our side of rice we ordered.   4.) They never once apologized for forgetting our dinner.    By that point I had lost my appetite completely.  It was my boyfriend's birthday and all we wanted was a good meal.

ckMFtaljrmXWaSiQqk9ZWA.review_text: Disclaimer: this review is for the karaoke rooms only.  Great place to do karaoke.  It seems a little sketch at first, because the karaoke rooms (only 3) are all tucked away in what would be the attic of the building, and away from the restaurant/bar area downstairs.  But once you get past that part, the rooms are pretty good!  A little musty/barf smelling when we first walked in, but then our noses adapted, and everything was great from then on.  Totally reasonable prices for karaoke - $30 per hour, plus a $10 min per person (but more if you stay longer than 2 hours).  They have a pretty good selection of songs, and the service is very good.  Soju was delicious, but not too strong.  I thought the owner lady was fantastic.  Super friendly staff - nice place!  Now if I could only get over the fact that I felt like an old hag when I was there... definitely more for the younger crowd! (e.g. early to mid 20s).

zpXqbJQ2CT4PsUBTy30DbQ.review_text: -1 star for the fly that was in my friend's cocktail. -1 star for #43 i believe. The picture looked like a tom yum style soup that came with veggies and seafood.  The broth tasted like dirty water and the seafood was like whole creatures. -1 for the other entree. not very hot and it tasted funky. I think that was #48. -1 for the service.   I don't know if I just don't like Korean food or what, but I did not like this place at all.   OH, and if I could minus another star, I would for the martini that I did order extra dirty, although it was extra extra dirty and it seemed like they dumped the entire jar of olive juice into my martini.

kqlN-k5PtDm4MEdwbrPVuA.review_text: Considering there are not a lot of Korean soju lounges in SF, this place is sort of the only option that is if you don't feel like trekking to Richmond or sunset.  The drinks are ok, the food is decent but compared to NYC, they kinda suck, but it'll have to do.  If you just want to have a laid back night with friends and eat Korean comfort food and drink, then come here.  If you want to sing Karoake on the weekend, good luck.  They only have 3 rooms and the wait is atrocius!  We called in 5 hours before to reserve a room, the lady told us we have to reserve a week in advance if we want a room during the peak hours.  F' that!  Karoake is a spontaneous thing, not a plan a week in advance thing.  So I suggest, drink some soju, eat some grub, and then head over to Do Ra Mi karoake which is on the same block.

OVo7FDZjjsEP01cNRTH3kw.review_text: Very cool and fun place to hang out in Japantown. My friends and I stopped by after the Cherry Blossom Festival for a few drinks and appetizers. We ordered garlic fries and a plate of mixed sausages, and overall the food was good. There's also a full bar, but the soju mixed drinks are fun to order when you're with a larger group. My favorite thing about this place is that they will play kpop if requested.

3rWdCM2_AK7GWQlwzRO99Q.review_text: It's like the Worldbeats of Oakland, relocated to SF (if you went to Cal, you know what I'm talking about). Extremely fun times - great atmosphere, very yummy food and cheap soju/ginormous OBs. For six people, the total bill was $83 and we all left very drunk/fatty mc fats.

M5_jWLsgTqkYMBQnIZsd9Q.review_text: I like to think that I tend to be pretty forgiving with restaurants... but this place is subpar all around.  The korean food they serve is not great ... not bad either but you could get better at a place like toyose (sp?) out in sunset. For the price, I expect more.  I mean come on... how do you mess up frozen yogurt (which comes sprinkled with fruity pebbles ... at least that's what I think that was).  And thank you for the fried platter, which probably came from the frozen food aisle.   As a bar, I suppose its okay if all you are really here for is soju and korean beer but that's pretty much all.  The service, quite frankly, is the worst and why I am giving this place one star.  Come here if you are looking for inattentive and rude service (at least my experience on this particular night).  I am surprised by the number of good reviews here and maybe I'm in the minority.  But I have rarely come out of a restaurant so displeased.    Oh yeah, the owners should look into cleaning the ladies' room a bit more thoroughly.  It's gross especially since food is being served here (at the restaurant I mean.... obviously not in the bathroom! What I'm trying to convey here and it may be because I'm not a writer is  that this is an eating establishment and cleanliness is important to me!). Then again, maybe they can get away with these bathrooms because this place can be considered more of a bar.  will not be recommending this place to anyone who asks me where they can get korean food in the city.  (Note: I just changed this review from one star to two stars because my husband made me do it.  he was a regular and now he is not).

CIyICwrEeEVCuuBUmaSdOQ.review_text: Great for Korean food and drinks.  I love their JaJang Min, kimchee tofu, and all their stir-fried dishes. blogs.kqed.org/food/2008…

CB5ogb0l1oCBxh5TdhQevA.review_text: For SF this a great little spot for some korean drinking food, beer and soju.  Not a local so I was pretty excited to stumble upon this joint.

2MbKqqyCbh5VlwbsIYq5Cw.review_text: Not impressed!!  Usually, for me, the point of going to a Korean bar is to order ridiculous amounts of food and alcohol and to inhale both at a disgusting rate. Completely not possible here at the Playground because everything is overpriced! Since when does a plate of dumplings (the cheapest thing on the menu) end up being almost $10?? After getting settled in and over how much everything cost we proceeded to try and get the waitresses attention for a good 10 minutes. Then...we waited a longass time to get our food which was served in 10 minute increments! First came the Jiajiang noodles (pretty standard, not bad), then the Soondoobu (GROSS and unsatisfying!), then the chicken (ok). Ugh.   In a horrible mood I hoped that the large yogurt soju and OB beer would save the day but although the yogurt soju was good it could not redeem this extremely disappointing experience.   Sorry Playground...the next time I have that yearning for the Korean bar experience I will have to resort back to the East Bay where they do it right.

ubbh74uR_FVEEcr3I6gpdw.review_text: i've always seen this place from the outside, but never went in until I saw it on Check Please! on PBS! The food looked yummy, the waitstaff looked friendly and so my bf and I came here late one night after work.   It was totally not what it looked like on TV. The staff was friendly, but no where to be found. I think the waiter and waitress were overwhelmed at how busy it was. There were people waiting, empty tables not cleared and people waving the staff down to get service.  dark, dim with blue neon lights, tv screens with Korean Pop and blasting the latest R&B/Rap .. not too loud so conversations can carry. People were obviously smoking in the karaoke rooms above so it stank like cigarettes and my coat, purse, hair and clothes stank like cigarettes when we left.   The food is great though. I wish I came with more people so we could have tried more. Fried Chicken Wings with Special Sauce - Cripy, juicy, meaty, nice salad on the side.. yum! BiBimBap in the Stone Bowl - It was yum, but I've had better. Maybe the stone wasn't hot enough, the rice didn't crisp up as much as I would have liked it, but the ingredients were fresh. Jajangmyeon - yummy! had the beef and potato instead of the seafood. authentic, but I think the one downstairs, down the block at San Wang is better.  thumbs up: food, portions, good for a fun group thumbs down: slow service, cigarettes

INi56PgdBBxz0i_V_-_cGg.review_text: I had one of my birthday parties here, and we had a complete blast! They are also one of few places in Japantown with a full bar. I booked a private karaoke room for two hours, and we sang the night away. Playground has a huge selection of songs. They already had "Only Girl In The World" by Rihanna and "Like A G6" by Far East Movement. Now they need to get Katy Perry's "Teenage Dream." My friend Audrey knows the owner of the place, and we got some nice perks like free food. The fried plate of fries, mozzarella sticks and nuggets was devoured quickly. Bottle service is actually pretty reasonable, and the waiters are great as well!  The only surprise was how fast the time went by when you're doing drunken karaoke. If you love to sing, I would say book your room for even longer than you think needed.  ~A

UVO0vrdc8Jfm00p7ixuf7A.review_text: The food is ok. Would say it's pricey and taste is alright  Many tables usually no wait. Young crowd

aBgTKRRj8uUMycpcrcGlxQ.review_text: This place was ok - not too great though...  The song selection was eh.   I feel like it's a bit pricey (well at least compared to karaoke in Japan - which I would be at Pasela or somewhere awesome for this price).   The food and alcohol is nothing special.  but it was a WHOLE LOT OF FUN in a big group!  :)

TNWQuWa3kLH2Llx10LW1Yw.review_text: omg cheese corn, where have to been all my life?  it sounds and looks so wrong but damn those greasy, cheesy morsels were yummy.  the food wasn't mind blowing but definitely more than edible.  this isn't really where i would go for dinner but to to play instead.  oh, is that why it's call playground??  omg!  i haven't experienced karaoke here yet besides being mesmorized by the giant images of korean music videos on the wall.  but who cares about all that when you're having an insane amount of yogurt soju and fro-yo with fruity pebbles?!

I2dVatJGkc8oVDxc4G058Q.review_text: Karaoke: Totally fun.  Karaoke Rooms: Cramped.  Hot.  Smelly.  Dirty.  Overpriced.  Privacy a plus, though.    Drinks: Strong  Food:  Didn't eat any.  Menu was sticky.  Sticky menus are a turn off.  Overall:  While it's great to have a private room, it was totally overpriced when you consider the per hour charge and the food minimum charge.   I have no problem paying a per hour charge, but felt it was high considering the state of the rooms.  The 18% gratuity is very generous considering the lack of attentive service.  The whole place seemed dirty, I've never used Purell, but I wanted to douse myself in it by the time we left.  This place gets points for strong drinks, Karaoke, and the private room concept.

fZoN7uy3Ifr8R0xIQRCLjQ.review_text: Journey, check! Earth, Wind, and Fire, check! Madonna, check!  My friends and I celebrated a dear friend's birthday at Playground this past weekend.  Overall, we had a blast.  Janet and Jin were very helpful.  I changed my reservation three times...oops; and they were always so accommodating. The food was delicious.  The soju kept on coming.  Our karaoke machine down on us.  Probably due to all the awesome singing...it couldn't handle greatness.  LOL

_pIG1_s6Bzymn1zeyLjBHQ.review_text: I love eating here. It's as casual or as fancy as you want it to be (the latter, within reason... I mean don't go there in your evening gown, ladies) and the food is good, alcohol abundant and the music is nice.   It's very.... blue.  The lighting is blue... and well, it's very blue.  The menu is quite expansive and has something to please everyone.  For those not familiar with Korean food, you will have trouble figuring out what's what - but try something different from the regular Korean dishes like Bulgogi and other typical stuff.  That stuff, you can always have somewhere else that is known for those particular dishes.  At Playground, you get to eat other foods that are usually eaten in Korea but with a twist of some sort.  For instance, their fried chicken is extremely tasty - and fried to perfection, no grease, just all hot and juicy.  It accompanies a beer like none other.  They also serve this unusual variation of the Chinese/Korean "Jja jang Myun" - - on a plate.  This one is rather spicy due to the jalapenos that grace the plate, so if you are prone to running for the bathroom or panting like a dog at the first hint of hot peppers - - this might not be for you.  I happen to be someone who has yet to encounter anything remotely "TOO SPICY" - so bear that in mind.  Their "al jjigae", also quite spicy, was very good.  I've also had a variety of other foods while there, though I can't remember them right now - and all have been good or better.  And we can't forget the corn cheese or cheese corn - whatever it's called.  A sizzling platter of corn bathed in butter, and covered in cheddar cheese... it's a small heart attack on a plate, and greasy as anything gets but quite yummy.  As I always say - you're eating out, get over your diet.  "Diet who?"  I have not tried everything yet since they reopened - but give me a few months... I am there a lot, it seems.  Their alcohol choices are great.  They have a full bar as well as a wide variety of sojus and beers.    This is a nice place for casual dates, gatherings with friends, or just hanging out on any given night of the week. You can go to eat, drink a little or enough to be carried out.  Be careful with that fruity mixed soju stuff - - it can kill you if you begin to believe you're sipping on juice.  They are opened late on weekends (until 2 AM) and I believe they close at varying times on certain weekdays.  Their hours are posted on the door... go look, don't ask me. And when you're there - check out that fried chicken, I tell you.  Good stuff!

2ciexSOVWX_jzN7rtyYRnw.review_text: pretty good Korean food , prices are a bit steep but by the time you get the check you will be way to buzzed to care,

NK4TEx8QUbe2CkAWVTkjug.review_text: 3.5 Stars.  Oh that sweet cheese corn!   This is your normal Korean late night beer, soju and anju dive, but they do some dishes pretty darn well.  I like the cheese corn, the kim chee tofu, and spicy sea food ja jang.  A friend of mine had a miniature cow when I ordered the regular ja jang.  But despite miniature cow and all, the spicy ja jang was better.  It's located right above the Japantown Denny's.  There're also rooms for private karaoke, but I haven't tried them yet.  Dishes are approximately $10.  I appreciated the fact that this place also provided side-dishes like a normal Korean restaurant.

xMTmf2rJZsvqPZmM36-lMw.review_text: Food: Awesome.  Every person I've brought to this place LOVED the food.  Cons: Overpriced.  But I guess they have to pay the rent and the employees.    Drinks:  They got a little bar and serve alcohol at the tables.  Drinks are good.  Hite and OB are the best beers I've had thus far.  Lemon soju is good too.   Price of the cocktail soju I think is WAY overpriced.  I've seen the amount of lemon juice vs. soju they put in the pitcher and the put so little of it.  I guess they had to make it taste decent but still!  I want my money's worth you know?  Service:  Two-thumbs up.  No superb service but they are polite and definately listen and are timely with helping you.  I have no complaints.   I'm not a smoker, so they should put up a sign that says "No smoking within 25 feet of this building" or "GO DOWNSTAIRS AND SMOKE."   Bathroom: ONLY ONE TOILET! So ladies, it would be wise to use the urination station elswhere before coming in.   Ambience:  Lively, dim-lit bar/restaurant.  Lots of young folks.  Sometimes the place is full and you have to wait, sometimes you don't.    Bottom line: Food and service is good.  Everything else could be better.

5U7TL7snFYmyHuO59OYEpw.review_text: There's a reason why there are incomprehensible lines on weekends at Playground, and all of them are good.  Good times have been had, time and time again at Playground.  Yes, service can be slow, but the waiters are pretty keen.  On one particular visit, a dish took way too long to cook up.  We got an explanation for the hold up, and were comped a bowl of noodle soup for our time.  No problem, as we're staying for drinks and the hilariously fun soju cocktails and giant-sized Korean beers anyways.  In between shots, you can ogle the Asian pop playing on the wall, or make snarky comments about the Russians getting silly drunk a few tables down.    I don't really understand the reviews here about the "high" prices and "so-so" food.  The plates are giiianormous and these reviews are missing the point of going to a Korean restaurant/bar joint.    $16 for a plate of fried chicken or $14 for Korean seafood pancakes that can feed 3-4 [non-Middle-America sized] people is not that pricey.  It also falls along what I expect culturally when I get with my Korean buds: go to a venue that serves food and booze, along some form of entertainment, whether it's K-pop, karaoke, or pool, share everything, and have a blast!  As for "so-so" food, who gives a crap when you're hosing yourself with soju?

WT1kawqQ43mXUNS2xL3Iyg.review_text: Ambiance: Fun!  Dark with blue lighting and a big TV screen to watch kpop videos. Downstairs dining area and upstairs for karaoke.  Food:  Tasty! The cheesy corn concoction is indeed amazing! Wish I could find some as good as this in LA or that I knew how to make it myself!

HAv257_IVJnQT0ZIL8Nn-Q.review_text: Ok so I have been coming here with friends for a few years. I always find something chill here. My favorite food by far is the cheese corn (which I just learned you always get ... ), and the Fire Chicken! which is awesome. Not really omg my mouth is on fire I can't taste anything, but more of a hey this has a kick and tastes good type of fire. You can get this with cheese too :) Basically I have never gone wrong with a dish. I have had the I guess strawberry flavored soju (really red one) and I didn't like that as much as just the normal yogurt one or even straight for that matter. Anyways yeah this place has it all :) Even semi awkward music videos playing in the background. Other than that it's a pretty cool place. I have gone to the karaoke as well here, it a little pricey but it's still fun. We have collectively decided in our group to go other places for karaoke for basically size of our groups and price but still this is our first spot to hit on a night out :)

PBmotLhDczArA10xRJ-_5w.review_text: A typical Koreatown bar.... but in SF instead of LA. You can expect what you'd see down south. Projectors with trendy MVs and random over presented Korean food to go along with the standard Korean alcohols.

tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ.review_text: First off, I love my friends for setting this up for me for my birthday.  We got one of the biggest private rooms, sang our hearts out, and drank every single flavor of soju made available.  Soju and I have a love/hate relationship.  I love the taste, but hate the effect.  They should not make alcohol that taste like one of my childhood favorite drinks (the yogurt soju is EVIL!).  Any night where we take pictures and don't remember them had to be a great night.  I hope.

OBtyvcdMA2OGrVdl3YjPSQ.review_text: Fun like this is a revolutionary act, people.  good food--good drink--good company--good fun singing and laughing so hard you'll loosen your dental work.

XpuNEgQPFBe0se9Agpprgg.review_text: I came here for my birthday with a large party (15 ish?) and I had a great time! The ambiance was cool - Korean music videos playing in the background and dim lighting. I ate the jajang myung (black bean noodle) with seafood and it was delicious! The cream corn cheese thing was good too, but I swear I can make it at home myself haha. Everything else was tasty too.   We also ordered a couple bottles of flavored soju. All the flavors that we tried were good! Definitely coming back!

25X-uRdgoLe0K5ArrnNrhg.review_text: I enjoy the playground because the staff there are super nice.   For Karaoke, there is a 18% service fee for everything. For example, the last time I went there with some friends we sang karaoke for two hours, some of them ordered food.  The bill came out to be about $150 plus service fee it was an additional $30 dollars.  So, consider that 'cuz we were surprise it came out to be so much. Overall, pretty good fun. They offer alcohol as well (in the lounge downstairs). YOu may also use a phone to order food (the phone is inside the karaoke rooms).  they have decent selection of korean/english songs, some chinese/tagalog/japanese songs. i don't like pressing the buttons to select songs though, I wish some day they will make it all computerized.   the corn/cheese thing was pretty good, it is free but u need to ask for it.

yoF5og4usGdK3AzFFWQV2g.review_text: Why 4 stars?  Because you can eat and drink in the Karaoke RoomS! Nice to see a place like this open up in Jtown again since the demise of Nan several months back.  (where the doobu place is now...)  Their Chiges are nice and hearty.  Pajun is light and airy and huge!  And yes... who can fergit the cheesy cream corn!  you look at it the first time like wtf?! but once you try it..  you'll tell yourself 'eh..not bad' and keep spooning it in while drinking your soju.  Tons of items on the menu and the portions are huge.  Plan on ordering one item per person.  Less if with females (sorry girls, no offense)  They have all the usual faire one would find at a venue like this.  Soju cocktails (lemon, yogurt, peach, strawberry, pineapple, etc) and beer of course.  Bar with hard liquor as well. I plan to go back to cause more damage very soon...  btw karaoke room is 30/hr and can seat about 10 easy

3UtTalOKNJ2Iz5CHoLdA0Q.review_text: Why is it that this place gets such good reviews? Have they not ventured out to outer sunset where Toyose and The Spot Lounge exist??  The food was not good nor was it authentic. Their dukbooki ramen was NOT good. The sauce was very orange and the ramen tasted like Maruchan cooked and plopped into orange spicy sauce. Nonononoo. I understand ramen isn't very fancy to begin with, but this place --- Just no.  I've had my fair share of good yogurt soju from Vegas, San Diego, along with Toyose added to the list. This place was WAY too sweet. They used syrup to mix their drinks. The green apple tastes exactly like Midori, yet sickenly sweeter. The yogurt soju was missing the slight carbonated Sprite taste which is definitely necessary in the recipe. Orange soju, pineapple soju, peach soju, strawberry... That's half the list and none was up to par.   I guess the only part I liked was the fact they accomnodated 15 of us. The waitress looked pissed most of the night, but the waiters were quick and friendly. I also enjoyed the Korean music videos.  Overall, no. I'm going back to Toyose for strawberry soju or aloe soju with real fruit bits in it. Delish!

S24qvVzFBFy4eQPfQzRJfQ.review_text: The spicy chicken is great here. Get it all the time when @ playground.

jYohp-vdOB_BVPRtZe1UDA.review_text: There simply is no such thing as good rent-a-room karaoke in San Francisco.  At least you can drink in the rooms here, unlike Do Re Mi.  Great quality sound system, but the songs all sound like they were recorded by the now-deceased Wesley Willis on his cheap-ass Casio keyboard.  There's no list by artist either.  Not a harmony joy ride.

lhBhdyUAJZhDnGPy92O5og.review_text: Awesome place, awesome food, love it and I keep going back! Thumbs up

LUj0l-kLPO9OUdg1bahiww.review_text: This place is hip and happening!! They blasted Korean/Japanese hip hop music the whole time and had tv's playing provocative music videos. It was dark inside which kinda made it feel like a club.  It was pretty busy when we went on a Saturday night so we seated ourselves. The servers came quickly, took our order, and brought out the food super fast. I like efficient service!!  We ordered the spicy dumplings. OMG they were spicy! They will spice the HELL out of you!! (that's my new saying) It was delicious! We also ordered the Soju (not a big fan), it was my first time, and it was super strong. I guess you get your money's worth?? Haha everything was tasty and the portions were big.   So $31 for spicy dumplings and soju, thumbs up from me.

aN7W4ujVXCz-HR3hsJ5i0g.review_text: I've heard the food is great and the chicks are hot-mmkay but for my first time I experienced neither. We only had 1 drink each and I left the newbie bartender a cash tip. When this is the tip I should've left: Hello server, training as a bartender. I'm assuming bc after we ordered a Glen Livet neat and a bitters and soda he was befuddled by attempting to punch in the order meanwhile my dry mouth was becoming more and more thirsty. We had to point out the Glen Livet 12 (no big deal), he was looking for bitters on the spirits shelf, and when it proved too challenging I said a 'club soda' w/lime and the Glen Livet came in a shot glass.  Poor guy was so nervous or had been recently yelled at by someone he was so skittish and we just wanted a drink. Relax, buddy you're at a bar. Try, "Hey guys how are you?" while throwing down 2 napkins in front of us w/a smile. Get our drinks (When you're serving you want to get their order in first, but we were 2 of 3 ppl at the bar and #3 had his beer -there is no one else around)  I hope to come back to experience great food, hot chicks and more relaxed bartender who has been properly trained in customer service. But perhaps this is what happens in a Korean joint in J-Town.

5Ap91V6vM4wgxgJeCu68-Q.review_text: Ok, so...  1) They have mango AND kiwi soju cocktails! I've never had those ANYWHERE else before.  2) The soju cocktails are strong, and you can pour tons more plain soju in them.  3) Their kim chee fried rice is actually kinda spicy.  I need to go back when I haven't eaten, so I can try more of the food...

CmmxEUXqkG18L0TQesXAUQ.review_text: How do I loathe thee? Let me list the ways.  Starting with service. When one walks into a business, it's always nice to be greeted with a semblance of hospitality or at the very least courtesy. Neither one was found when my friends and I came in after we reserved a private room for karaoke. We were greeted instead by a snarky host (who obviously would rather not be there. ) Before we even got situated we were asked to sign a contract. Say what? A contract? All I wanted to do was sing, not sign my life away. Be forewarned, that when you agree to use the private room you're guaranteed to spend more than $30. It's not enough to pay for the room at $30/hr, you also have to spend $20 PER PERSON ON TOP OF THE ROOM RATE. My friends and I were naive enough to assume that the contract meant $20 minimum on food and drink was meant for the group. Oh no, we were greatly mistaken.   Let's talk about the reason we even went to this place: the karaoke. If you came here expecting karaoke with the background vocals to diffuse the flaws in your singing voice, then hit the road Jack because you're not gonna find that here. Everyone's going to hear the nuances of your lovely (or not so lovely singing voice) so drink up liquid courage before you take center stage. If you don't speak a lick of Korean, then the song choices are cut to about 1/3 of the entire library of songs. From the 8 or so song books found, only 3 of them had English songs in them. Finally, be warned about the oh so sticky pages. If we're paying more than $30, the least we can expect is cleanliness. Sheesh. Sure they have a handful of top 40 hits, and a sprinkling of alternative and some oldies here and there, but after 2 hours it all sounds a bit redundant.   Now for the food. My friends and I ordered the standard munchies like garlic fries, popcorn chicken, and pot stickers. Although they weren't horrendous, they weren't spectacular either. I can get better versions of the aforementioned munchies for a fraction of the price at a local boba place. The thing that really got my blood boiling was the $20 fruit platter. $20 for a fruit platter isn't all that ridiculous for a restaurant you say? Well if ALL THE FRUITS WERE FROM A CAN, then yeah it is. It really fucking is. The least they could have done was cut a couple of fresh oranges or throw a handful of grapes in there. But no, that might have been too much effort. The only saving grace was the soju. I recommend the yogurt and lychee ones. Can the soju compensate for all that was lacking? No, not by a stretch.   My friends and I ended up spending $36 each for three hours, six appetizers, and four rounds of soju (two small and two large.) We ended up paying for only 2 hours because of the misunderstanding with the food and drink minimum fee. Still, there was a disparity from what we were expecting from other people's reviews and what we actually got.   So if you want a grand little time with your friends while singing some tunes and sipping some soju, look a little bit harder. I can't imagine a worse experience than what my friends and I had.

lEpnjfCk9n29YkmhnOfuYA.review_text: THIS PLACE IS DISAPPOINTING! Came in for my friends birthday for a party of 30. They messed up my order so they gave me 2 free plates on the house. The first one was too spicy for me so I couldn't eat it, the second one were noodles, I finally got my plate 2 and a half hours after I placed my order and an hour after everyone was doing eating. I kept asking them about my order and they kept saying its coming out while everyone else were getting their orders. Wtf. NEVER COMING BACK EVER AGAIN!

fo1goU7F2eYwJqOzGSP3Jw.review_text: Awful. Awful. Awful.  Horrible service. Disgusting food.  I've only ever written one other bad restaurant review. Boy does this one deserve it.  My friends and I are pretty easy going, but the food was unedible.  When we left we went to a pizza place just to get something to fill our stomaches. The service was a joke. After our food was served the waiter never came back once. We had to go ask for the check, he wouldn't pick up the plates off our table, never came to see how our meal was.  And to boot, it was expensive.  The sweet and sour pork turned out to be deep friend pork skins - revolting. The squid salad with mixed vegetables was hard as rubber and had no vegetables.  They even screwed up noodles.  How do you screw up noodles?!  This place should be shut done.

2eEXWqhKYtQfhvjMtn6ERA.review_text: I love this place.  The food was so much better than I ever expected.  My favorite dish was the fried shrimp.  We also got the yogurt soju which was soooooooooooo yummy.    All the servers were friendly and courteous.  But my favorite thing about Playground was the atmosphere.  I usually don't hang out at places like Playground, but I had so much fun there.  The people there were all having a good time & the Korean music videos were a blast!  If you're looking for a quiet place, this is not the place to go.  But if you're looking for a fun spot, Playground is it!!!

_uU06wZkLrSJmhgZiIhIgw.review_text: Good food and good music. Gotta order the spicy garlic wings (even though I don't do well with spicy). Service is good but slow on busy nights. Great place to hang with friends for drinks.

AiQL1INckKUk1Bx2WD8ozw.review_text: It's great!  Sing your heart out while also drinking yummie flavored soju and eating yummie food.  The price is right (I think it was $30 an hour for our middle room), the place is clean, and the songs were easy to program.  The place gets filled up on the weekends so make sure you reserve the room.  We started off at do rei mi, and that wasn't as nice (but had more rooms) in my opinion.  It was also harder to get the japanese songs onto the machine because it was a separate machine.  But the selection was better for japanese songs at do rei mi.  But I'm not japanese, and I only sing utada hikaru from memory, so I definitely prefer playground overall.  Can't wait to go back.

IwZOjxYo2p8olromlfFMsg.review_text: Being new to Korean food, I had a great experience.  I found the food to be similar to some Korean BBQ places I have been, but seemed a little more on the bar food side of things.  The food had great portions and tasted fantastic.  The scene seemed very friendly.  We came just for dinner and did not par take in any of the late night activities. The service was top notch. I recommend the yogurt soju (large) and hite pitchers.

ZdY3VTgSHaLgCfnRZEeosQ.review_text: Another hot korean drinking spot in SF. Good for any size group. They offer soju cocktails in a good variety of flavors in 2 sizes, small ($14) or large ($25), but what stands them apart is a fully stocked bar that has it's own area and seating if you just want a drink. Yes you can mix! Soju + beer + wine + vodka + whiskey + gin + etc... = A GREAT (UN)FORGETTABLE NIGHT!!!HAHA if you catch my drift.  They also have karaoke up stairs (you can order drinks and food while singing your heart out) can this night get even better?! (~$30/hr FYI, and I recommend calling in advance to reserve a room) I've only been in the karaoke rooms once, I usually go for the tables.  Yes it can! Their food is pretty good, I would rate them 3-4 stars. What's memorable is their cheesy corn and potato salad banchan and OMG IT'S FREE?! They also offer a good variety of dishes to go with your alcohol like korean style fried chicken (perfect drunk food), stew pots (great for sharing), noodle dishes, rice cakes, your typical korean dishes, etc. And the more you drink the better the food tastes!   All their dishes range from $10-$20. Expect to spend around $20-50 (on the pricier side for me).  Service was ok. Don't expect them to stop by your table and ask how you're doing. It's more of the waving down kind of service. But they respond quickly.  They usually play kpop on a giant projector and on multiple tvs. Distracting for me because my eyes are always drawn to a TV screen no matter what is on.  Parking shouldn't be too bad to find. But if all else fails, there's a garage that closes late (If I remember correctly, it's only $1/hr :O Does that even exist in SF?!)  I used to come here more often when I lived down the street. But now I live closer to other spots like Toyose and the Spot. But I miss that cheesy corn. :( Maybe it's time to return.

RGrDTsVmcUBCOUOn49y-wg.review_text: This is a small-ish but decent place to go with your friends late night for an Asian style bar and some Asian pop star music videos showing in the background which you can't really hear over the noise. You can still gaze dreamily though like the true Asian (or non-Asian) fan you know you are.  The drinks are okay priced but the appetizers and food are totally overpriced for what you get. Nonetheless at 1am you are hungry and you will pay for it. But beware! Last time I ordered a dish and asked for "very mild spicy please", and what came was this dark red covered dish. I was like "What? Mild spicy my arse. There is no way anyone could think this is mild spicy." Even our Korean friend was like "Whoa, that's kinda spicy." You serious? The only way to even make this thing edible was to ask for a cup of water and then wash off the sauce in the cup of water. It was a cup of red after like 2 seconds. Wow. Then I asked the waiter, and he goes to another waiter, probably the head waiter, and then he comes and goes like "That's mild spicy", then he walks away. The only saving grace here is that at the end the head waiter guy brought us some sweet, cold yogurt right before we paid. Great. Not really good customer service, but at least he gave us some type of compensation...if only he had apologized or something. Normally places will offer to take it away or waive it from the bill if they prepare it wrong, but nothing here. So lesson learned, don't order food here unless you want some atomic red goodness that burns the taste buds straight off your tongue.   UNLESS, it is happy hour (5-7pm everyday), where well drinks, beer, soju, soju cocktails, and appetizers are 50% off. Then it's semi-worth it to order appetizers and maybe some soju. ~$5-8 per appetizer and $12-14 for delicious soju cocktails. The soju cocktails are pretty much why I'm giving this place 3 stars. Get the soju cocktails.   Bottom line: 1) Come during happy hour 2) Get (any of) the soju cocktails 3) The sweet potato fries are not what American's think of as sweet potato fries. They are more like skinny sweet potato chips (maybe 1/4 inch wide by 2-3 inches long each and 2 mm thick) that have powdered sugar sprinkled over them. They aren't bad, but just warning you that they aren't what most people would normally expect. 4) Don't expect fast service or even food being prepared to the way you ask, unless maybe if you speak the native language, but even then I don't know.

w84JfFJm1TbQZ_iO_hXjXw.review_text: FUN times here! But how could I not have fun when the food & drink minimum is $15/per person...?!  We literally had soju bottle after soju bottle to make the price per person minimum.  And then when the drunchies came, someone in the group ordered 3 plates of jap chae! It quickly became a hot mess.  At the end of the night, the waiter was nice enough to box up the leftover jap chae, but of course, you can't take the soju to go ... so someone downed all the leftover drinks... HOT MESS!  To prepare for next time, I will make sure I plan to not dine/drink somewhere else beforehand.  I hate the expensive mimimum per person (darn you SF inflated prices -__-), but I guess it does guarantee a good time!

vkcbILTGGd1ejg5xSmAHeQ.review_text: So I showed up with a group of 8 around 4:50pm on Sunday. Not gonna lie, there's a possibility that some of us were a bit tipsy after getting a late lunch w/ bottomless mimosas. My friends were a bit anxious and we proceeded to walk in as the clock hit 5:00pm.  First impression, this place looks cool. The ceilings are high and they have large windows that let in natural light; the cool part about this is that the place showed a blue-ish hue that made the atmosphere really relaxing. There were multiple TVs on the walls so it wasn't too difficult to watch the game.   Anyways, after my group barged in, I apologized to our server, but he didn't seem to mind in the slightest. He gave us a few menus but the only thing that we looked at was happy hour menu. Oh man, everything was pretty cheap (especially if you split with 8 people). We started with an order of popcorn chicken, 2 bottles of soju, and a lychee ice. The food came out relatively quickly and it came in a pretty large portion. Just a heads up, I thought the lychee ice would be a drink, but it's literally a good amount of lychees laying on a bed of ice.   Everything tasted really good so we ordered 2 more orders of popcorn chicken and a plate of dumplings. At this point, I had sobered up, but the rest of my friends were ready to KO. Strangely, since my friends were so quiet, I could tell that the other patrons in this place were also quiet. I thought this was a little strange, but nobody complained that we were a little loud when we entered.  Overall, if I knew that this place existed, I would come here instead of bottomless mimosas. You can get full and drunk for such a low price here! Oh and the service is really chill and helpful

ENWYFwsp6gxLIn2c-86ynQ.review_text: We both ate here last year. We read they had 'brown sauce noodles" and immediately made reservations for 6pm on a Saturday night. Well, the place was empty, giving us thoughts that maybe the food taste like crap! After the lst bite of 'brown sauce noodles", i didn't give a shit who was there or not! This place is the best for 'brown sauce noodles!". Ahh...i have to say, it ain't for old folks like us to hang out, it's for the youngsters who came storming in fighting for a Karaoke room upstairs at 8pm! So, you see, I am glad we were seated at 6pm, and it was empty because i was so afraid to run into my friend's kids!! I will definitely return for the noodles!

W7sQ50m0VADz-RD2To4YNQ.review_text: Looking for a chill hang out spot with good food and drinks? Playground is the place to be. Its a great balance of just laying low but still having fun. On the weekends it gets pretty crowded and there can be a wait. There are Korean pop videos playing on the big screen and steamy platters of delicious kal bi ready to be devoured by all the hungry drunks.   My favorite drink is the yogurt cocktail soju. I use that to chase my the pure soju in the green bottle. Mixing them is good if you prefer a strong cocktail. They also have a full bar if you're not big on soju. For those that don't know what soju is, it's basically a rice wine that tastes like vodka. It's a creeper, fyi.  There are also private karaoke rooms upstairs and a minimum on food/drinks must be spent in order to reserve one of these rooms.

_t8PCMgYp21pKmEflbasug.review_text: My first impression after stepping one foot into the restaurant:  "Why is the men's bathroom door propped open?"  That made urinating a rather self-conscious experience, as you are within plain view of other incoming patrons.  The karaoke rooms were all booked up.  My friends' food took forever to come out.  The food and the Korean beer were decent, however.  At the end of the night, as we were walking to our car, they ran after us to ask if we had paid the bill.  They didn't see our wad of cash because we didn't put the money with the white handwritten receipt, but instead on the middle of the table.

GZRgrSF4Z65w6ToFd4nXlA.review_text: If your looking for well prepped and authentic Korean cuisine do not come here expecting it.   If you want some cheap beer, salty trashy food that you wouldn't admit to yourself you ate the next day ( i.e. frozen corn w/melted cheese on top? ...) wash that down with plastic 40s of cheap Korean beer and sprinkle some blaring high-class Korean Pop on theater sized screens... then this is the place to fulfill your most kitchy late night drunken fantasies.   This is the one place on my SF visit I didn't brag about visiting ~ however it was my guiltiest pleasure.

96IKLbNHdK-sOAjuMwoegw.review_text: I came here around 8:30 or so on a Monday night.   It was my first Korean BBQ experience, and I was impressed with the different delicious sides that come with the meal -- (can only remember a few. forgive me, for I am not too familiar with Korean cuisine) creamed corn, spicy vegetables, etc.. Everything was fresh and good, but the only part of the meal that kinda let me down was the main part -- the meat. Not the best, but decent, I guess.   Service was excellent, by the way.   I really like the concept of this place. Karaoke room / restaurant / bar. Perfect combination. Next time I'm definitely going to tear up the noraebang!

GIMg5oHqsJXdRq_7tR2jjQ.review_text: Food: I came here with Jason C. and we ordered so much food I thought I was going to die.  Luckily Miranda R. came to the rescue by showing up and finishing all the food we couldn't eat.  That girl can eat anyone under the table.  I learned that most of the food here is not really Korean food, but more of a Korean-Chinese fusion.  It was a little different for me, but I ate.  I loved the corn and the pot stickers, clearly I played it safe.  The yogurt Soju is so good that I think I accidentally drank too much and had the worst hang over of my life the next day.  Koreans can drink!    Karaoke: Of all the Karaoke places in the city I think Playground is one of the nicest.  Remind me to wear my glasses, however, next time I come here since for some reason I could not read the words on these television monitors.  I would like if they had more rap selections.  I can't sing for sheet, but this girl can flow.  Can anyone just have a section by artist?  That would be fantab!

Rx7DNBmPPShVjlcQidGuTw.review_text: 3.5 stars for the food, but 4 stars for staying open late!!  if you are at a loss about where to eat late at night, then come here!  this is not a good place to come if you want a quiet evening out, b/c the music is played very loud here.  however, it's a good place to lounge and eat.  two of us shared the soondubu and the champon.  both were good, but the champon was HUGE.  i think it could have fed a family of four.  there aren't too many panchan, but it did the job.

rtTpEZSTIDSurdw12xZK1Q.review_text: NEW DISCOVERYYYY... I thought a lot of korean bars in SF disappered until we found the Playground on Yelp... not only is it a restaurant/korean bar.. but it has a KARAOKE ROOM.. AND u can order drinks there.. i find a lot of bay area karaoke places that does not let u order drinks... but at Playground.. you have yummy (yet weak) yogurt sojus.. the room is $30 per hour... and we ordered some food while drunk karaoking.. yummm... remind me of SD days....

_E3yaczgef7enusOIf7Jug.review_text: Came here for karaoke and drinks.  I think they have three private rooms in their upstairs section for karaoke.   In terms of edibles, I enjoyed their: --- yogurt soju (made with those little bottles of yogurt, jam packed with lacto bacillus and calcium - sure to make me regular and keep my bones strong!) --- black bean noodles (like zha jiang mian) --- fried chicken --- seafood pancake Food/drink service is very quick.  My biggest qualm is their lack of modern pop songs.  Everything was from at least 5 years ago.  I was missing my Lady Gaga and Biebs!

OCcHlcwqFtHcKFo5t4UBYA.review_text: Playground, I really, really wanted to like you. Anything that appears on "Check please, Bay Area!" automatically earns my respect, especially when everyone on the show gives it the best reviews ever. And, what can be better than singing kareoke, downing beer, AND eating all in the privacy of one room?  Since I'm official party planner for most events (I suppose), I called to reserve a room, which is thirty bucks an hour with a minimum of 10 bucks per person. They were very good about giving me the room, and it was a good price for a two hour session. Upon arriving, I was able to easily let them know that our party was going to be one less person and it was no problem. However, they ask that you give them your credit card just in case there might be some kind of "damage." I thought this was a bit odd, I mean, how much trouble could you get into while singing kareoke? As soon as I handed my card over, she handed me some tambourines, which I think is pretty dangerous when you consider the number of Filipinos who would give their right arm to have these things during kareoke. Me being one of them.   We were led upstairs to a small, but big enough room for our group of eight people. Our waitress was very lovely and nice, and showed us how to use the remotes for the machine, both of which were in English and Korean. We ordered drinks, and when she said we were ready, we could order through this black phone on the wall, which made this place even more awesome.   And I guess once we got through the cool quirks about the place, that's when the breakdown happened. We ordered a pitcher of Hite beer, and the next thing we knew, they came up with a bottle that looked like a huge soda liter. Upon first taste, it was flat, and this led my friend to say he didn't want anymore, so I had to chug that whole bottle by myself (I am not above chugging beer that will go to waste). The food looked good at first, especially the Dolsot bimbimap which was hot and just plain good upon arrival... it's really the only thing worth mentioning. What I expected to be better was the bbq short ribs! I mean, they were good, but they were just .... mediocre. That's how I can describe the food. And I was slightly buzzed, and this didn't really stop me from judging the food.  All in all, I probably wouldn't go back to Playground unless invited, or maybe just for dinner. But I loved the service and attentiveness, especially since we reserved a room. The kareoke is most definitely a highlight in this visit, especially since their selection is wide (it goes from Top 40 to World to beyond!). I recommend it if you've got a group of friends who want to try something different.

cc63x9MRwIwQn9QUZVXwKg.review_text: this is one of those restaurants where it is certain that you'll leave with alcohol in your system. The noise level at this place is comparable to a club, you'll have to speak at a tone where it appears that you are screaming... But that's the only way for you to get your message across to your friends or waiter. the dumplings there is good, same with their chicken wings that appear to have steroids injected into them because it's so big!! but yes.. This is a fun restaurant for you to get together with a group of friends to socialize and enjoy Korean food that caters to people who chooses to drink soju!!!  Beware: making reservations may make or break your dining experience there...a total of 2 times where I made reservations for a party of ten.. They some how manage to screw up the number of people or time... Just be sure to repeat your self and have them repeat it to you to confirm the number of people and time!

GnPIEtAOx4NsZuq9CNmEQA.review_text: After Shabu-ing it, we headed over to Playground and had so much fun! My colleagues had a post holiday celebration with a few pitchers of OBI and Carafes of Yogurt Soju.   Janet was the perfect hostess and showed us to our room. Make sure you make reservations, this place gets BUSY on Saturdays. For the two hours we reserved, we sang our little hearts out.   They had a vast selection of songs and were quick when we called down for more pitchers.   Although I didn't try any food, it looked sooo yum. I'll definitely be going back for the food and more karaoke fun!

x4dMlJWPH-iaNqdDoRwmqQ.review_text: This is where the beautiful Asian people go to eat. Nice eye candy and the boys often have funky hair-dos. The menu is SPICY. Great beer food and yogurt soju. Damn, its easy to get drunk here!

JnGtgOPpkjyWOvWM0SYEXg.review_text: morphed main level...transformed into restaurant setting..keeping bar in place...watering hole never the less....beers 'n' soju.....karaoke pushed up to the upper rooms....a bar/restaurant..korean name "no-lee-tto"...translates to "playground"..2nd floor (top of denny's in j-town)....korean drinking place....cheesy corns....rice if requested.....kkan-pong-beef finding decent.....budeh jjigeh just "okay," but overpriced.....overall decent food....drinks plenty....this ever so changing location finally finding success?....time will tell....come drink at the playground...

GUF4PL5UsDOjF__OQLIiYQ.review_text: Wow. I just realized I have never written a review for Playground, which is my favorite Korean restaurant in San Francisco. Also my favorite Korean bar and my favorite place to go NRB (Korean-style karaoke in a private room)....because you can order food and booze.   The food is fantastic - I recommend the bibim mandoo (dumplings in a Korean spicy sauce), tang soo yook (sweet and sour pork), gganpoong saewoo (shrimp in a totally different Korean spicy sauce), jjajangmyun (noodles in a black  bean sauce) and dooboo kimchi (kimchi, tofu, and sauteed veggies). The prices for food are more than reasonable, same for soju, and unlike most other Korean bars, they even have various liquors if that's what you prefer. The service is always fantastic and I love how if you order lots of food, you get free food or soju.  This is my go-to place for taking out of town visitors. In fact, my brother-in-law who is from Portland has had his last three birthday parties here. I think on the last one, everybody had such a good time, nobody remembers it. Thanks Playground!!!  UPDATE: Went to Playground with a bunch of non-Koreans, most of whom had never done Korean-style NRB. We were having too much fun but our reservation ran out so we went downstairs to Ssisso and did beer towers. We had so much fun that my wife and I both lost our phones. Thanks Playground!!!

zMmaQdrilVfTqn1mAyw0Mw.review_text: Came here for a friend's birthday and had a wild ass time. First off, they give you this appetizer that is literally CORN AND CHEESE. And it's delicious! They have a pretty good soju cocktail menu, and plenty of other kinds of alcohol to keep you busy. I didn't order any food, but people around me did and I think they were quite satisfied.  Service was overall pretty good. Stuff we ordered was delivered in a timely manner. People were nice to us. Or maybe I was just drunk? Dude, I had like 13 shots.

hxtr08X-pvyjhs4PPp4DwQ.review_text: Hands down the best Korean spot in SF.  Went here with my buddies last week to get our drink on and our eat on, and I was 100% satisfied.  The food was great.  We ordered the Yangnyum chicken, Kalbi short ribs, Kanpoong shrimp, and the Budae Chigae.  Everything was bomb dot com.  And with unlimited corn cheese and sides, who can beat that?  As usual, the soju never disappoints, until the next morning that is, when you get a huge hangover and can't get out of bed.  It was all very worth it tho.  Good food, good drinks, good service, good company.  Money well spent.  Looking forward to my next visit

qVKfU2bsumZxzNCHS6-dDg.review_text: Been here twice; first time, we sat at the bar and only ordered drinks and other time we sat at a booth and ordered food. The drinks are the usual (soju) but I felt that the soju cocktails could have been stronger. The food was good. It is pricier than most Korean bars I have been to BUT it is SF. We ordered the Kim Chee fried rice, some duk buk kee, japche, chicken wings, and had the corn for free. Our server was very nice and attentive since we were there around dinner time and the place was pretty empty. Would come more often but parking is usually tough to find around J-town.

BoNbRffFMN4YDtDGVJIvuw.review_text: $30 for a tiny karaoke room. Caution to tall folks out there and full on claustrophobic people, the room was tiny and I'm a petite gal! The remote controls were kinda hard to work and drinks have to purchased in addition to the room fee. The  food and drinks seem pricey yet appealing.  Just think twice about the space issue and the number of people you bring.

rP1JhMcc7sZTzW3KzLpL9w.review_text: Sure felt like a Playground!!   We had one of the rooms upstairs and although it was kinda cold at first, it quickly warmed up, and once you get singing.. nothing else really matters. The food was awesome, portions generous, drinks were TASTYYYYY and those waiting on us were the most patient and friendly peeps I've met in JTown. They were joking with us, helped us find songs, laughed with us (or at us?!?!).. just great!  The song selection was pretty good, although somewhat confusing.. but at least everybody in the party will find songs that they will like. 3 hours of karaoke room, food and drinks for 10 (although we didnt get drunk because we all had to drive) for $200something.. not bad, really!!  We all had an absolute blast and I really wish I had booked the room for the rest of the night.. oh well, next time!

W10iLe_5rS8LCScxUhGHug.review_text: I went here for my friend's birthday. It was great, they serviced us well, the food came fast and all the different soju they got (a must!!) and it was all good.   the only complaints is the 18% gratitude... and the fact that the words to the songs were a little off...  I would come here again for dinner for sure :)

4_6thhKcK6bgrr0UdG9xsg.review_text: playground is the shit. and by the shit, i mean exceptional. awesome food, awesome people that know how to take care of their customers..not to mention my favorite server ARLEN! he is a very sharp korean kid with a round face and impeccable memory, also knows how to really make you feel at home. consider yourself privileged if he is ever the one to take care of you.  oh yeah..major endorser of their cheesecorn. it's like a party in your mouth, and everyone's invited. :)

W_ds8g8jSNf2DLHcCHexxA.review_text: I've found out that this place is so much more fun if you arrive already intoxicated. Their food is alright but really seems to be overpriced... really nothing special. If you come with a big group of fun people, their karaoke rooms are SO FUN!!   The service was pretty good because the place just turns into a complete nuthouse that they need a lot of staff roaming around to see if people need more stuff (or to clean up drunken spills). It's a good place to have a super loud fun time.  Otherwise, if you're coming here for just a normal dinner.... go somewhere else.

20VlNq1zu8gzJ8g_tNByBQ.review_text: my friend wanted a mojito. The guy gave her a minty syrupy lemony sweet drink that tasted like a nasty lemonade. I guess he knew that he sucked, so he tried to give us another drink. Overall I had a really good time here, their food was pretty good. I enjoyed my tofu soup a lot.

8McGXwV6PHfYfG7ro6ZWfA.review_text: excellent place! i booked a large room for my group on a thursday night. this was the first time most of my friends had been to a korean restaurant/karaoke bar so i was a little bit scared at first- singing and eatting korean food is like the staple of korean culture so i really wanted them to have a good time and enjoy good quality korean food.   my fears were quickly quashed: the service was great- the waiters were all super friendly. the song choices blew my mind- all of our favorite songs were available to be butchered by us! and the food and drinks were plentiful and tasty. everyone had a fab time singing their little hearts out. whee!

1pSfJ4rVOfOKftAo801QSw.review_text: Super hip place to bring friends for a drink and listen to k-pop. I love it. All the interesting small dishes were delicious, especially the cheese and corn mixture. We ordered a combination noodle dish which was super spicy but perfect! Noodles had a nice texture to them. Korean style fried chicken was awesome and the seafood pancake was enough to feed 5! Bulgogi was delicious. they dont put so much onions on the platter. It's actually all beef. =) A++ place to go. will go back for sure!

geXaQzofMKiAgC44vsgGNg.review_text: WARNING: They have terrible service!!! We were told that our wait time was 20-30 minutes, we waited over one hour!! They are slow here!! It's too loud, crowded and dark!   Their Korean Fried Chicken taste like cheap Chinese food. It's nothing comparable to the ones I've had in KoreaTown in NYC. They have good soju. We got their yogourt soju, it saved this review from being a one star.

q29DsL5xmpdV42bJ6XLkBg.review_text: I planned my Bf's Bday here, since he's a hardcore Karaoke competitor. LOL. I reserved this place a couple weeks in advance, since I heard the rooms go out quick here. When the day finally came I had about 16-18 people. The room they gave totally didn't fit all of us and the room was soOo small, that my closet was bigger. But honestly it wasn't their fault that they gave us that room, because I only said that 13 people were going to come.
