(helpful hint: add a little moon walk to fade out the embarrassment)  OVERALL: Good place to go chill and hang out.  Drink to your heart's content.  Do get a peach or yogurt soju.  The K-rooms are all private, but if you want to pull off a Super Junior "Sorry Sorry" dance in public....do it Coyote Ugly Style! =P

QXiLo4tY-7H5z-hd7ADyvw.review_text: This place is definitely good for a big group party or a birthday. I had my birthday party here last year and it was off the hook. But you should reserve it in advance because it does get a little crowded on the weekends. The owner there is hella chill and he gives free food service once in a while.   They have the kareoke room upstairs too, which is nice. I used it before for a birthday and it can seat about 30 people. It's not bad, but it just gets too loud with a lot of people. The food and drinks are real good, but yogurt soju was kinda so-so.  Tofu kimchi and the jja jjang myun are one of my favorites. Probably will have my birthday party here again soon.

9jZAXnAaulEC40wtEZK6Fw.review_text: Anyone who knows me, I like to hog the microphone. It's always a challenge when I'm at home with my parents, they sing so well and me...well...at the time, I was pretty good. OK, I lied. My parents didn't think so, they stole my thunder.  Not this past weekend, I got to sing. I was amazing. People were telling me I should be on American Idol. Thank you adorable fans, I heart you.  -whoever thought of this after the Korea house is VERY COOL!

iLjMdZi0Tm7DQxX1C1_2dg.review_text: There's karaoke... then there's karaoke at Playground. When it comes to unleashing my inner rocker (or diva, depending on song selection), I'm more familiar with the 'white guy' version of butchering pop songs than I am the Asian version. What does that mean? Well, I typically find myself at bars, surrounded by drunk frat guys and sorority sisters who seemingly only know five different songs. -Love Shack -Friends In Low Places -I Will Survive -Bohemian Rhapsody -Baby Got Back But now that I've had a crack at grippin' the mic like our brothers and sisters to the east, I've got a newfound love of karaoke. Nothing beats having 15-20 rowdy friends packed like sardines in the same room, making collective choices on what to sing next. No more sitting through 50 year old Gloria Gaynor songs or listening to some ass wipe completely shit on the grave of John Lennon... it's all about gelling with your buds and singing in unison! Playground has a pretty swell setup in the upper karaoke area. Three rooms, all differing in size, and running at about $30/hour. Not a bad deal considering you get a private room JUST for you and your crew. They also have a pretty great selection to choose from. Though I still haven't found anyone with Ice Cube's "It Was A Good Day" on karaoke (automatic 5 stars for the first place I find rocking it), they had some pretty unusual offerings... like Lonely Island's "Jizz In My Pants." For the uneducated (all four of you), enjoy: youtube.com/watch?v=4pXf… The best part is that if you get a little parched from banging out soul jams, you can just pick up the phone from the room, and they'll deliver you icy cold brews in three shakes of a lamb's tail! Pretty cool, huh? You can also order grub, but I wasn't very hungry, so I can't comment on that end of the deal. Overall, a pretty unassuming, but really fun hang in the middle of Japantown. If you find yourself in the 'hood with a surly mob of wannabe vocalists, stop in for a few tunes. You'll dig it!

Hnu5s_myOZZIS2eny7liVA.review_text: Fun place for a birthday party. This was only my second private karaoke room experience. The first was Music Cafe in Oakland the week before. (yelp.com/biz/music-cafe-…) We arrived with a reservation for 10 and were helped promptly. Our server was attentive and checked in with us often throughout the night. We left the food ordering up to my friend's brother's girlfriend and everything I sampled was delicious. Our total was $50/person for three hours full of karaoke, drinks and food. (Not bad at all!) Oh, and we drank ALL the Anchor Steam available that night. We were in room #3 which is at the top of the stairs and has a bathroom nearby. Although the room seemed spacious compared to our limo, the talls in the group (me included) only fit in half the room (standing) due to the slanted ceiling. There was some fun lighting that we could switch on and off but our disco ball didn't work. The karaoke system was easy to figure out. All of our song books were sticky (eww). We couldn't find the great selection of songs that others have mentioned but maybe we missed something. (?) There were still lots of karaoke favorites and we sang as many as we were able. Random: One of my karaoke pet peeves is when there are elaborate videos behind the lyrics. They are so distracting to me. I prefer my karaoke lyrics straight up.

yW-GBoKnzyduaG86Y1NLzw.review_text: Not the best, but I think it depends on what you're going for.  As a drunken Karaoke where they allow and supply your with liquor, I'd give it a 4.  As a general Karaoke for people who don't speak Korean OR Japanese...a 3.  Obviously I fall into the latter.  The book was sticky, and I assume it's because the mic's aren't wireless, so you have to pull the chord with it...given that this usually means across the table, where the food and soju are and where the book is, it makes sense.  But, since I also don't know what was in said sticky stuff on the book, I opt to bring hand sanitizer. ALWAYS.  Soju itself was good. Had some of the yogurt which was pretty bomb.  The food was pretty good too. Decent for a karaoke place.   Music selection is good. It doesn't give you the BEST selection of songs, but when you start getting more wasted, even the oldest cheesiest songs are pretty awesome.  There's a $30 minimum per person. We had a large room, which was $30/hour, but we also ordered Soju (about $25 per carafe) and food.   Atmosphere was ok. Not the cleanest karaoke place, but not dirty either. For the room. The bathroom, I don't know if it was because it was late in the day or what, but it was GROSS. Like, seriously...ICK.   And only one unisex one. Not good.

EWKfNz1tp-P5QqvqyPYI3Q.review_text: Playground has an excellent atmosphere and yummy food and drinks!  I've been to Playground maybe three times, and I haven't once been disappointed with them.  The only downside is that it's usually very crowded.  My boyfriend and I shared the  (dak galbi) and it was more than enough for the two of us.  I also like their Playground  (jajangmyun) a lot.

A2mx9xsHoIDNnd81_lxiFA.review_text: I don't have references, because it was my first Korean food experience, but everything was yummy, and .... authentic. Authentic, because it is the only way to explain that we were the only 2 non-Asians at the restaurant. Cool!  Portions are big!

dds8kGUJG1juP-SDhfDm_g.review_text: my best friend took me here the other day to snap me out of my funk, and it worked.  we were double fisted with burnt corn tea and 40 ounce OB beers, while munching on cuttle fish, peanuts, banana chips, beef (i think) jerky and dried mango.  they play this weird korean variety show on all the flat screen panels surrounding the tables.  no one on the show could really sing or dance, so immediately i felt better about myself.  we were about to hit the mics for karaoke, but she was late for dinner.  it may be that we're both asian, but there is a certain comfort in drinking 40 ounce beers, eating fear-factor sundries and watching bad korean tv.

pBAnCaacZRtk1PWtjPANAA.review_text: Some groups communicate best through regular ole conversation. Others families may communicate best through food. Me, I prefer a microphone, about 10 shots of soju, and the company of about 20 of the coolest Yelpers in SF. No one snickered when I, again, royally screwed up "All Out of Love". (silent tear).  Playground is more of a Korean restaurant these days than a karaoke destination, but there are 3 rooms upstairs that can accommodate about 10-15 people per room. Now, there are about 20 negative things I could say about Playground, ie. It's expensive, the drinks are watered down, and it takes a Rhodes Scholar to run the remote control. However, these were minor distractions because the company was so freaking good. Yelpers, 5 stars. Playground, 3.

XzuGe_Q2b955aZQRHpSjRQ.review_text: Imagine if Pinkberry froyo was an undercover alcoholic; it would be Playground's signature "yogurt soju" cocktail.    It's delicious and it's dangerous.  The smoothness of the soju, yogurt, mixed with some soda tastes so good that the buzz creeps up on you after your 3rd, 4th, 5th glass.  The food was solid - had the kalbi, spicy pork, and Soon Tofu soup.  Tasty, but a bit on the pricey side.  It seems pretty busy, so I'd suggest reservations.  The nice part about eating in Japantown is the parking garage, which is right across the street from the place.  I was there with a party of about 15 - 20 people for a birthday, who were either downstairs eating or upstairs crooning away in the karoake room.  For $30/hour for a private room, it was cheap given the number of people we crammed inside.  The staff was super accommodating given the fact that we kept floating from the room to the bar to the main dining area.    After a fun night of karaoke, food, drinks, and laughs, I left with 3 thoughts:  1.  Outkast's "Hey-ya" repeats the words "Shake It" about 100 times.  Andre 3000 must have been under some serious drug influence to sing that song.  2.  Please do not sing "Last Christmas" at a birthday party.  It just dampers the mood.    3.  Why do Asian karaoke videos have the most random images that have nothing to do with the song?  (e.g. animals, fountains, streets, naked babies on the beach).  Fun times!

0gEDwhSUIWIBz23MbLYMig.review_text: I did have a 5 star time here last Friday with a gang of yelpers as we took over the upstairs area.  I'm not a big fan of private room karaoke though.  The big sloppy gangbang singing gives me a headache pretty fast.  It didn't help that I got ridiculously gassy after the bibimbap that I ordered and left my rolaids in the truck.  I'm also sure that the beer I had been drinking all day and the vodka sodas I was drinking at DYL before was a bad pre-game strategy.  For some people it's the only way to karaoke, for others not so much.  I really wanted to try the corn cheese thing but didn't.  The chicken that I had was good though.

XrycmeUFBq_r2vT4ggD6oQ.review_text: For karaoke, jja-jjang myun, and yogurt soju - highly recommended! The rooms are pretty clean and comfortable as far as karaoke rooms go, and the service was friendly and eager to help. Expect a completely asian crowd in the bar/restaurant area.  The selection of music was decent for American songs. The only downside was the order was only by song name and not by artist. And the best part of Playground is that you can order food and drink (+alcohol) from the room easily. It comes up without delay. $12 for a large bottle of yogurt soju is a good deal! Just be careful because it goes down easy but can slap you in the face in the AM.  Bottom line: with drinks, uninhibited singing, and a fun group of friends, you'll have a good time. Reserve ahead of time. They require a $10 per person minimum charge in addition to $30/hr for the room. Not bad, actually. Those prices are pretty competitive with any other karaoke place, and you can have food and alcohol in your room.

7ITjIwsDmTFNauTOHxVsHQ.review_text: I have been here a couple of times. Take out only. I always get the BiBim Nagmyoen which is good but I wish they did not put so mush salt in the food. After You finish eating it your just thirsty all day and I hate that. The Pot sticker that are steamed are good. the food is average I think if you want real Korean food you should go to To Hyang.

WqpJr92lWXRik_aEpfwCNQ.review_text: yeeaaah!  this is so great for when you are craving the k-town club feel. and have late night k-munchies!  next time i'm going for booking! (kidding, i dont think they have booking)

Rto4xWr5gXA2IbrfyAn-Xg.review_text: songs are ok. rooms are dingy.

hxrlveyL89yvIpwnm7MgPQ.review_text: great food, atmosphere, service.  LA ktown might have some places that edge out playground , but at least here you won't get stabbed or sucker punched while you're taking a leak by some hooligan wanabe banger who didn't like how you looked at his oversized white polo shirt.    best advice: don't sleep on this place.

ixo96VAqfMCSDJQ_qKnrcg.review_text: so after a long stressful week.. i decided i needed some drinks.. so my sister and i head here  we sit at the bar and order a yogurt soju.. three pitchers & 2 margaritas later.. you have two really drunk girls struggling to make their way out.. you seriously cant tell how much you're drinking.. it tastes soo good!  anyway.. moving onto the food. it's ok.. the fire chicken is really good and the cheese corn is different.. in a good way. most of the other things are unmemorable..  anddddd they cater to the younger crowd.. and have korean music playing in the background (which i love... since i am korean) and i love the decor.. especially at nighttime.. the ambiance sets the mood & makes you want to keep coming back..

Mu6wz7_d6OBgRqkl4_NaXw.review_text: I may have butchered the following songs while at Playground:  -Nasty (if you haven't heard the unintentionally amusing lyrics to this in awhile it's worth a revisit) -She's Like the Wind (I may have changed the words to "I feel her breasts in my face") -El Condor Pasa (duet - my husband is shy and wanted me to sing with him but he didn't know much beyond Simon & Garfunkel) -We Built this City (duet - we made up our own traffic report 2/3rds through the song) -Zombie (I love me some Zombie)  If only I'd had more time I would have laid waste to (I Just) Died in Your Arms by Cutting Crew.  I didn't eat any of the food here, but we did reserve a room here to celebrate my friend's recent birthday. Unfortunately, despite our reservation we stood around the packed waiting area of Playground for about 20 minutes. It seemed like more than that but maybe it was because of the constant crush of drunken bodies trying to get by us in the narrow waiting area. (Worse was the drunken idiot who seemed to purposefully splash his drink into the area and got my white coat wet.)   There was a sign on the wall saying that only something like 10 people were allowed upstairs at a time. (That seemed like a mistake since it was ridiculously low for three rooms.) Anyway, the weird part was that there was a steady stream of people going downstairs at all times, as though they were exiting some upstairs clown car.  Once we had our room we had a great time. My favorite random topless Tahitian man dancing video even made an appearance during one song.  The most memorable moment was probably when my friend got down to U Can't Touch This complete with Hammer dancing (sadly no Hammer pants).

3i9l561AmBnxmgVyChql0A.review_text: From the looks of other reviews, the only reason I would come back is to just do a regular sit down dinner and skip the karaoke. The appetizers we got were decent and I would like to try other things because I like Korean food.  For karaoke, I came with 3 other friends so we split the $30 between us 4 and of course our meals were separate. When we came in, we were literally the only ones there. With that, I expected service to sort of be on top of it because we were the only ones they needed to attend to. We got our food 30-45 min in so we were stuffing the food down our throats while putting in songs because we were running out of time in the room. A little stressful.  There is a phone in the room that you can use to call and order downstairs but I found it easier to walk downstairs instead of waiting for them to answer the phone. I went to ask how much time we could stay in the room because we got started a little late and the guy didn't even know what time we got there. That made me a little mad especially because we were the only ones there!   So the two stars come from good food, and in the end my 3 friends and I did have a fun for the most part. I'll look into having a sit down dinner if I ever come back.

2RosvaxvSKX0YY1VVmg-fg.review_text: Playground is whatever. Good place for pregaming and big groups. Food is just okay, not good, great or bad... its edible and thats about it. I come here to get tipsy/drunk before a night out.

IDfBkG5L5rbtFomDN--k3Q.review_text: I've always heard of this place because my sorority sister always go here for awesome korean cuisine, drinks, and karaoke.  Until recently, I finally tried out this restaurant myself and I absolutely LOVE IT. I love korean cuisine in general, but it's tough to find a good place like this one in San Francisco.  Me and my friends ordered the fried chicken and the server was super nice and gave us a honey mustard sauce to go with it which was even better than eating it plain. We also ordered soondubu here and it's quite good as well.  The service here is excellent and this place is pretty hip to me. I love all the korean music videos that are played on the flat screens. And if you're 21+, it's a good spot to have a drink or two.  After this visit, I am going to come back to Playground more often :] I want to try all of their dishes as well.

TIZQuJV8_8NUiiBI6YAMQw.review_text: Playground is definitely the result of an LA gangsta married to an SF girl - or at least, that's what it feels like. The LA style "boomin' Korean karaoke eurodance" is too much for my ears sometimes; the floor was slippery from dropped fish cakes (and it wasn't cleaned up).  I go to Playground for the Jajang myun (NB: regular jajang is called "Playground jajang" on the menu; the other more expensive jajang is just a refried pile of spicy crud).  Methinks this is why I don't live in LA - to have a little snippet of LA's KTown shoehorned into SF's Japantown seems kind of... odd.

4r-8Ty-TB-NOX5huxXY_hQ.review_text: finally a decent, modern korean-style bar in san francisco that is remotely reminiscent of many attractive drinking places in k-town of los angeles. i can actually take my so cal friends to this place without being embarrassed. why don't we have more places like this in nor cal? tasty anju (the best in sf) and friendly service. but they need more seating to accommodate larger crowd. karaoke rooms in upper deck are plus. last time i went, it was 30 bucks an hour for the room.

s1mD1PvJQrAYHfNG9UDYJw.review_text: My fave dish is the seafood onion pancake.  I won't even TRY to replicate it at home.  But be warned that your breath may smell like onion all night, in case you plan on going out later to pick up a lady friend or gentleman friend.  Find yourself a really strong mint.

ospduHDy9IPFYD1UBwaJIw.review_text: The numerous 4 and 5 stars just confirms again that the bar is low in the Bay Area for Korean restaurants (basically Korean food sucks here).  I understand that some of the reviews are more related to the karaoke, but 4 or 5 stars?  Have you ever been to karaoke in Seoul or Tokyo?  NYC or LA?  This rating is just about the food, so...  The jigaes (stews) are mediocre, the jja-jjang noodles (black bean sauce) were a weird smoky taste, the tofu kimchi (tofu with a fried kimchi and pork) was okay, the nakji bokum (fried squid in red bean paste and noodles) was weak, and the pajun (korean pancakes) was mediocre.  The kalbi (korean shortribs) was good, but how bad can you really make kalbi?  I'll stop here.  Playground is more for a place if you want to hangout with your friends and eat bar food.  Not a place to satisfy your palate for Korean food.

AFml12j0El_FUAo6qtkqFg.review_text: Came here for a quick stop for a few drinks before going to another bar. Tried the yogurt sake for the first time and it was delicious! The large size bottle is definitely enough for 4 people. The place gets busy so we only had standing room. Overall cool/hip vibe!

tvjL4BErlkBNsSyLjkEzFg.review_text: Let's face it - the Bay Area doesn't have a legit Koreatown.  So it's really important to find those places that make you happy and fill a sorely needed role in the late night culture scene.  I'd put Playground up there as one of the places I'll be hitting up on a regular basis.  When you want to relax with some friends and have a few beers while eating tasty Korean food, this is the place you want.  While there may not be the full BBQ setup with the fan and grill, that's not why you come to a place like this.  Seoul has thousands of places just like this, and LA has hundreds.  But for the Bay Area, there aren't many that hit the spot like this.  And for mixed crowds (that include non-Koreans), I should point out that everyone that worked there seemed to speak perfect English.  But if you want something, you need to just raise your hand and ask.  Most people get the wrong impression and think service is bad at places like this, but all you need to do is ask.  If it's late and I'm eating and drinking, I don't want some waiter coming by every 5 minutes asking if I need anything else - I'd rather be left alone with my cheese-corn (much better than you think) and dduk-bukki (rice cakes in spicy sauce).  Haven't tried the noraebang (karaoke rooms) upstairs (yet), but I'm sure there will come a time when I have no choice.  PROS: - Open late, full bar - Pretty extensive menu - Fried Chicken is pretty good - spicy, crunchy (like the Colonels USED to be) - Staff is friendly (although not all that attentive), and they speak native English  CONS: - Parking on the street is tough, but there's always the Japantown Parking Garage - Not the best Korean food you'll find (but that's not why you go here)

trsr1OL-Cn3ZYjTNYIxfKQ.review_text: Been here a few times in the past.  Food here is Korean, quantity over quality.  The waiters are Korean and they speak some Engrish.  I've had the soju, soju and soju here..  all good, ask for the soju.  Crowd is young and primarily.. Korean.  'Nuff said, you do the math!

xdavkX57NzkwLGqe_2fwsw.review_text: Playground is a good "fix".  You know, when you're craving some korean bar/karaoke food.  It's not the best, but certainly good enough.    Not recommended for folks unfamiliar with/unopen to a REAL Asian scene.  The service and environment is just... different.

ZmEVWKz1IHk-cCbPb27xlw.review_text: So we were all excited to go to this place after watching it on Check Please Bay Area...and we took the family there thinking it would be terrific food. We've had good Korean BBQ before, both at a restaurant and at friends houses, so for a place to be on a tv show, we thought "heck, it's gotta be good!" Warning: don't be fooled! Nothing about out meal was good. The short ribs were ok..but nothing great, we ordered the BBQ pork...fatty and not good...and the chicken which was super dry and in super small pieces. It honestly did not taste much like BBQ.  The service was terrible as well. Our waiter took our order, and never returned until he gave us the check...not even a refill on water! Oh and don't order hot tea...it tastes like dirt water, and is served in the same plastic cup they serve water in.  Also, make sure to pace out your sides as they don't refill them. So if you want Kimchi with your meal...only have a small piece at a time. I guess you could order more of it...but do that when you order or else you won't see your waiter again. Maybe this was just our experience, as everyone else had good things to say, but we went on a saturday around 5-6pm...I would expect a better experience then this!

awqtQmC1QoUxOdmdQoeirQ.review_text: I'm gonna say that although the food is consistently delicious, the prices are higher than your typical Korean bars - it's an actual restaurant instead of a dimly lit FREEZING bar that never seems to be built with a heater, so clearly there is some overhead that needs to be covered but $15 on average for a plate is definitely not typical.   Service is just ehh usually, but now they give you froyo at the end of your meal! It's a nice touch, and most likely I will be back soon.

LFha-r2VljAzN13YwySTXw.review_text: Came here after the NEW PEOPLE YEE on 9/2. All I remember is going upstairs, singing loudly while banging our tambourines, drinking, lots of mayhem, remarking how tiny but cute the bathroom was downstairs, and that I paid $5 for 2 bottles of SPARKLETTES water. Yah, the stuff you get a case for $3 from Smart and Final. Whatever!  I'll be back to try this place out sober. I don't have to be sober when I leave though. Mwahahaha.

nwhBcly3mJKHUPMrg0rttw.review_text: After Yoshi's we decided to walk around and end up in Japantown.  Of course I had a few drinks I remember Cobber talking about a bar named Playground.  It so happens we find it and I wish I just kept my mouth shut. Cuz the next thing we did was order SOJU. Blueberry soju as a matter of fact.  It is pretty sweet but not bad.  If you all know SOJU is not my friend just as much as Gin.  I can see this place to be a party place during the weekend but Monday's nights are pretty dead.  I might be back but we will see.

i7lEtGBHmUJNXt6pTtjxYg.review_text: Came here on a visit with the yay area folks.  This place isn't that big so I would suggest reservations. We ordered a bunch of stuff and it was all pretty good.  Not anything amazing but way better than similar places in San Diego.   The Ra-boki was really spicy here!  So be careful. Overall a fun place to drink with your friends.

JOtF5CrxlvHKpoKU4ByAbQ.review_text: I went here to meet friends who wanted food and drink and thought this would be an easy place for people to meet up at. We got there second so I wasn't able to direct my friends to another place before they ordered. Playground specializes in being a fun scene for groups of friends to hang out at with karaoke rooms and movies/music videos playing on the wall of the main dining room, so if you just want food and drink it's quite expensive for those purposes. Most basic dishes cost between 15 to 17 dollars, which is more expensive than the better late night korean places around the corner on Fillmore across Geary street.   When we wanted to order a large bottle of beer to share with our table the waiter suggested Hite, which turned out to be one of those almost tasteless korean beers whose large bottle is comparable to a Tide detergent bottle. At least the yogurt soju was decent.  The service is great, but given the prices for their mediocre food I'm going to make sure I only go here if my friends actually want to go to a karaoke place.

ARovTKw6IO9jfX9bw4OLXQ.review_text: Went here for a friends birthday gathering. It was a bit pricey but about the same as most karaoke places I've been to.  well it was kinda a small room for the group we were with but it was still big enough to suffice. the food was excellent but definitely pricey lol i think we spent more on the food and booze than anything. they had a variety of flavored soju so that was a big plus to me. their list of music to sing to was pretty large but i think the need to add more into other areas than just English and Korean. we had others that could of been singing in Japanese and Tagalog, so i think they could benefit by providing more updated songs in all languages. was a bit disappointed that they had nothing in Spanish....not that i know many songs but still need to represent lol.  it was a great place to gather with friends and sing with our tone deaf voices while drinking soju and enjoying random conversations and sing rediculous songs. It was a blast so i recommend this place if you're looking for some karaoke, though i suggest a large group since the price so you can all slit it and make it cheaper on yourselves lol.

ZuCP8O71LHKl6tlXkS7Ziw.review_text: I LOVE coming to playground.. for its food, drinks, and just overall just great times!  Every time I come to Playground it is guaranteed packed! Despite how busy it is, service is always great and our orders don't take a long time to come. Whenever we come here, it is a MUST that we get the Yogurt Soju and Seafood pancake. DELICIOUS! Last night we had a huge party and ordered a lot of other dishes and drinks. I love it when you order a lot of things at Korean places, they give you some free stuff (service) and it's always really good too. Last night we had fried calamari and potato cakes. yummm!  I like how aside from their full Korean menu and soju drinks, Playground also has a full bar.  Prices are really reasonable too. 3 shots of Henny Priv and vodka tonic was $32. The proprietor, Janet, is great and super nice! Thanks for trying to accommodate our large party and checking in on us even though you were totally swamped with everything else and hooking us up every time we go there!  I have never had a bad experience at Playground. Looking forward to the next time we come here again!

j8mIPH18DpTF-CdJFHV87A.review_text: 20598 starship          "we built this city" 20384 avril levigne  "sk8erboi" 7537   phil collins     "against all odds" 20133 guns n roses "paradise city" 20051 helloween     "eagle fly free" 7887   skid row         "18 and life" 20120 incubus         "wish you were here" 20121 blink 182       "all the small things" 20287 berlin             "take my breath away" 21164 weezer          "say it ain't so" 7403   extreme         "more than words"  and i guarantee you'll have a blast if you bring the right friends. but "lost in translation" ruined american karaoke lounges for us natives. we all now know how good it can be done, so dark, sweaty rooms with lights that flicker on and off  just don't cut it. this does, though, definitely beat out bow bow's karaoke experience..  a little heads up for other karaoke joints. if you're going to put bands like judas priest, helloween, and iron maiden on your song lists, please ensure you have "mother" from danzig on there as well as kenny loggins' "highway to the danger zone" and "she's lost that lovin' feeling" so i can fulfill my top gun fantasies. kthanxbai.

X2uF3C3YBD24xcgKA104Sw.review_text: I would say this is a 3.5 - but I don't believe in half stars. I've used other Karaoke rooms before and would say the following:   1) Although it's cool to have a restaurant/karaoke place, I don't like the fact you are enforced to buy food and drink. I mean, I would buy a drink anyway, why make it an issue and a $10 minimum  2) The $10 minimum doesn't really matter as the majority of the food is over $10 anyway. Neither me or my friend were particularly hungry, so we ordered a combo plate for just under 20 smackeroons. Pretty poor quality food and definitely not worth the price. Should have stuck to 3 or 4 drinks to go over the minimum.   3) 18% enforced gratuity. Really? For the enforced food and drink order? That's mean, people.   Overall, I love karaoke, so I had a great time, but it was expensive. I've seen multiple reviews saying the food is great, but that isn't the experience i had, so maybe it's worth trying something else next time but to be honest, I am not sure if I buy into the novelty of restaurant/karaoke - not when I am forced into both at the same time. It makes for a night more expensive than it really should be. The English song list is pretty small as well - maybe if they expand their selections I will be more tempted to go here over Do Re Mi.

KWTh82mmgzBNuOiXnJv3kw.review_text: Service here is terrible. We had a large group and we weren't given enough glasses for water. I had to get up to talk to a waiter everytime I wanted something (for water, for glasses for the water, to order food, for soju...excuse me is this self service? i wasn't aware..) . The music is too damn loud for anyone to hear you say something the first or second time.  Expect to be given a menu by a waiter, only to have it be taken away by the manager before you order, a manager who's  going to brush by you and act too busy and important to care if you're trying to bring to his attention that you haven't freaking ordered. Service get's a 0, because it didn't exist.  Their potstickers are like how non-asians make potstickers. They're fried on all sides, the skin is puffy and just not very palatable. A 2. Wouldn't order it again.   I also ordered number 35, which was some sort of fried chicken with spicy garlic sauce. which was delicious.skin was crispy, the meat was juicy, the sauce was yum.  Hearty portion. i give this a 4.   The heralded soju cocktails were pretty tasty and not as watered down as some reviews suggest, but they ARE pricy. I'd rather go for the much cheaper plain soju and get plastered sooner .

Qfv430Hd9fwdIGGf_mEaLA.review_text: I'm torn because I really do love this place but the quality is suffering and the staff need to know.   First what I do like about this place: 1) The food and atmosphere are top notch! 2) The service is good! Friendly staff! 3) Pricing is not the cheapest but the place is a bit higher quality than hole in the wall places like Do Re Mi (which I still love and visit regularly also).   This is a place to have a bday party.  They are flexible with pricing so if you don't exactly meet the food or drink limit they don't make it a big deal unless its way off. 4) The yogurt sojus. Keep them coming. 5) Tambourines. I love when karaoke places include stuff like that in the room. Adds a new dynamic (and if you don't like them you don't have to use it.)   The things that I did not enjoy as much: 1) Things have not been maintained well over the years.  I came in a 8-10 person room which is spacious but one of the microphones had duct tap at the bottom and cracked horribly anytime the mic was passed around or not handled carefully.  This is a high-quality karaoke establishment and a new microphone is $99, please throw this dying microphone away.  You are worsening the experience for good paying customers and they will think twice about coming back. 2) All the song books are reallllly thick because they have songs for about 4 different languages in them.  If I was running my own karaoke place (a dream of mine) I would go to Staples, buy some binders and split this in 4 books.  Think about how much more enjoyable this would be for the customer. 3) The American song selection is ok but not amazing.  I love when karaoke places have a list of songs in the back of all the new and latest songs. Makes things easy and fun. Again think about the customer. 4) We had 2 song binders and one of the girls in our group refused to use one of them because she said it "smelled like piss".  Being the person that is running the party, I just switched binders with the other side of the table.  Only halfway through the party while I was flipping pages did I find one of the pages soaked at the bottom (under the plastic sheet) which made the white page gray at the bottom. I smelled it and it really did spell like piss.    To conclude: Please properly maintain your song books, microphones, and other equipment, Playground.  This is not the cheapest karaoke place and we go here for the quality.  We depend on you and want to give you our money for a nice night out.  I will probably hit up The Playground again in a few months and will update this review if things improve.  In the meantime I'm going to scope out some new places.

SgiBkhXeqIKl1PlFpZOycQ.review_text: In celebration of my friend's second 29th birthday (she was in slight denial about the big 3-0).  It kind of reminded of me being in an 80s arcade?  Why?  There was a blue neon ambiance about the place with some louder music playing in the background.   The banchans were decent, but I wish that they would have given some refills on them through the course of the meal.   The portions of the food are rather large.  One of my friends commented that the fried chicken was "all you could get in a family meal at KFC" and a little bit more.  The fried chicken was super hot, and packed a little bit of heat in it.    The dolsot bibimbap was pretty good, nothing to write home about, but was decent.   Now, to the drinks ... good freaking Lord.  Since I had to drive back down to the south bay after karaoke (a review of Do Re Mi will be following shortly), I decided not to drink.   However, there were some people that did, and ordered a $12 "exotic drink".  The waitress brought them out, and they were small carafes of fruity soju-infused adult beverage.  They served them Korean style with small shot glasses that are never to remain empty ... and wow, it packed a punch.  I had a sip or two of one, and wow, it's a value for $12!    Overall, good experience.  The wait staff was fairly attentive and good time was had by all.

wr1Y8-yLVCoaDKR4ihiTGg.review_text: I'm biased because I always leave here buzzed, but if you want to eat Korean bar food, drink soju mixes, and do this with a group of friends, go to Playground.  The only downsides are too many dishes I want to eat and not enough room in my stomach.

mE-hdFF4RgCxspZU72GAsw.review_text: I finally moved away from the bulgogi classic and tried their homemade noodles with a beef and potato sauce. We also had the seafood omelette and the soon doobu (tofu soup.) Their banchan are not the greatest, but their kimchi warranted seconds. To top it off, we had a 1600cc jug of OB beer. This place is designed for friends to get together and drink, eat and sing. It is open later and is a spot you should visit when the festive mood calls.

B4GclFaVa270QoWbE2o5jA.review_text: I love describing this place to friends who have never heard of it. It's a Korean karaoke bar that offers a great selection of American music in the middle of Japantown and it also serves Korean food and drink. Put that into your cultural pipe and smoke it!   First came here with a group of co-workers, and you know how us accountants do - we like to get pretty tipsy. The soju was great of course - i recommend yogurt, lychee, and especially mango for those who like the sweeter stuff. Also try mixing the sojus together for new tastes as well! Also go for the chicken wings (dry).   It seems many people don't remember what they do here, which is great. :) I mean, how could you? You're singing, you're drinking, you don't really have that much food...  It gets pretty pricey here - a room is $30/hour, soju is $25/big carafe, plus food which is usually in the $teens. last time i came, we ended up paying $60 each for 5 people. Then again, we were there for 3 hours. V^.^V  Be careful when you come down those steps if you're drunk. They wind and will add to the drunken effect you are experiencing. b^.^

Pc9TIdnI_dgds-4xGyQwsg.review_text: When I was 7years old, I was giddy with excitement when my parents got a new car and proclaimed I was in charge of the radio on our first car ride. I switched over to radio disney, and began belting out the lyrics to my favorite nsync song. My mum commented to my daddy, I think the radio is broken. What is that awful sound? The radio wasn't broken. It was me :( Years after, I'm still horrible at singing. But after a few shots of yogurt soju, I'm singing along (softly, mind you, I still want to have some friends at the end of the night) at Playground, and having a grand time. Cheese corn, soju and a platter of scrumptious fried foods (media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bp…) makes for a delicious and festive evening. I suck at singing, and even I love this place :D

WOpdd2yNtkQgbpqNgFMzOQ.review_text: Good place for groups to sit down and chill. Don't have to worry about being too loud or staying too long. There's a nice variety of soju drinks, my favorite was the yogurt flavor. The food was pretty good. There were some cute girls too. Was going to give 4 stars but the round of soju on the house from the waitress bumps it up to 5. My kinda place!!

oGiqow-Dt9IMepgkswdM4A.review_text: Came here on friday after dinner and dessert. We wanted to cap our night with some drinks. We were greeted by the friendly staff and were seated right away. It's a pretty big place and it was packed.   I've come here plenty times before and the food here is pretty good. I;ve had the fried chicken, fried squid, the green onion pancake, potstickers, etc..and everything we order was delicious. Tho I had just come from dinner, so I wasn't hungry at all. We ordered yogurt soju ($13 for the small, $25 for the large). It hit the spot right away. So Yummy! It gets pretty noisy because everyone is having a good time, and they have korean music videos playing around the restaurant. There are karoke rooms upstairs that is rented out by the hour.   Overall, a great and fun place to come and enjoy some korean bar food and soju! Def. try the yogurt soju, its the best!

9Vmqj86WQ6WTU8SdSkfBCA.review_text: Really good jia jiang mian (Bean Paste Noodle).  The service was also quite good.  I like this place.  Plus the waitress chase after me to give me back my camera.  Classy place.

pdilmEaeXuntV4eTnc9KcQ.review_text: Went here with some Asian friends that always end up going to an Asian bar or restaurant at some point of the night and as the token white guy felt a little out of place, but not worried or anything.   Had the big carafe of the fruity soju and ended up feeling pretty darn good. Didn't karaoke or eat.

4aWNZNBGRetGOcdgwRq2Kw.review_text: Sometimes you just want to throw back a few in a gritty Korean bar, right? If that's what you're specifically looking for, Playground delivers JUST that!  Walking up to this joint was a little confusing. I wasn't sure if I was walking into a diner or a bar or a karaoke lounge or what. I was greeted by bouncer and then seated by a hostess. So I suppose it's a combo of both? The place looks like it's lit by bug zappers as everything was glowing neon blue. The screens were playing unfamiliar K-Pop. The bathrooms are hell-holes. And you had to yell to your friends who were sitting a foot away just to hear them over the drunken shouts of your neighboring patrons. That said, I had a grand ole' time!  It looked like there was a full bar area in the corner, but it seemed that most others sat at tables while sipping on soju and snacking on Korean tapas style plates. They auto-brought a couple common dishes, one including corn and melted cheese. Simple....but amahzing (bonus points for who can tell which Fall2011 show that's from). We also ordered spicy dumplings, which I hear were to die for (my delicate palate doesn't appreciate the fiery touch of that sort). But the main reason we were there were to sip on the various choices of Korean vodka. We got the Yogurt and Mango types. Yogurt: A+, Mango: B-. If you're a n00b to the soju-movement, be careful. It tastes like a common Caprisun, so you drink a million shots. Then it just HITS you like when your father catches you watching late night HBO (that really happened to me when I was 5).  The place isn't for the dainty or faint of heart. Be ready to deal with some ish, but you'll definitely have a good time if you're up for it.

xYd1WZlr4EIo_mlrSVedrg.review_text: I love this place. I recently moved to japan town a month ago and now frequent this playground weekly. The staff is wonderful, the music is tasteful, and the chicken wings are to die for. For the young professionals that are still kids at heart, make sure you work hard and play hard at the playground.

NLjRAhG_O9odE0qDD_FAYQ.review_text: Whenever I get a craving for crispy chicken wings and ramen all drenched in spicy sauces, Playground is the place that comes to mind. While the weekend crowd can be young, as in barely out of college kids, and the environment may resemble more of a lively soju bar with food being an afterthought, weeknights are typically quiet. Its a good place to have a very casual group dinner if budget is a concern, and you don't mind the K-pop videos playing in the background.  I like the food even if it's not the most authentic Korean fare. There are some unique dishes like The La Bokki, which is a stirfry consisting of ramen, rice cakes, and egg. A spicy chicken topped with cheese is surprisingly, a good combination. You'll also find things like the standard korean meat entrees, tofu stews, and noodles on the menu. For sipping, they have quite a few flavors of yogurt soju which I prefer over the clear, rubbing-alcohol variety. If you're like me, try the aloe or lychee flavors. Both are not overly sweet and very yummy. But don't forget, they are alcoholic beverages.

vASaF47nWvCHEEDA8nfCVw.review_text: Belting out tunes whilst intoxicated (and surrounded by companies who are equally so) followed by a parade of spicy snacks is my all-time favorite way of spending a Saturday night.    Playground offers all of the ingredients for my abovementioned perfect Saturday night.  It is a Korean karaoke perched right on top of the most famous Denny's in San Francisco (it's weird how everyone seems to know THIS particular Denny's outlet in Japantown), which means 3 things: 1) Encyclopedia-thick books full of Japanese, Korean and English songs (none of which are by the real artists); 2) Abundant supplies of soju (a.k.a my drink of choice whenever I feel like getting pleasantly smashed); 3) Menu full of spicy Korean food (I'd suggest spicy squid - hold the thin rice noodles, and fried chicken with spicy Korean sauce).    PLUS... they have tambourines.  Two hours and thirty songs later (including some of the songs we had to kill cos the singing was so poor... and singers intoxicated), with great sadness we made our way down to the register, surrendered our tambourines and squared up.

ti4lRf8rv9KICw6msOJT0w.review_text: i really liked this place, eat drink and eat more. they have 1.6L korean beer and good korean food.  i also saw a young girl with another girls head in her lap, and puke all over her lap.

otujf80voksbLsEVHL6P1Q.review_text: Came here on a Sunday late evening after arriving into town. Friends and I were staying in the area (Japantown) so we decided to check out Playground and grab a drink (albeit, knowingly it was a Sunday at around 11pm). We ordered a round of soju and chatted up with the bartender. He was nice and recommended some places for us to check out while we were in town.There are two floors to Playground -- first floor is the bar/lounge area and second floor is for noreabang. When I come back into town, will visit Playground again.

iFdGPWU6Qfb5php6JGfbwQ.review_text: I think this is the ONLY Korean drinking place in SF. I swear....everytime I head up to SF, I ALWAYS end up drinking here. I'm only giving it 4 stars because this place seems as if it's one of the few places that's a Korean drinking place in SF. The staff isn't very knowledgeable about the Korean food/menu.  I was born in the states, and I swear....I know more about Korean food versus the workers. =P

Bm0ASL6b3_fsiHYZ3jBW5Q.review_text: When I came home to SF one year, I found that my parents had turned into major Korean drama addicts. Although we were already big fans of Korean BBQ, it threw me off one day when my mom and dad were suddenly saying: "I want to try bibimbap!" And so we went to Playground, a place perhaps better known for its karaoke, and it was the start of a beautiful thing.  Is the food good? It's pretty good -- not amazing, but decent. The portions are large and it is a wee bit expensive. They have a pretty large offering.  Is the service good? They're polite, and more importantly, gave us free gyoza when it was a slow night which is an easy way to win me over.   But the main reason I go back here nearly every trip... is the yogurt soju! They give it to you in a milk bottle and believe me, it goes fast. The taste is very mild, so be careful since you can wind up drunk faster than you know it!

VqBv-QqMsLso9qf7i3_gUQ.review_text: food was alright. i think ull have more fun if u come w a group like other ppl are saying. i went there on wednesday night and wow it was crowded! oh and they dont  check ids so prolly a good place for a young crowd

lhrUV5lXGqA9QrnmV99IVg.review_text: Stuffed myself into a karaoke room here along with around thirty other people to celebrate a friend's birthday.  Did not get to taste the food, but I will comment on the venue itself.  As far karaoke venues go, this is one of my least favorites and I'll tell you why:  low ceilings, poor ventilation, and the most pitiful English song selection I've ever encountered (a playbook without "Love Is a Battlefield" is like refusing to help a lost little kid who wants to borrow your cell phone to call his parents).  It just ain't right.  In addition, my friend's girlfriend had to make a second reservation to secure a room on the designated date because for some reason (to which we are still in the dark about), they gave away the first one.  I'd rather spend my cash at Do Re Mi, thank you very much.

w1tI3Oh7GB-fUYzECYrnlQ.review_text: San Tung's chicken wangs will always have a special place in my belly, er, heart, but I've found a new Korean lover to satisfy my chicken wang craving: Playground.  I came here to celebrate my cousin's birthday and we did it up with yogurt soju, hite beer, and several entrees. The pricing of the entrees concerned me, but the banchan and size of the entrees made up for the price. We ordered:   -Haemul Pajeon: seafood pancake with green onions and assorted seafood -Yang Nyum Chicken: fried chicken seasoned in a special spicy house sauce - Kanpoong Chicken: deep fried chicken battered in a sweet and spicy garlic sauce -Bibim Mandoo: spicy dumplings filled with pork and vegetables and meat  The pancake was a tasty way to start of the meal: crispy, savory, and slightly salty from the dipping sauce.  Both kinds of fried chicken were battered and crispy, but covered in a slightly different sauce. Both sauces were literally, FINGER-LICKING-GOOD!  The dumplings were also tasty, but there was a slight disparity in stirfried veggies-to-dumplings ratio (ALOT of veggies were leftover).   Definitely a fun place to go if you're craving alcohol + chicken wings. Don't be scared by the prices! The chicken wings are worth it.   Note: We only came here for dinner, not karoake.  The dining room was really dim and had K-pop blasting on a floor-to-ceiling projection scene. A plus if you're into Korean girly boys and soap operas, like I am. A negative if you like adequate lighting and intelligible music.

WPBrjBbk76ZtZQ8QpG09cQ.review_text: Mmmmm nice Korea food  The price is a little high, which is expected given that this is a hip, cool, korean bar serving late night food in the center of Japan-town. WHaaaat? The TV near the ceiling is constantly playing provocative music videos of korean pop stars. How can I focus on my delicious food when there are all these distractions? Distractions I say!  The food was surprisingly good too. The budae jigae looked weird when it first came out, but after about 5 mins of boiling over a heated stove, it looked much more like what it was supposed to. Ohhhhh yaaaaaa. And the taste was really good too. There was so much food even 2 people couldn't finish it. Wooot  Most definitely would come back.

dR-nXFsZESpQMsieXvHcWw.review_text: Four stars for.... me being the young one, surrounded by my coworkers as they sang songs wayyy before my time, as they ordered rum and coke after vodka cran after alcoholic beverage after alcoholic beverage. I knew enough to chime in to a Journey song, and sing my heart out to Bohemian Rhapsody. After all I'm Filipino and we all have to hold the mic at least once if karaoke is happening, its in our blood.

GaA3ghh7xxsXCMK6v6bLfw.review_text: Really great food here. Surprisingly busy tonight... its a wed night! That must mean great food. Really good service and the soju is off the hook! Remember to order the pancake! My favorite!

zy2cNfG4lLE3SlY9p2OL-A.review_text: Playground is situated on the upper level of this corner building at Post and Buchanan at J-town.  As we ascended towards the stairs, I somehow remembered, this has always been that Asian hangout in the late-80s/early90s where one would spend a group date evening listening to jazz and sipping cocktails.  Fast forward 2007, the Playground has transformed into a restau-bar with a dining area at the main level while providing various Karaoke private rooms at the upper level.  My cousins and I joined the Karaoke loving Yelp community for an hour or so of serenading, enjoying a nice bottle of Cab, and  a few soju shots.  The Karaoke event  was a sweet proposition:  songs and drinks for charity.  The rooms were quite stuffy, a functional ventilation system would have been great.  The equipment's interface and instructions were all in Korean characters.  Technical equipments though, are intuitive for this geek, characters or not, I somehow knew what to press, and as we started the evening, the three of us immediately got our Roke system going.  The private room setup reminded me of the Karaoke places in Tokyo, although those in Tokyo are more hip, industrial and definitely high-budget looking.  It was interesting to note that they served potent and sumptuous looking food in each room.  Too bad, I was not in famine mode, otherwise, I would have indulged.  I enjoyed seeing Luis M, devouring the soup, and made a mental note:  to return and try the various soup dishes.  After one too many songs rendered, we opted to slip away, hail a cab, and checkout what was in store at Rassales.

r-zd9EGfO0aq_Fb_M_C5qA.review_text: Great place! Love the pork dumplings and the yogurt soju is yummy.

PtTZf3VF_JwSKf-rkhuvRA.review_text: It's like the Worldbeats of Oakland, relocated to SF (if you went to Cal, you know what I'm talking about). Extremely fun times - great atmosphere, very yummy food and cheap soju/ginormous OBs. For six people, the total bill was $83 and we all left very drunk/fatty mc fats.

4Ebs_E9ANhInJ9YzNXCZvA.review_text: See it's all relative...  For Bay Area SF, this place gets 5 Stars For California, K-town food in LA even kicks Korea's @$$, so 4 Stars For Planet Earth, K-town food in LA *mah-shee-suh* and Karaoke in Japan basically has unlimited selection on songs, so 3 Stars  But this place ROCKED regardless!!!  We went out for Jenny's basday and we had a group of 25 well kalbi, bulgogi, pu dae chigae, kimchee bokumbap fed, mango/yogurt/strawberry soju drunken rockstars.  No soft porn though :(  Off to Element Lounge!

VvPjJBX_bU3UK0-OltaAYQ.review_text: We booked a private room here for a belated birthday celebration and had a lot of fun. I'm no Korean food expert but I really enjoyed the food, as did my companions. The yogurt soju was tasty, but I have to say I'm not sure how much soju was in the batch we received - it was pretty mild in terms of alcohol content.   On the karaoke front, I found their song selection to be pretty decent - based on other reviews I thought it would be a lot worse! We also scored a tambourine midway through our reservation, and I have to say that really added to the experience.  Things preventing Playground from having a 5 star review:  - We arrived on time but had to wait 15 minutes for the previous party to exit our room. We were told we could have an extra 15 minutes in the room, ourselves, but they ended up kicking us out at the original time.   - When we made the reservation, we got one of the smaller rooms and were told we could fit 12 - 13 comfortably in that room. Um...this is a bit of a fabrication. We were crammed in there (thankfully we only had a group of 10). The booth only seats 8, and they had folding chairs for extra people, but those people have to either sit with their back to the karaoke screen or block the door (and therefore move every time the server needs to enter the room).   - The song books are a bit cumbersome since they are multilingual and poorly organized. Instead of being alphabetical by song, it would be better to have them alpha by artist (especially since a lot of the song titles are misspelled and therefore possibly in the wrong alpha order).  So, a few minor complaints - but overall a fun time. I love the private room experience and I have to say it's a relief not too put up with prima donna karaoke participants or snooty KJs!

-M4ZqHZDsA9vOt7UscVRpQ.review_text: I am wavering between three stars and four stars for this place.  I think had I written this from Playground during my bouts with soju, then it would have gotten 5 stars.  However, I have cleared the soju cloud, and I am going to give it 3 stars.  Let me start by saying I love karaoke.  I don't need to be drunk, I don't need any back up singers, I don't care that I can not carry a tune.  I love it.  I love when there's a stage, the whole thing.  I also love the private room type of karaoke.   I think the food was good and the drinks were a plenty, but something about this place didn't make me love it.  I mean, I liked it just fine, but love...well that's another thing all together.  I do love being able to pick all my own jams uninterrupted by others in the bar, but the night we went, the minimums seemed to change over the course of the evening, so that didn't sit well with me.  Neither did having a minimum.  I'd rather just pay the per hour cost and then food and drinks separate.  But again, i could have had a soju fog around me, so perhaps the rules were clearer.  I'd still give it another whirl though.

ytS-kLAuzU4lvTBtdRfxVw.review_text: This place is awesome! We went in a large group and had one of the private rooms. It was so much fun. The staff was great, we didn't know what food we should order and they were very helpful making suggestions and recommendations on what to order. All of the food we had was so good. We had some pancake thing, an garlic shrimp dish, black bean noodles, a pork dish with kimchi, and a beef dish. It was all very good. We also had three different types of soju the pineapple, peach and mango. So good! We had a lot of soju! Anyway it was a great time! Also if you park in the parking garage the parking is really cheap. Only 5 bucks that is great for the city. The one and only complaint that I have is that the room we were in was pretty warm, but that could have been due to the amount of soju that we drank  We will be planning another event to the playground again very soon.

J4ooUVziBRPo8UtlNUZr2w.review_text: More yogurt soju please! Don't forget the spicy fried chicken.   Wait cheezy corn pleeeeze!

qEvvMP71m96-0NXZ_weh1g.review_text: came here just for a random get together of some nice singage and drink age! my homeboy can sing really well! he was working that mic like a stripper to a pole... no homo... the drinks kept coming the food kept cooking and the fun lasted an eternity. their song selection was great and to be honest I'm going to have to do a review update on the food since frankly i was just too drunk to pay attention to the food. i was singing my heart out... not very well but i tried my best haha. its all fun tho! great food, great drinks, great music, awesome friends!

VNR0wxYQhFufnPbqbAjfcw.review_text: made a reservation here for my birthday party. small rooms but that makes it even more fun. we all piled in and excitedly poured through the play list and starting singing up a storm.  being as obnoxious as we wanted to.  there's a phone inside the room where you can call in your drink orders. price was decent - once it was all split, ended up being about $20/head.  3 hours of the best time I've had in awhile, aw yeah.

07A5NOoYvsC_o5kpWCCk1Q.review_text: playground gets 4 stars for surprising me.  the an-joo food was surprisingly really good.  we were a group of 4 and we ordered a bunch of items off the menu, family-style, with the standard bottles of soju and beers (didn't try the flavored ones but will have to at some point after reading all of these reviews!) and it took me back to the days of 'four a' and 'innercrew' in l.a.  (sorry if i butchered the names, it's been a while and my memory is sh*t.)  the karaoke rooms are what you could expect them to be so no complaints there.

heFOOAWUVa3IlYkAeyyV8w.review_text: Honestly...I've only been here two times. I found this place when I had a craving for soju and was driving around japantown with my friend at night. Decent priced flavored soju. That night all we got was soju, and really that was all we needed. The next time I went we got food and soju. I...really was too full for soju so sadly, didn't get to enjoy it as much. The food is decent for late night korean. Plus a lot of korean restaurants don't have flavored soju, and...I can't drink straight soju. So, if you want flavored soju and some decent korean food in a quiet dimly lit restaurant late at night, this is the place you want to go.

xQizfjez_WUmTeNQjVARww.review_text: Every time I go to Playground I leave stuffed, tipsy, and with a raspy voice.   Amazing food and service along with Adele on the karaoke playlist... it doesn't get much better than that! Go to playground, order the fried chicken (or anything on the menu, I've yet to have a bad dish), soju yogurt cocktail, and sing like you've just "set fire to the rain"!

y2Y-iGnRMk7zqJidVnC_Lw.review_text: Who would've thought cheese corn would be that good? If you like spicey food, there's plenty here. The wet fried shrimp is amazing (I might have that wrong, it's battered with this tangy sauce). Gimme some mo'!

pwjt8MTUdywtwNkDWRKWIA.review_text: this place is awesome!! Happy hour runs from 5pm-7pm. 50% off drinks and selected pupus/anju. -The happy hour food menu prices are quite reasonable, ranging from $4 to $10.

vUI0jXAxFDzoLX04jN9RPA.review_text: The first time I came to playground, we were not informed of the $20 minimum for each person. So, we had to drink up some soju like there was no tomorrow. However, I found that the yogurt soju was quite good!   10 hot friends and I came here a few days ago and so we had to order $200 worth of food. We ordered a mix of things including: lychee and yogurt soju, seafood soup, beef, friend chicken and shrimp in house sauce, bibimbap, korean noodles, and the fruit platter. ALL were delicious, a good amount, and very tasty. The soup was super spicy though, so go for that if you want to add to your kareoke experience with some sweat.   The kareoke was fun as well, but in this particular room, there wasn't a space in the front for a "stage." So, it was hard for the whole party to see the screen. They have some new songs, but hey, songs of the past are best to sing along to.   The service is amazing. The older woman was the nicest Japanese woman I've ever met. She did keep stroking my back....and patting me though...but it was out of love. It's okay, I love her too. I would definitely go back.

4A63IX7Vav1bOvaT4TMX-w.review_text: I'm from Koreatown, Los Angeles, where there is largest selection of delicious Korean foods outside of Korea itself. With that being said, I was taken to Playground for some good ol' Korean-style partying and drinking during one of my leisure trips to San Francisco. I must say, I was impressed. The atmosphere is lively and fun, and the food and drinks are authentic and tasty! Especially compared to other Korean restaurants and bars I'd gone to previously in San Francisco, Playground definitely stood out! As for the foods I tried, it was very typical Korean bar foods: ddukboggi, donkatsu, corn cheese, and spicy chicken, all of which were decently prepared and served.

FIlJ2W-dfrlfVQm4KZsiXA.review_text: I came here one night after clubbing for a late night meal.    We ordered so much food. I hardly remember what we had.  I remember the corn and cheese, who would have thought something so simple is so delicious.  I'm also a big fan of potstickers, and they made it right here.  Overall all the dishes we had were good.  I came here for karaoke before too and they have pretty good songs and the soju aren't bad either.  Although, I'm not a fan of flavored soju because it's a creeper and get you drunk before you even know it.

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: JUN IS THE MAN!  Last week, my friend decided to throw one of five of his birthday bashes on a Monday; yes, a Monday at Playground/Milo Lounge (next door). HAPPY 27th BARFDAY STEVE! Thanks for the Tuesday hangover! *evil eye*  While waiting for Milo to open we decided to grab some drinks at Playground. We ordered several Yogurt Soju and Chamisul Soju (green bottle). Soju is similar to vodka but a little bit sweeter.   The Yogurt Soju is my fav as it has a creamy consistency with a tangy sweet flavor. Be forewarned, soju is a C-R-E-E-P-E-R. You may not feel anything for a while, then the next minute. BAM, you're blasted!  While we were downing shots, we got hungry and Jun came to the rescue. He gave us complimentary corn cheese (like cream of corn topped with melted mozzarella cheese), fish cakes and kimchi which are all part of the complimentary banchans when you order dinner. After going into town like savages, he kindly gave us a platter of mozzarella sticks and fries on the house; super sweet of him.   After everyone was nicely buzzed we went to Milo next door, only to come back to Playground 15 minutes later. Yes, we were hungry drunks.   F O O D As a disclaimer, the food did taste better because half the table was drunk.   *BIBIM MANDOO: Spicy Dumplings Filled w/ Pork - 4 STARS Jun brought us a platter of the bibim mando, Korean fried potstickers tossed with a spicy cabbage slaw on the house! The mandoo's skin was perfectly crisp and the pork filling was savory and juicy. The slaw was crunchy and had a nice fiery kick.   *HAEMUL PAJEON: Seafood Pancake- 4.5 STARS One of the BEST pajeon's in SF. Unlike other restaurants, Playground's pajeon was perfectly crisp throughout and not soggy. The bits of squid was nice and tender and not chewy. The soy vinegar sauce gave it a zing.  *KYOCHON: Fried Chicken Wings - 4 STARS The fresh-out-of-the-fryer wings were fried to a golden brown. Super crunchy on the outside and succulently moist and juicy on the inside, I wanted the whole platter to myself.   *KIMCHI BOKKEUMBAP: Kimchi Fried Rice - 4 STARS The rice was infused with the kimchi juices imparting a tangy kick while still maintaining an al-dente texture. The over-easy egg with the runny egg yolk added a deliciously creamy decadence.  *JJOHL MYUN: Cold Spicy Noodles - 4 STARS The cold spicy noodles had a nice toothsome chew with a fresh crispness from the cucumbers.   *KALBI: Korean BBQ Short Ribs - 3.5 STARS I'm a kalbi whore and though the kalbi was thick and succulent, it was missing that quintessential grilled char marks to give it smokiness.    *BUDAE JJIGAE: Ramen Noodles in Spicy Broth w/ Sausage, Spam & Ham - 3 STARS Served tableside on burner, the budae jjigae is a Korean stew of ramen noodles with a hodge podge of  meats. Perfect for a cold winter night, as it's comforting, hot and spicy. It was however, my least favorite dish of the night though as the meats tasted very processed and artificial.   S E R V I C E JUN ROCKS! From the moment we walked in to when we left (and came back), Jun was there to tend to our every drunken need.  He was very friendly, attentive, and down-to-earth. One of my friends wanted another bowl of the complimentary Korean Egg Drop soup and instead of just bringing a bowl, he asked the chef to make us an entire pot of it...on the house again! Awesome.   A M B I A N C E / D E C O R Contemporary and dark with K-Pop music videos playing on the big screen. There are 3 private karaoke rooms upstairs ($~30/hr). They also serve food and alkie to you in the private rooms.   P A R K I N G Street parking. There's also a parking garage across the street which closes at 2:30 AM on weeknights and 3:00 AM on weekends.   It's not very often that I've received such awesome service from an Asian restaurant. Jun totally made our night. Though he's allergic to alkie, I made him promise to do a shot with us when we come back to Playground. Jun, we're holding you to this! :)   GOM BAE!

CZU1RZavKV2fHhTvRRWdew.review_text: Karaoke: 1 dirty music books 2 sticky floors in rooms 3 hella expensive!!  4 song selections outdated 5 videos are irrelevant to songs 6 closes early!  DON'T COME HERE FOR KARAOKE For the love of god please don't spend your money here. Instead, Fillmore Karaoke - we came here after our horrible Playground experience ....

7T5p5uv7vFlBk9sUpJBV9A.review_text: Horrible customer service! Spent over 300$ but at the end of the night Janet was RUDE.  I enjoyed the food although it was over-priced. The room was dirty and should be cleaned daily. The song selection was alright, I prefer the ones at Fillmore Karaoke.

A0DoQYVztRnqJBmUXMWq9w.review_text: This place had various Korean dishes and we ended up ordering more than our stomachs could handle but it was worth it. The kalbi was cooked and marinated well. The octopus bokkum was nice and spicy and we tried two different styles of soondea (bokkum and regular) as well as the chopjae. I have had better Korean food but the entertainment (k-pop videos) kept my attention.   I'm usually not impressed with restaurants that have TV blasting, but I could not stop watching these Korean music videos. I was mesmerized by this flamboyant gay boy group and I thought "wow Korea has come a long way." Living in Phoenix kind of shelters you from what's going on in Korea in regard to pop culture so it was "educational" for me to watch these videos.   We also ordered the 1.6 Liter OB that came in a plastic bottle and a large carafe of lychee soju. Boy was that soju sweet! Not my favorite but the trashy OB beer made the night. Overall, a great place to take a group of friends for dinner/entertainment.

GqzoKYXv6F1O85bhywyoSA.review_text: Corn and cheese! Corn and cheese!  *that was the highlight of my night* and of course the company that I was with. :)  I had a great time here after the YEE @ New People. I came here to meet up with some fellow yelpers and boy were the rooms packed like sardines upstairs in the karaoke section!  So I decided to hang out with couple of yelpers downstairs in the lounge area!  Our friend knew the people pretty well here so it was awesome!  Service was great and overly friendly! I love korean people!!   Located upstairs right across from the Japantown center! $30 karaoke rooms!  It tends to be a bit small for super large groups though!  Played the Titanic game and flick the bottle cap games several times!  Yogurt soju beats Pineapple soju + OB Beer.  Complimentary soju bottle on the house!   Supposedly we were getting too rowdy and noisy so a group of koreans next to us told us to TONE IT DOWN.. we were all like eh?!?!?! It is a korean lounge... we were so confused but alcohol didn't stop us!  Janet our waitress was awesome!! She even offered me a cup of froyo with cereal at the end of my visit to eat while i drive back home to san jose! It was so sweet of her! How could i deny some frozen yogurt?!?! It was a good balance of creamy and tarty.. perfect to wake me up from the buzz i was trying to get rid of!

nRHreRvxWdg_m99JVElu0g.review_text: This is one of my favorite Korean places to eat and I can't believe I haven't written a review for it yet!   My all time favorite is the black bean sauce noodles. This is something I always get when I come here. I like to go with friends because I hate mixing the black bean sauce noodles and serving it myself haha. Other dishes I like are the dumpling/rice cake soup, regular dumplings and even though it isn't a real dish, the corn and cheese plate. It's a bit pricey but I always leave happily satisfied so it's totally worth it. They're only open for dinner, so if you come here during the weeknights and early enough on Fridays, it's easy to get a table but otherwise expect a wait because it gets packed fast. Service is good, sometimes a bit slow, but the people who work there are always friendly. There's one girl that's always working when my friends and I come here and even though she doesn't know us by name she'll come up to us and make small talk before she takes our order. I'm just sad this place isn't open for lunch.

GyhAtgINQAiYSVqdWHeubQ.review_text: My husband and I finally had the chance to try this place after seeing it on "Check Please!"  At first glance of the menu, I thought it was rather pricey, but after seeing the size of their servings, I thought it was worth it.  Being a HUGE fan of anything with corn (LOL), they give you a side dish of creamed corn w/ cheese...and YES, you can ask for more!  Everything we ordered was delicious and we'll definitely be back.  We tried the yogurt soju and if I wasn't driving, I could have drank the whole thing!  Tasted like Yakult with liquor...yum!    To top it off, our server was awesome!  She was very attentive and informative.  She was so good, we left her a 20% tip.    A suggestion would be to park in the Japan Center parking structure and just cross the street.

TAzGPFt9x99JCYWtDmZDWg.review_text: Solid late night Korean food.  HIghly recommend the seafood pancake - huge chunks of real seafood and fried to perfection.

waf3LdNsDyr7qow-OCtAJQ.review_text: There are two things I always get when I come here: Yogurt soju and the fire chicken with cheese. Maybe delicious dukkbokki (forgive my terrible Korean spelling) if I feel really hungry. Followed up by a couple of bottles of soju.  Followed by about an hour of laughter outside the establishment sobering up before we all head back home. The food isn't super delicious hence the four stars, but it's still good! I have yet to have a bad experience at this place. Never tried the karaoke rooms yet though.   And be careful with the fire chicken. I spend most of my time there laughing at friends coughing trying to eat it... (but I don't think it's THAT spicy...)

TdPkpZf5puPvGcxdNxgd3w.review_text: My first time having dinner here.  I remember this place as a Karaoke bar, but now its sort of a restaurant.  The food is decent, but the atmosphere was disappointing.  If you plan on having dinner and talking to friends forget it, its more like yelling.  Plenty of decent food and a full bar.  Why I found it disappointing was, if i wanted to go clubbing I would goto a club.  I wouldn't want to eat there.  It was crowded, drunken people yelling, and loud music.  I found myself yelling across the table just to have a conversation.  I don't know if I would go here for dinner again, unless I wanted to have dinner in a Karaoke bar.....  Gave Playground a second chance and the food was just as great.  The service was wonderful and pleasant staff.  I guess the music was not as loud as long as u sit towards the front of the restaurant bar. Corn and cheese is great and its complimentary...

8Lc3-TTHjExd79GSQIHnAw.review_text: Good price They didn't have Touch My Body I left my briefcase there and it was still there the next day!

zORQY85qUfWiIEltLOxG1g.review_text: Girl meets boy.  Girl loves boy.  Girl leaves boy.  Girl goes out with friends to forget boy.  Girl drinks countless rounds of soju at Playground.  Tone-deaf girl embarrasses herself singing Melissa Manchester's, "Don't Cry Out Loud" like a goat.  Girl almost stumbles down the stairs as she leaves the 2nd floor karaoke room on her way out of Playground.  Boy breaks her fall and saves her.  Girl might like boy?  She thought to herself the next day after spending the most of the night talking to him even though she doesn't really recall most of the conversation.  Girl meets boy in person again, this time sober.  Girl thinks, "really?"  -True Story-  Love this place.  Fun for large groups.  Been her for countless birthdays and a bachelorette party and this place has never been a disappointment.  Playground is a perfect place to start the night for dinner/pre-game before heading out to the lounges or clubs.  Just prepare to cab it to your next destination.  Good food, drinks, and service.    Also, the karaoke playlist is always up to date with new songs.  No bueno if you are friends with me because you'll be stuck listening to my pathetic attempt to sing.  I sound like a Chihuahua attempting to bark with a giant dog cone around my neck.

feZlrKUy6bB2k5Lzw8J6XQ.review_text: It's like very other Korean place.  I think I would come here again for mostly the soju. Their flavored soju (whether it be mango or yogurt) is delicious.

j-ewLhg_NgDDTC0DcN6TSA.review_text: yummy in my tummy. after my first time there, i was hooked. great food with huge portions to share, soju and other types of alchy, karaoke, and of course that cheese corn thing they give to customers for free :) haven't tried everything there, but so far so good. faves are the fried chicken and fried potstickers with spicy sauce. other good things... owners are very welcoming and sweet, and the restaurant is open late. you can seriously sit there for hours talking/drinking/eating with your friends and they never stare at you funny and wish you'd just go away :P love this place

SI0B9MRW_x3O9ua-L3gvPA.review_text: this review is for the flavored soju only.  tried mango, kiwi, peach, pineapple and strawberry. toyose and the spot definitley do it better. theres something artificial and different about the flavors. when you get the soju, its so bright and tastes so fake. at toyose/the spot the flavors taste natural. like real fruit juice was used but they just added soju to it. but at the playground i didn't like their flavored soju what so ever. i wouldnt mind coming back to try the food, but i am unlikely to get the flavored soju again.

xoNpQ_DnzNuTbkFPPO0Lgw.review_text: Located upstairs across from the Japantown center, it's bigger than it looks from the outside. It's dark and has music videos playing on the tvs and also projected on the back wall. I came here for a friend's birthday because she wanted Korean food & soju.   Note: Dishes are HUGE! Each can feed about 3-4 girls who doesn't eat that much (which our group was mostly consisted of).  We ordered Haemul Pajeon: seafood pancake w/onions Kanpoong Chicken: deep fried chicken battered in a sweet & spicy garlic sauce Cheese corn Kimchi Bokkum Bap: kimchi fried rice w/beef & veggies & fried egg on top La Bokki: soft rice cakes w/ramen noodles & fish cakes in a spicy chili sauce Yogurt Soju Lychee Soju Strawberry Soju  The food was good, but none wowed me that I would have to go back. Soju was on the stronger side so not as fruity as I would like.   Service was good for how busy the place was.  We didn't end up karaoking since there's a minimum of 2 hrs for karaoke for $40/hr and still a $40 min food purchase even tho we ordered a whole bunch of food already. Plus everyone was exhausted. Maybe next time.

CXoCh1bwbIKGYbY6xdP9Dw.review_text: The food is average here. I use to get the chicken wings because they tastes really good with the spicy sauce, but recently the wings got worst. Filled with fat and small pieces. The only cocktail soju i like from this place is the yogurt. The wait here on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday can be up to a hour or so, which i find is not really worth it. They play k-pop music and also have a large projector showing the videos on the wall.

q16FcvZyP5SURJEX8iGcTg.review_text: Review is for the Karaoke rooms upstairs:  one page of Chinese songs (being in SF)?! Seriously?!?!? (fine, the place is korean, i get it) lack of english songs.... common... 90% korean songs. the song binder is sticky..  on the bright side, the place is generally clean and doesn't smell like smoke.    If I had to pitch in for the tab, I would've given this place 2 stars.  would I come back for karaoke? probably not.

L47yNpuJtzKqkmMVHCZ8dQ.review_text: There's always a lot of people when I go here. Probably because it's always a friday or saturday night. Anyway, my friends and I come here for soju and to have a great time. Their food is pretty good, but i always go for the small sides. The creamed corn with cheese is sooo yummy to pick on. haha!
