The karaoke rooms are upstairs, but I bet you can do a lot more than karaoke in them if you know what I'm saying.  All in all, not entirely my cup of tea, but just fine for a birthday karaoke party for 40 of your most embarassing friends. It's a good thing I'm not a regular here or they'd probably recognize me next time I came. And they'd give me that "your-friends-stole-our-tambourines-and-fake-­plants" look. Then they'd ask me how my friends who left sobbing are doing. And then they'd ask if I cared to pay the rest of the Yoju bill we walked out on after our last visit. What a nightmare that would be!  But seriously, Four Stars for gracious service and that delicious Yoju. In fact, we're going to add a splash of Manischewitz, rename it YoJew, and serve it as our signature cocktail (in a martini glass, natch) when somebody finally breaks down and marries me :)

887-WxTKfe6Tcj3o4nNcfQ.review_text: I came here last weekend to celebrate a friend's birthday and thought Playground was a great place to enjoy a Friday night with a group of friends.    Located smack in the middle of Japantown, this Korean karaoke/bar/restaurant totally reminded me of Asia...it's dark, got kitschy decor (including randomly strung Christmas-style lights), flavored soju and of course, karaoke.  The bottom floor is a restaurant/bar where the management tries to cram as many people as they can to serve food.  I'm sure it's a fire hazard but who cares?!  You're going to have fun regardless!  There were +20 people total, and I sat at a table with 9 of us and we ordered:  -Various flavored soju: $13 for a small carafe, $25 for large.  Yum!  They might be girly flavored but it will creep up on you if you drink enough! -Bulgogi: can't go wrong with this dish. -Dolsot bibimbap: hot stone pot rice, again, hard to mess up anything with crispy rice. -Japchae: Sweet potato flour cellophane noodles, stir fried with various veggies.  Plenty to share.  Very tasty. -Kalbi: beef short ribs. -La bokki: (ra bokki) this was supposed to be ramen noodles mixed with duk bokki (thick rice cakes) in a savory red sauce.  This was my fave, I *love* the chewiness of rice cakes and the sauce that it was cooked with was so good that I would spoon it onto some rice and eat it that way too (carb overload much?).  Only complaint was that there was no ramen noodles!    Everything came with your typical ban chan like kimchi, bean sprouts, etc.  With all that, plus 2 bowls of rice and 2-3 carafes of soju, our bill came out to be a little less than $20 per person, tip included.  The hostess was really friendly and so were the servers, albeit extremely busy.  There were at least 2 other people celebrating birthdays that night too, so the whole atmosphere was really festive with lots of singing and chugging.  Afterwards, we made our way upstairs to the karaoke room.  I don't know how we packed that many people into what felt like a 6x6 room, but it happened.  The charge was something like $20 minimum per person, so I'm sure they made a killing off us; nevertheless it was fun.  Bottom line: go with a bunch of friends, grab a bite and drink downstairs then karaoke the night away.  Just be sure to make reservations first!

V-MvohG15HHEJAvljBqc7A.review_text: So Ju? Corn and cheese? Ahh...YEZZIR

GHuFAuSur--ISyEog2xcDQ.review_text: I can't say that the food itself is beyond marvelous.  Your usual bar foods...  Cheese Corn always looks so wrong. Gooey cheese and canned corn but it really IS tasty and a fun little appetizer.  SoonDae tastes the same everywhere you go...after all...it IS the lining of a YOU KNOW filled with noodles and chewy goodness. This doesn't sound so pleasant...but Koreans love the stuff!  HaeMool JunGohl...now that's more like it! This is what you order when you're eating with 2+ people. A big tin basin filled with spicy broth, shrimp, crab, udon noodles, squid. Yay for sharing!

JcpDK-JobtPjcJdIFaJ0Hg.review_text: I have a love/hate relationship with Playground.  Minus 1 star for the customer service.  I feel like a 3 year old at a real playground having a good time until I'm scolded by a mean adult.  The food is good and it's fun to hang out with your friends playing drinking games and munching on korean food.  You get korean side dishes, such as kimchi, pickled onions, and corn with cheese.  Oh-my-god.  Who would've known corn out of a can topped with melted cheese could be so good?!  We ordered fried chicken wings, bulgogi, bibimbap, and korean fried rice-all which tasted yummy.  Food can be pricey depending on what  you're ordering, but who cares.  The real reason you're here is to drink!  We were having a good time eating until we wanted to order some drinks.  Friend: Can we order a large shochu? Waiter: What flavor? F: *confused* umm.. the large one W: quickly walks away and gives us a menu F: questioning if there are flavors of shochu and finds out the waiter thought we wanted a flavor of SOJU. W:  it's called _____.  Keep that in mind for next time! and walks off.  WTF.  Well guess what waiter, we've already forgotten what that shochu is called. But thanks for the heads up.

GzJ5pB8Io_6OEZTSmzgI6w.review_text: this is what usually happens when i go out with my friend susan: i want a beer or something... she wants some sort of girly alcoholic beverage.  i can never figure out if she just wants to try everything or wants to get me drunk, but i end up either sharing yogurt soju or polishing off a cocktail.    so last night once the yogurt soju was done, she decided it was strawberry soju time...  if i wanted to take shots of cough syrup i would've gone to walgreens.  BLECH BLECH! team player beware.  no need to take strawberry soju for "the team".  and don't try to "be a man" and down the thing... there's nothing manly about flavored soju.  playground's redeeming grace is that they're open fairly late and their other food is tolerable.

UYZaM86Jfj9Zdmnad_aJ8A.review_text: I went here a couple of days ago with with my friends to celebrate a birthday. We reserved a private room and sang our fricken lungs out. I have to say nothing like asian snacks, alcohol, and a karaoke machine to get your friends to belt out a bunch of tunes that normally you wouldn't be caught dead listening to in the privacy of your own car! It was a blast!   Well, don't just read this review...experience it! Go and grab some friends, reserve a room, drink alot of alcohol, and sing till your voice sounds like a raspy old woman or man. :-)

3ZrjvKpBvez2uHzvDNxa_g.review_text: I wake up early after nights of drinking.  So it's 9:30am, I've been at the office for an hour and up since two hours before that, my throat is killing me, the room is spinning ever-so-slightly and every time i shift my body i have to concentrate on settling my nauseous stomach.  But goddamn I had a hell of a time at Playground last night.

F7vgCzNV-cSGvTn4szQDuQ.review_text: day 6  so i went with yelpers to this place. they said the korean food in la is better. might be but i think the food here is about as good as any drinking karaoke spot in la. service was good. but probably cuz the yelpers may have some clout there. i met the k fury of sf and unfortunately i only have clout in la in my apartment. he wins!   its upstairs, the inside is dark and bright. the girls are mildly unattractive but may have great personalities. the karaoke room had a freakin buzzing coming from the speakers.  but i loved this place cuz it gives people a place to go to get drunk and sing and im all pro for drunk and sing and take ghey pics!

qiPRHMHwIhEdjgZVkvfnUw.review_text: This was the closest 'Korean' bar I could find in SF. They serve the traditional items of seafood pancake, cha jia mien, ramen with rice cake and fish cakes, and dumplings. The also serve my favorite pan chan: corn with cheese!!! Yummmm  I guess the reason why I like this place so much is because it's a great late night hang out spot with karaoke, good soju, and a great selection of alcohol. There's k-pop blasting in the background so this is as close to a k-club in SF as it gets!

7ZrRa59L7za38g0lCQ3_MA.review_text: Great place great food nice ambiance and clean decor.  Food was pretty good too. The budae jjigae or army soup  was nice spicy and full of meat! Tong dak was good but not as good as the old Koko house tong dak and yes people you know that is so true! Other than that service is good and I would definitely come back!

bdZLmvZg7ibzD0YbLfru6A.review_text: Right after dinner, we came here to grab a snack at a table and critique the latest and greatest K-pop music videos on the screen.  We grabbed a couple bottles of shochu (my favorite was the mango),  though they did seem watered down compared to other Korean bars that I've been to in the area.  We had a couple of plates of the sliced pork dish and french fries.  I also like the blood sausage with vermicelli noodles, especially with the pepper.  Service wasn't too bad, they were pretty quick to answer any and all questions.    Pretty decent place for drunk food and for pretty much having a good time and yelling at how weird/cool the latest GG/2NE1/other K-pop groups are, for sure.

POuV49clGW0V3Xe0TpO3MQ.review_text: I went here for a birthday party recently and had a blast. We rented a private room for a couple hours and sang our hearts out.  The only thing that was annoying about it was that they have the songs in English sorted by song title, not artist.  Overall a good spot, but be prepared to drop some money.

aW7Oi0wd1o7Pol6P0-fQBg.review_text: The restaurant is located on the second floor, so you need to go up the stairs from the street level to get to the door. There are windows that overlook the Japantown plaza. The dining area is relaxed and fun. The karaoke rooms are on the third floor, separate from the dining area and bar.  The food is excellent. The kalbi (short ribs) and sundubu (tofu stew) are both outstanding--really tasty--and go well together as a good meal for two people. The yangnyeom chicken has a nice sweet flavor.   Be prepared for poorer treatment if you're not Korean. When my party entered, we were being seated at a window table when a staff member appeared and whispered to the staff member seating us, at which point we were told the table was "too wet" and we were moved to a table by the kitchen, and the party of Koreans behind us in line were immediately seated at the nicer window table.

igTfZCuAFk8Wjkrf6kqiWg.review_text: Damn those scary stairs going to Playground.  All I am saying is, if you plan to leave there drunk, put on some comfortable shoes.  But that's probably just due to my complete inability to walk in heels.    But damn!  That Yogurt Soju sneaks up on you!  It is so easy to drink down, you think you're good all night, until those wood stairs forsake you as you leave.  It's crazy delicious.  I am totally going to get me some Yakult next time I drink. (It's also good for your digestive system!)  Warning:  Don't try to to make yogurt Soju from some Yoplait mess.  LOL.  Believe me.  A friend of mine tried with horrible consequences.  That corn cheese stuff is disgusting AND delicious at the same time.  You should try it!  As for service, it's decent.  It might take awhile for them to notice that you need some service, but they spot you, they are pretty nice and get the stuff to you as soon as they can.  The crowd was also pretty chill.  Make a friend in the long bathroom line! :D

Vf3DJncooLUHWYele0Cxrw.review_text: Sing your ass off.  Pick up the hotline phone.  Order food.  Sing more. Done.

XZAxvvHFOxDVVvtsjHK1BA.review_text: this place is definetely not like any other korean restaurant ive been too...it is always very loud in here and there are a bunch of tvs with korean singers singing and dancing all time.   if you come here on a weekend it is usally really packed but on weekdays they are pretty good..the wait on weekends is definetely worth it! i love their crispy beef, seafood pancake, and omelette friend rice! and who can resist the delicious cheese corn that you get as a side dish! their yogurt soju is always made perfectly where you can easily drink 3-4 large bottles each time without even know...this is definetely one of my favorite places to chill and eat some delicious korean food :)

hFCUoOVs1rA4FX9Vps9fsg.review_text: This is where i want to spend most of my nights. Eating korean food late at night and drinking soju in 12 different flavors. Come here on a Friday night and eat spicy La Bokki and fried chicken with friends. It's salty, comforting, and delicious. Plus loud kpop music videos plays on the wall. It's bustling but everyone here maintains surprisingly nice and attentive. The whole place encourages you to end the night in drunken karaoke. Remember, soju sneaks up on you.

DAf3UOAONCpgETWlNTERKg.review_text: EDIT: This is more like 4.5 stars, but should really get bumped up to that 5th because of the great friendly service we had! Even after we paid the bill :) -------------------------- Playground was the venue for the first unofficial Norebang Night, in which this restaurant/bar/private-room-karaoke joint morphed into Club Steph. I do have to declare that it was a SUCCESS!  Not only because of the fabulous Yelpers who came out to eat, drink, and sing...but because Playground was so kind and accomodating to our rambunctuous group!  The owner Lisa and her niece Janet were wonderful! It also helps when your right-hand-man is Korean and related to the owners :) So the deets of the night and some helpful bits:  Dinner for 20?  Delicious and out in a flash. Highlights: the Korean Fried Chicken whose skin is a little bit more battered than other Korean joints, the Sun Dae Bokkum (blood sausage), that soup w/ the sausage/luncheon meat/veggies/ramen, this tofu w/ pork belly. Sorry I cannot be more useful than this. Let's just say that they do a decent job w/ food.   Drinks - yogurt soju? Check. Fruit flavors like strawberry and kiwi? Check. The usual Koeran beers like Hite and OB? Check. Bottle service? Check.   Karaoke! Upstairs there are 3 rooms of varying sizes (think S, M, & L) to accomodate their "capacity" of 37. Please note to you norebang-newbies. This is definitely Korean style karaoke because:  1) The remote controllers are all in Korean. You will have to use your ingenuity to figure them out.  2) The system and the song books are the kind where they get a new batch of songs periodically and just include new inserts. This means that navigating the book is a little tricky. *Tip* In the book, there's a large English section, but there are also English songs at the end of each section of new Korean songs. 3) The roofs of the rooms are kind of slanted; maybe they figured Asian people are short anyway. I guess they never met Ed.  But dude, there were plenty of karaoke standards and favorites: Bon Jovi, Journey, Madonna, disco, Britney, Xtina, Mariah, CELINE!!!, and surpisingly plenty of 90s rock.  And if there is one single reason for you to go to Playground for your karaoke needs, it is this:  In my research, this is the ONLY private room karaoke joint in the city that has a bar. At $30/hour, this is a pretty good deal...and if you want to plan your own little party, just call them up and they are more than willing to work something out. Playground is definitely a great place to rock the mic and PLAY!!!

rLNhOBzyuSbWTq2iuJ3mBw.review_text: We came here on a Tuesday evening after having ramen. Since my friend can't really handle alcohol so we just ordered a bottle of fruit-flavored soju, a diet cook, and a seafood pancake.  Like most Korean places, it came with a generous section of kimchi and various appetizer, which were really tasty. I was particularly fond of the corn and cheese they provided for us; it was really yummy!  It's a bar, nonetheless, and I have to rate their drinks right? The favored soju, honestly, tastes like some medicine for kids. I've had much better tasting ones elsewhere so I won't recommend their favored soju cocktails.  It was a Tuesday evening that we visited so the place wasn't crowded. But they had the music on so loud that me and my friend had such a hard time hearing each other. I suppose that's something they should consider improving?

bXE5T1RRLFJgVFRczfV-Kg.review_text: I wanted to have some Korean food while i was in SF so he yelped this place.  The food was awesome, though a bit pricey.  I loved the cheesy corn in addition to all the typical side dishes.  The soju cocktail selection was also really tasty, the favorite being the yogurt soju.    The wait staff was very nice and was quick with the service.  It was a really trendy hot spot as it started to get really busy around 8.  Around 9, I could hear their karaoke rooms blasting upstairs.  Definitely a great place to chill with your friends.. probably not the best place for kids since there was a number of very drunk people making fools of themselves around our table.    Besides the place being a bit pricey, the manager/owner was kind of pushy as she was pretty much urging us out while we were still trying to enjoy our soju.  It was a little awkward for her to just hand us the check when we were clearly not done yet..  I also thought the bathrooms were pretty small and claustrophobic, but it wasn't horrible enough for me to abstain from coming back to  the Playground for some great food and soju.

oYrD51tsMhVHtqCOOJo6og.review_text: I was in a private karaoke booth in here a week ago for my sister's friend's birthday, and I loved every minute of it. We all got drunk on the tasty yogurt soju (tasted like dessert, and we took turns doing refill patrol) and the karaoke selections included entire English, Japanese and Korean sections. Unfortunately the remote control was in Korean so our drunk asses had to figure that out very carefully and despite the instructions posted on the wall, we couldn't figure out how to change the pitch and stuff. But otherwise it was super fun, the booth was temperature-adjustable (and had DISCO LIGHTS), and the servers were great (we had a photo op with a particularly cute dude :). If I'm feeling up for super Asian-style karaoke I'm deffo coming back here!

41HLwXnR0Lm3NUp01cIOQg.review_text: Playground is a fun Korean drinking establishment. It is not a bar nor a pub. It is a drinking place with lots of tables and some private karaoke rooms. People gather here to hang out, drink their flavored yogurt soju while playing various drinking games. The main room usually have a pretty rowdy and happy crowd.   Clientele is prominently Korean as you would have guessed. That means lot of cute and well dressed Asian girls and guys.   The food here was surprisingly good. (And no, I wasn't completely drunk. Was I?) The seafood pancake was so very crispy. They have cheese corn, spicy rice cakes and many other cooked dishes that are perfect pairing for alcohol.   The karaoke room equipment is really primitive. It was fun nonetheless.

UzG5IHFUu6H1UyCRbqHHZw.review_text: pffflt, pffflt go the sticky song menu pages.   trrrrk, trrrrk go my shoes against our private karaoke room floor. how often do they mop and wipe down these rooms?  i usually don't karaoke, only b/c i've been taking singing seriously for a while now, but, i CAN appreciate the fun in having a few drinks and belting out 'all my life' by k-ci and jojo w/a few cool people in an intimate setting.  (thanks to jason c, debbie l, diction, and carol for being those cool people!)  their collection of songs seemed to lack a little bit, and a good portion of their songs catered to korean patrons.  ...their mics could be a little bit better too.   there was a slight mix-up in the bill at the end of the evening.  our room was confused w/another and was subsequently charged for three hours as opposed to the one hour that we were actually there for.  the mistake was corrected quickly, and we managed to sneak in an extra half hour of singing.  : )  the flavored soju was delicious, and i wasn't expecting to get a buzz off of it, but i was pleasantly surprised as i walked home, humming a lil george michael to japantown's sleepy streets.

QKbq76KuUHLRZjWXDtbwWQ.review_text: I don't feel quite right giving Playground a 4....  I came here the other night for my birthday - got the biggest room, which is for 20 people.  A few minutes before arriving there, my friend who had already arrived called to tell me they didn't have my reservation which I had given a week and a half earlier, WITH my credit card information.  I spoke to the girl at the front and she moved a smaller party into a smaller room to make room for us.  Later they realized they misread the schedule.  That was strike 1.  The other thing was the room size.  The room for 20 is really more like a tight fit for about 15.  The 16 of us squeezed in like sardines...  The room was also incredibly stuffy and hot.  Enough bad, here's the good.  The food is good, the Soju is GREAT (just go for the $18 bottle!) and the song selection actually isn't that bad.  I read from others that it is lacking, but it worked for us and we ended up having a great time.  The room was $30 an hour, and the rule is if you stay for over 2 hours, then it is a $20 minimum per person.  It actually isn't bad at all cash wise.  Also, the staff was extremely kind and quick.  Janet was very very helpful once they realized the mix up.  All in all we had a great time, and I would go back, but knowing now a few more things about it, definitely don't invite over 15 people and don't wear anything warm.

sYtO-WgBz9oShCaezw2UwQ.review_text: Actually came to Japantown hoping to eat at YakiniQ, but the wait was soooo long so we decided to look around for something else. We say playground and decided to go look in.   The environment is really cool for dinner in San Francisco-- music videos projected on the wall and a kind of "club"-y feel to it.  We started off with the lychee soju, which was great, but not as strong as we were expecting.  We ordered the fried potstickers, Kanpoong Chicken, and some type of beef (I didn't try any of it.) The potstickers and chicken that i did have, however, were AWESOME. Seriously, that chicken was sooooo good. I will definitely be coming back and ordering both of those dishes again.  Service wasn't that great-- they seemed really busy and didn't really get around to us unless we flagged them down.  Overall, this lost a star mainly because of the service, but the food and everything else was spot on.

ZpOxKeLD5zYW4ESk1HL1ag.review_text: playground is a regular hangout for me and it encompasses a typical korean bar, but better...the food and drinks are great, but beware of the food that is spicy..it really is THAT spicy, even for me a korean girl like me who cant get enough of spicy food.  if you order the (bool dahk) spicy chicken or the jeng-ban jja jang myun (the black bean noodles), ask for it to be made mild..it is no joke burn in your mouth, taste stays awhile spicy-ness.  staff there are super nice and will be helpful with whatever you need...their flavored soju is yum especially if you dont want the taste of regular soju...i like the lychee and yogurt flavored ones the best...but if you dont want soju, they have a full bar to fulfill your drinking needs.  friday and saturday nights get super busy, so make sure you either get there early or call in before you get there

pwYYEGzk4KUU5fGxju41ew.review_text: One of the better places to go for karaoke if you have a decent sized group and can plan ahead.  You will need to plan ahead so you can get a reservation.  The karaoke rooms are great although it should be noted that the selection of English language songs is limited in comparison to say the Mint.  Still, they have most of the staples so it isn't a big problem.  The food is decent and they have a pretty big range of drinks although many of the prices are a bit steep.  On the other hand, they do have 1.6 liter bottles of beer for $12, so if you started drinking elsewhere it is pretty easy to keep in the karaoke state of mind.  I am sure I will end up going here again and again.

ksonr4xKjpmznXtf_rB2jg.review_text: Update 9/2:   A great place to get your Karaoke/Norebang on. Last night they fit 15 of us in the bigger of the three rooms. Since it was a Sunday, they closed at midnight. They allowed us to finish out our songs and were great about it.   5 solid stars!  ---original review-----  NOREBANG! (THANKS STEPH)  SOJU! (Thanks Euge)  YOJU! (Thanks Euge)  KIWI-YOJU! (Thanks Omar)  HITE-YOJU! (Thanks Omar)  KoreanFC (Thanks Euge)  Korean tempura! (Thanks Junie)  Korean tonkatsu! (Thanks kevo)  Hours of alcohol induced fun! (Thanks all you songbirds!)  Good times! (Thanks everyone!)

fsD-6-i7Cqs-7RUcYtrZUA.review_text: What a great place to eat hang out and drink with your friends.  Great music to and even karaoke room. Food is excellent and good price during happy hour. They have happy hour everyday! We are coming back again for sure.

ECh7YPG7Pc6T1hUVQD7H0w.review_text: Health Department score of 78 posted, dirty table, dirty bathroom...neon lighting and multiple tvs showing hip hop dancing Korean boy bands with loud Korean pop playing...either this is your scene or it isn't. I had no complaints about my vegetarian dolsot bibimbap. For two of us, we got 6 little dishes to start, which is fewer than other Korean places with the same price, and I thought melted cheese on canned corn is kind of strange. We accidentally ordered a huge beer because the sizes are large and huge, not small and large.

MDMcW_LjuhDedSuJ2cB8Rg.review_text: I've now been here 4-5 times, and have to say that I've always had a great time at Playground. Some people knock the food because it's not the best Korean food ever, but the atmosphere and service (not to mention downing several pitchers of flavored soju with friends) more than make up for it.   Each time, my friends and I have ordered some standard Korean fare (bulgogi, dolsot bibimbap, jap chae, etc.), along with several pitchers of flavored soju (flavors include yogurt, lychee, pineapple, mango, peach, blueberry, apple and more). One of the great things about this place is that, along with the traditional complimentary small plates, they also give you unlimited cheese corn (layers of cheese melted on top of corn).   During our most recent visit, we ordered 5 pitchers of soju and they gave us a 6th on the house; furthermore, we told them that we really like the cheese corn, and the guy kept bringing out more for us.  This place also has private karaoke rooms, though I've yet to do that. I'm sure it would be a lot of fun with soju flowing in the room.  This is a great place to chill with friends while enjoying Korean food and flavored soju. Give it a chance, you can thank me later!

eEhWNBT0lZH-WOojdnkfjQ.review_text: They have such an amazing happy hour deal! I'm surprised too see that not many people are taking advantage of that.   A great selections of appetizers are HALF OFF! Including all the sojus and beer!   Babe and i grabbed:   Small yogurt soju - $6.50  Mool Mandoo (steamed pork dumplings) - $5 Pretty good, I think this was babe's favorite dish. It wasn't bad, but I feel like it doesnt taste much different that those frozen ones you can get from the super market.   Popcorn Chicken - $6 This was actually my favorite dish.  Really crunchy and the portions are big.  Ojinguh Twigim (tempura squid) - $7.5, not bad either, but it was mostly the fried flour here. The sauce that comes with it was pretty flavorful and probably the best of any tempura soy sauce. This dish is good to much on for a group, because it was definitely too much just for the two of us.   Overall, LOVE their happy hour deal. The only other time I came here was during New Years Eve and they opened till 2 am.  Their dokbokgi is also pretty damn good here, especially when you add the ramen! (I think it's the spiciest and most flavorful I've tried)

QwiqIA89fEh5bRGNyOcU6A.review_text: The first time I went there was quite an experience but that's only because of the events that followed shortly after leaving this place.  Nothing spectacular about this place. It's small and cute but rather pricey. Their soju cocktail was $25 and I'm sure I can go some place cheaper. One of our waiters were rude but the other two balanced it out so it's whatever. The girl was rather sweet and explained how they were short staffed so it might take awhile to cater to our party of 20. I wish they had more than one bathroom though and that we could have karaoked but that's a little too much for a starving college student.  Overall I had a great time. I honestly think I'd have to go back again to really see if I'd enjoy myself but that'll be awhile since I'm lacking paper in my wallet at the moment. Till we meet again, Playground.

KNaFBclpiEYriJa7cE0eJA.review_text: Went here during the Japantown Cherry Blossom Festival, my sister and I decided to try it, I had Jajangmyeon , and her some kind of fried triangle thing lol. I loved my Jajangmyeon, my sister said hers was nice but would have been better if she didn't wait the long muni and ac transit ride back home.

lY5l8PUFBeZ7Dhd9ccFekA.review_text: We were a party of two, dining on a Saturday night based on positive recommendations from a PBS Saturday morning round-robin restaurant review show, followed up by Yelp reviews.  Getting seated was very easy. Initial wait staff interaction was very satisfying, a friendly server came quickly and volunteered what he thought was the best dish on the menu--#17, deep-fried shrimp. We also ordered the bulgogi, and a noodle dish. The initial side dishes that I love Korean restaurants for were, here, meagre, only 3 dishes, and included a cheesy corn dish I am not familiar with from other Korean restaurants and tasted so-so. We ordered strawberry soju, which was as delicious as other Yelp reviews have stated.  When our food was delivered we quickly found it to be astonishly bland, a first in Korean dining. The bulgogi was lightly spiced and very dry. We ordered some extra kimchi to help liven it up, but by this time the waiter was preoccupied with setting up a large table and completely forgot. The fried shrimp touted by our server tasted like an entree off of a cheap Chinese diner menu, okay but for Korean food highly disappointing. The noodle dish was good, though unexceptional.  The volume of the restaurant began to rise dramatically as a few large parties arrived. I didn't mind this, having been clued in by the reviews that noise and brouhaha was de rigeur for this restaurant. When wanting to leave it was difficult getting the staff's attention to bring our check, an annoying postscript to a forgettable, disappointing meal.   I don't recommend this restaurant for diners whose emphasis is food rather than the scene. I won't be returning.

LzmC0SDuCp4Tps-k9fc0sQ.review_text: The playground is a playground for everyone that is over the age of 21.  It's a place for you and your group of friends to go eat, drink and have a good time.   I've had the food here and i  think the food here is so -so.  I mean it's good but just a little bit too oily for me The kimchi fried rice was too oily for me, but it still tasted really good and it had a good amount of spicy to it.  There are some places where the kimchi fried rice is not even spicy. The seafood pancake was ok here, but it was huge!.  It took us forever to finish it.    What i love about this place is that you can listen and watch Kpop while you are drinking your soju. They have various TV screens here.  Sometimes they play some games like the Niners or Giants.  The Soju comes in different sizes.   They have a bottle for a party of two and they have a bottle for 4 or more.   I've had the aloe, lychee and strawberry here and my favorite one is the strawberry.  You  really spend hours here because it's a very chill place.  They also have Karaoke rooms upstairs.   And we all know that it's a perfect combo when you have karaoke with Soju. And the are even open until midnight on weekdays!, even Mondays!

FNu1frS8lfTaavlgMCnojQ.review_text: I gave them an extra star for the yummy Omlette Fried Rice! The have a sign that says you can rent a private room for $30/hr. Their flavored soju seems to be carbonated?? but why? Drinking flavored soju is like drinking juice; you just keep drinking! It hits you later when you least expect it just like the bill. I wouldn't recommend the kimchi fried rice or the pot stickers. The one at Toyose is muchhh better, but Playground has side dishes! yummm :D I'll be bok!

Zqu-tMR9CHjA44sU7I5bXA.review_text: I guess I'm trying to start a family/cousin tradition where every time we get together, we partake in a night of karaoke. So when my East Coast cousins came out West, I chose Playground for our fun.  While the place is more of a restaurant, the three karaoke rooms they do have are quite comfortable. There's a large room big enough to accommodate about 15 people and two other smaller rooms for parties of 6-8. The rooms could be a bit more ventilated as the act of karaoke really makes you work up a sweat.  Luckily, Playground serves a wonderful assortment of soju and beer to cool you off. The yogurt soju is delicious... it's like an alcoholic version of the little Asian yogurt drinks I drank as a child. Mmm...And they deliver it right to your room via phone call. You can order off the food menu too. The spicy fried chicken? Not bad not bad.  The selection of songs is pretty good. They have a variety of Top 40 and old school but I'm still forever searching for Bob Marley and/or Tears for Fears. But at least I got to sing along to Journey's "Don't Stop Believing" so I was a very happy camper.  So three hours of singing, an order of chicken, two beers and two carafes of soju came to $32.50 (tip included) per person in a group of six. Not horrible at all.  Here's a tip: Order some pitchers of hot tea to soothe the throat between songs.

3HHLpfU7q4HoREEOXtt7pw.review_text: I'm not a karaoke kinda girl, but I do LOVE to watch people embarrass themselves while karaoking. I mean, how can you not laugh when you watch someone attempt to rap to 2Pac? Yeah, that's what I thought ;P  Having never been in a private karaoke room, I was curious to see how the night would turn out. My cousin's girlfriend was celebrating her birthday so she had a reserved room till 1:15 a.m. and a bartender that would bring drinks to the room. It was super convenient to just telephone the bartenders, that are located on the main floor downstairs, and let them know what you needed - be it more drinks, food, napkins, etc.  Karaoke is pretty standard - they had a huge book, organized by song name, to pick music from. The tv's were huge, flat screens and they played random Korean music videos and shows while you were singing.   Overall, this place is a solid 3 stars. The bartenders were very attentive and speedy when it came to bringing whatever was needed to the room. The boy and I ordered a few drinks and they were pretty strong, so it's safe to say that they pour with a heavy hand.

4bn1cbpU7pTZcDq_T30Tpg.review_text: GREAT place for large groups.  Went here for my birthday and worked out a deal for a large group.  They didn't flinch even when someone puked in the hallway.  They just got a bucket and cleaned it up.  The soju is a creeper, TAKE IT SLOW!  Food was pretty good, but don't remember much of the night.  Great memories, fun times!  Would definitely recommend if you want a rager of a birthday.

UuxiH2oLycDhMv7TKQ5EVw.review_text: Maybe I don't get the whole "booth karaoke" thing but apparently I'm not into it.  You get your friends, you cram into a tiny low ceiling room and sing along to bad midi versions of songs while watching video of someone's summer vacation. I need to be up on stage baby!   The booth was pretty icky and the karaoke book we had smelled like feet. Seriously, it was bad. Like, you had to put your nose into a gym sock to find the song you wanted to sing. I suppose if you really want to sing to your friends but absolutely cannot muster the courage to sing at a bar, try it out. Better yet, go buy Rock Band for your Xbox.  The restaurant part of the event was OK, but I can't really imagine going here just for dinner. I'm betting there are better places to go for Korean foods.  Yes Soju is good. That we can all agree on.

3FFjZg2Klrp8ORbCNOYQWA.review_text: I made reservations for 14 on a Saturday night. I made the reservation a week earlier and they said they can fit us in at 8pm. Saturday rolls around and since most of us were a little late I called in a little earlier to see if they can hold our table until 8:30pm. We got there right on time but the hostess said she already gave half of our table to other customers. We finally got seated after 30 minutes. The owner was really nice, she kept apologizing for the wait and she even gave us a free bottle of green apple soju. So nice!!  The prices are a little high but come on now it's Korean Food...it's expected. I got the seafood pancake ($14.95) and couldn't even finish most of it. Everyone basically shared with one another so it was family style. Since it was my late birthday dinner we HAD to order soju.   Yogurt Soju (L) $25 Mango Soju (L) $25 Strawberry Soju (L) $25 Hite Beer (2) $12 each And Green Apple Soju (S) on the house  Yup I was pretty messed up after a few shots of flavored soju. Yogurt and Strawberry Soju is sooooo goood!!! It's a must order if you want to get your drink on.    Flavored Soju:  apple blueberry kiwi lemon lychee mango orange peach  pineapple strawberry yogurt  Playground also has karaoke rooms on the 2nd level. $30 an hr.  Food was good, Service was good. Drinks were good.   Good food+good service+good drinks+good company= good times =D

zzERAXUF_mzRnEkh1bZWAg.review_text: I love PLAYGROUND. I go here all the time!  Its a great place to be with friends. just hang out and be silly. The Yogurt Soju is my favorite. And Janet is always super sweet.

4HziAeBVVljDQSjpMm9nHw.review_text: Great place for private karaoke. Not so great place to eat or drink. Went here for a bachelorette party and we ordered 6-7 dishes and drinks galore. Food was nothing special, incredibly salty, and contained less than choice meat products.  Drinks were obviously watered down and/or just plain botched. Bottled beer arrived warm. Finally we ordered straight up shots of Patron- hard to mess those up. HA! Not only were we not served Patron (we KNOW our tequila), we were all served shots in different sized cups- some as small as thimbles, others in tumblers. At long last, we got smart and smuggled in our own booze and a great time was had by all.   Beware and be critical of your beverages here!

T0RwWrAdU6kRDC1n-ROZRw.review_text: This place has a reputation now of getting me/my friends really really drunk. And in my books that's a damn good bar.  First off this is a Korean Bar for people who don't know. First time we came here on a Saturday night and it was nicely packed. Not solely Asian people here.   In terms of prices, they're similar to most Korean Bars I've been to. For people who have never tried it, I suggest getting one of the flavored sojus. They're delicious.  Overall a fun bar and a nice atmosphere. Heard there's a karaoke room on the upper floors but will have to go back to check it out.

14KPx8QwmeIg2QaTMVTidg.review_text: So we were looking for somewhere to hang out and we were stopped by a gentleman in a ballcap that totally hooked us up! We were treated to amazing service and a yogurt Sojutini. We didn't get to do karaoke but the ambience was just fine with us.  If you have never hung out Korean style be prepared for large boisterous groups and Korean music videos on the tv screens. Come with a nice sized group, order some snacks and grab your soju and see where tr night leads you. If you want to do karaoke it's best to call in advance for reservations. Also, it's private rooms so you don't have to worry about public embarrassment :)   If you are looking to reserve ask for Leo, he was the manager or staff that really saved our otherwise liquor-less evening.    Enjoy!

TmfYoFVydVLLtGeY7yHMig.review_text: I dont know why I came to this spot but I walked out disappointed. Drinks were good but food was pretty lousy. Impeccable!   I like the owners idea of integrating this place into a 3 for 1 (bar, food and karoake). Maybe they should add a massage parlor and make it a 4 for 1.   Maybe people will write rave reviews like for price of 6 ppl and happy endings = $60 CHEAP!  That's right....

pCXlJxRt_FCIt9ASSLQ_Zg.review_text: This is my fav Korean restaurant in tha bay! Great Service and tha best Yogurt Soju! I've tried a lot of Korean restaurant and their version "yogurt soju" and it tasted nasty! not enough yogurt or soju. They also have KTV and karaoke. They have good side dishes and you also get a bottle of iced cold water for your refills. I always get the Bul go gi and the jajangmyeon or Jjajangmyun. ( I hoped I spelled it correctly) Fried pot stickers, large yogurt soju, and 2 shots of patron. They also have frozen yogurt with fruity pebbles as topping or w/o it. = )

Z4QbwXw8E_vxdA9briic7A.review_text: It was one of our friend's birthday so he decided from all the rave reviews about this place he wanted to check it out. He made his reservations at 9pm, and they told him to be there by 9:10 or else they will NOT hold the table for us. So we rush over there, even booting someone out of the car to make sure we get the table, so we can find parking. Ends up that the table is still "occupied" and waited another stale 30 mins. After being seated we ordered our drinks, and food. I have to say the service was horrible, we had to wave down the waitress/waiters several time for our orders that took forever, and their flavored soju.. just tasted like flavored apple with a little bit of sprite.. I couldn't taste the alcohol at all! and also.. who the hell puts ice in their flavored soju.. i kept chucking down ice... The service was soo bad we didn't even finish our last bottle of bekseju, so when we got the check.. that charged us for an EXTRA bottle of it.. Luckily one our korean friend caught that! (good job erica)  FOOD:: Overpriced.. ALCOHOL:: WATERED DOWN MUSIC:: NONE Overall..  I've been to better Korean bars in Santa Clara, and this is one of the worst by far.

tSLMJzxCPP2x0x904sxw-w.review_text: This is a decent Korean restaurant. They offer karaoke rooms upstairs, and the food is good overall. The service is iffy -- they will occasionally mess up your order by leaving things out -- but otherwise the staff seems friendly and courteous.

EuuyiAuEa_s3VSS9i8okmg.review_text: This place is definitely Korean.  They have flat screens hanging on the walls which display various Korean music videos and television shows.  I always come here when I am craving jajamyun (noodles with black bean sauce).  It's a dish that is hard to find (for me at least).  Another reason I come to The Playground is for the corn/cheese appetizer (panchan).  It is soooo delicious.  This is a great place to go drinking with friends, they have various flavored soju.  Also, they have patbingsu.  I have had better in K-town in LA, but hey, it'll do.

ZGT9H35Edi4y8rHYSqSKfg.review_text: Flavored soju. Good. But what do they put in them?? After a couple and my night becomes a blur. Ridiculous! I'm not one to easily go down. Food was nothing special. Price? Don't get the rooms with the karaoke. Not worth it.

KwvcoeFzkvbNIP3GXyWlEA.review_text: For drinking and snacking, it is very good.  I was here several times, tried different food.  they have very tasty good versions of various Korean food.  During the day, week nights are not that busy but I heard that you have to wait in line on weekends.

5iCzdzUFqbwwjgYkfr2nhA.review_text: The first time that I have ever gone to a karaoke spot ever!  I must say, after hearing all the good things about places like Playground, I was always hesitant to check it out...however, this place is awesome...especially if you are with the right folks who like to go nuts and sing!  The songbooks have pretty much every song in the world in so many languages. handle it!  The food here is pretty freakin good too.  So order some grub (family style) so if you order various dishes and split the tab you will be a full and happy person.  Then go reserve a booth and enjoy the drunk people sing while you get really drunk in the process too.    However, I do have one gripe.  The drinks by themselves downstairs are hella good, but if you order "Soju bottle service" I really taste and feel like the alcohol is all there, just a bunch of flavor.  Just be cautious.

HmupA20O8arLkJ9Pd5oKLQ.review_text: If you want typical korean fast food, you'll enjoy this place.   Food- We ordered the Bulgogi, Squid tempura, Garlic Fries and the Soondubu.   The Bulgogi tasted good at first bite but eating a couple of beef strips made me think twice. It was seating on top of a bed of onions. I'm not sure if they did that for taste but it didn't work for me.   The squid tempura is so greasy and rubbery. Obviously it's not fresh squid. The batter is ok, could be better.   Garlic fries lack salt. Portions were really large for appetizers but that worked great for us.   The Soondubu was great though. Tasty and not too spicy.  Service - Our waiter was nice and very accommodating.   The place could use some better lighting. I know it's a bar and all but the very dim blue lights made me feel like I'm in a strip club of some sort. Bathroom was very small too.   Experience- It was pretty nice. Would go back for a lazy night with friends.

wsIh1q5zS7g-FIh8KuMDCg.review_text: I came here with a group of ten people. We hit up a private karaoke room for 2 hours and then occupied the bar for another 2.  The karaoke room is kind of weirdly shaped. The ceiling is slanted on one end, so you can easily bump your end. The karaoke tunes are pretty current though, with some new hits (Some Yeezy) and some of the classics. Our 2-hours wasn't really enough. The room actually has a phone down to the kitchen/bar so you can order your snacks and/or drinks without leaving the room.  The soju we had was crazy good. We started off with strawberry, then yogurt, and then finished off with at least 2-3 carafes of lychee. I think the lychee is the way to go. The soju hit everyone pretty hard, but it was damn tasty.  For snacks, we had the bulgogi, the korean fried chicken, and the garlic fries. All three were really good. The garlic fries tasted really good for some reason. The garlic is roasted I think and there's some sort of seasoning that makes it really good, maybe they sneak in some MSG? Whatever it is, we went for a second order.  our last few hours were at the bar, getting more snacks and drinking HITE. I never saw such a big bottle of beer, the biggest bottle is like 1.6 liters, crazy. A couple of those go a long way.  Great time, I'll come back again!

LH4_Z6gehUbNbROi09KGGw.review_text: Me and my girls one of the favorite spot.... i LUV their corn and cheese ... everytime we go, we will order one more..and they are so kind to give us for free.... like their spicy roe soup..that's my girlsfriend favorite...the soju is always nice... service is ok....

KSF2B_Ak1e9YbrBRvqZYHw.review_text: As a restaurant, the food is okay tasty, but on the pricy side.  The ribs and the pancake were very good, but the rest was so so.  As a karaoke, it's the worst I've ever visited.   - Expensive!! $30/hr + $20 (or was it $25?) min food purchase per person, and the room rate is charged by the hour.  All other places I've been to charge for room rate + maybe $2 - $5 min charge per person and the room rate is charged by 15 minute increment. - Service is SLOOOW.  They kept forgetting the stuff that we ordered or asked for and we ended up go downstair to grab them ourselves.   - Menu system is ... I don't think BAD is the right word to describe it.  It's like this place never had their menu system updated since the 90s. - Song books were old, yucky.  Song selection is extremely limited.  Also, at the end of the night, it cost us $350 and we had only 5 or 6 girls.  Com'on we are girls and we didn't order much food/drink.  One of the girls decided to pay first with her card, so I didn't know the amount until after we left.  Otherwise, I would definitely review the bill 'cuz I doubt if the charges were correct...

QGltovR2EHaI4i93hKLZzQ.review_text: This review is written from a non-korean, but Asian standpoint, forgive me for not remembering the exact name of the korean dishes =P  Walking in, there were three guy waiters in the front, huddled together talking about something, each had a different korean guy look (at least the ones i see in the videos).  One guy had pretty long shaggy hair that went down to his eyes and long down the back, the other guy had similar hair to...Shin Dong from Super Junior and wore those trendy glasses and were red-rimmed, the other guy just had short spiky hair, not so much kpop star like, but more regular korean guy =P  anyway, it took them a little while to notice us, but when they did, they did try their best to accommodate us.  though the place was full, they said we could order at the bar and when a table opened up, they'd move us there, so we agreed to that.  the place is definitely suited for the younger crowd, with large neon sign, lights that you see at a club randomly place in the room going off placing multi-color dots on the walls every where, and popular kpop videos playing continuously on multiple TVs.  there's also a karaoke lounge upstairs that i didnt have time to check out.  so my table ordered some deepfried beef in garlic sauce, seafood noodles with some sort of black sauce, and yogurt soju.  (sorry I dont quite remember the korean names to these dishes!)  the food was all pretty good, noodles were saucy, but not too saucy and at a good spiciness level, and the beef was sweet (with the sauce) and a little savory at the same time, made in little deep fried balls so it was easy to eat. we made quick haste of it all!   the yogurt soju was not bad as well, pretty much felt i was just putting down liquid yogurt, but our waiter did forget our order, so it came kinda late, meaning we hadda put down about 5 "shots" of it post meal.    when i saw a couple walked in, the guys were huddled again talking about something, leaving the couple standing there kinda awkwardly waiting, the guy and I made eye contact, and i merely smiled and shook my head indicating that: yeah, i went through that too =P  overall, the playgounds a pretty good place to hang out late at night with your friends as an opener, a place to stop off in the middle, or even an end to your night (its open till 2), it definitely has a chill, good vibe for the younger asian audience =P the staff is nice and accommodating when they do notice you, but the food is a little expensive, but then again it is SF =P

kZzwW0hGHZo00PS2gWFmYA.review_text: I use to go to this place here and there when it was Sonic.  I just went back last week for the first time since it became Playground...and man....I won't be going back ever by choice.  It was horrible!!  They were first off slow as hell to clean up a vacant table (15 minutes), the table smelled like an old table rag that they re-used from the previous night, the drinks took forever (another 15 minutes), the Soju cocktails (peach) was overly "syrup'd" (where was the alcohol??), and I didn't try the food.  I hope this was helpful...

KFaUuuvfw-6rAbTzuYwU0g.review_text: a bit pricey korean bar, but a good place for groups.  I would not recommend the kimchi rice, and cheese corn. They both lacked flavor and the rice was kinda over cooked. Instead I would recommend the soju cocktails and the bbq boneless chicken. the yogurt flavor is probably the best tasting of the 3 that I tasted (yogurt, lychee, peach). the drinks were not too weak compared to other soju cocktails ive had in the past. The chicken kinda tasted like ging dou gwat (bbq flavored pork chops at a chinese restaurant). Their fried chicken and fried appetizer platter are good sobering up munchies. The atmosphere is pretty loud as korean music videos of 2ne1, snsd, super junior etc are always playing. Great place to play drinking games and they also have karaoke upstairs.   Bottomline: Good place to go with a group, but a bit of a hit on your wallet and can get busy so be prepared to wait and lots of smokers outside the entrance. There is also a homeless guy camping out and panhandling.

71-mlkXjXi_U8C1z5LbDiQ.review_text: Seemed like a fun and promising place initially but I was a little turned off by how small the karaoke rooms were, maybe because there were too many of us in there. The blueprint of the karaoke rooms upstairs scared me a bit. I don't know if it's just me who think about these things but if the place went up in flames, everyone upstairs would be screwed. *Shrugs*. But that's just me and my crazy thoughts.  The food was great, although it was a bit pricey. Soju was great as well. I had a nice little buzz going throughout the entire night. After all, karaoke is only possible with the help of liquid courage.  My biggest gripe would be the song selections. I wished the songs were a bit more updated and the song menus weren't so confusing to look through. I probably would have rated higher if the song selections had more variety and weren't so stale. By stale I mean songs only your parents would sing drunkenly to after mahjong in their living room. Mic and sound quality was mediocre.  Bottom line: Great place to eat and drink, not so much for karaoke.

exgDi_lZjekOOtM1ZYedgA.review_text: It was ok.. The flavors were just too bland for me. Had the chicken, bulgogi, seafood soup.. It was ok. Ive had better. staff was really friendly and helpful. I would try again.

gm0V0GmBBlUlTqoZHsjWqw.review_text: Date/Time:  Saturday - 7pm Occasion:  Dinner after Cherry Blossom Festival Party of:  Eight Location:  Bright disco lights with Korean pop videos playing on the wall and tv's.  Never been to Korea but I imagine this place is what restaurants/karaoke places might look like there.  Seating is a little tight. Ordered:  fried chicken, kalbi, bulgogi, seafood pancake, seafood udon, beef japchae, house bean/meat sauce over noodle, and fried potsticker. Total incl gratuity: ~$200  Food is pretty good but prices were a little steep.  I guess I wasn't that surprised as Korean food tends to be on the pricier side.  We ordered an array of items and shared everything family style.  Of the items we ordered, I'd say the fried chicken, japchae, and house bean sauce over noodle were the most memorable.  The fried chicken had a nice glaze and the meat was moist.  Japchae was really sweet, saucy, and slippery - just the way I like it.  I really liked the house bean/meat sauce over noodle.  It was so yummy.  Definitely getting that for myself next time I'm back there.  Not impressed with the bulgogi as it was rather dry.  This is a good place with decent food to come chill with the "homies".  I've come here for karaoke on a few occasions in the past as well but it's been a while.  Since it's such a popular spot amongst the friends, I will be back, however I don't know that I'd come back craving any of the food except for that one noodle dish.

-K8UhXfWk_DyKQRTq1VzTg.review_text: As you can tell from the Playground's metadata, the best times to stop in are on the weekend. I went on a quiet Monday, but considering I pretty much loathe people in general, everything worked out just fine because it was comfortable and empty.  Stopped in with some friends after class in J-town--around 9:30pm--to have a few beers and be on my merry way. A few more friends decided to join and expand my mind with a variety of soju and Korean foods that I would be hard-pressed to recite or even pronounce correctly. Of note was the yogurt soju, cheese and corn plate, and "ribs".  Overall decent eats and drinks, service is prompt and attentive if not a little on the timid side. The lighting is dark like a midnight bowling alley so everyone looks much more attractive than they really are; maybe that's why people were staring at me...or maybe they were just squinting to see if I was a person or a hat rack. I guess I'm fine being interpreted as either so long as you don't hang one of those douchey flat caps on me.  I can't vouch for the karaoke rooms, but hear they're a good, cheap time for a group. Speaking of prices, don't come hungry because the food is insanely expensive in my opinion. You can order a Korean beer bottle the size of a fire extinguisher for about 12 bucks, but the simplest appetisers seemed to weigh in between 15-20. I think I'll stick with the free peanuts at the bar, thank you. At least they have a lot to choose from and the portion sizes for many dishes was fairly large.  Bottom line: a great place to stop in with some friends for a couple drinks or with a few more for karaoke. Grab your appetisers or meal elsewhere if you'd rather put your dollars towards drinks; the food here will consume your wallet. One of the few places open in J-town Monday nights!

EVaW-GGDEbYrYhgGUmO0DQ.review_text: only came here for the food.   loved the spam fried rice, the dumplings, fried beef, the ramen, and soju  didn't like the: fire chicken (way too hot) and the corn and cheese (it was cold)

KjaR8eXZLNpxrI7EyrCH1g.review_text: Food: Not the best korean food but certainly not the worse. got the bulgogi (bbq beef). tasty! also got some sort of seafood noodle spicy soup. it was also good but i guess i wasn't "wowed". the panchan included cabbage kimchi (my fav!) and the crazy-ass crack corn cheese mess (*it sounds crazy but its good like you know its wrong and you eat it anyways).  yogurt soju TASTED fantastic but....when 2 carafes = 24 shots, does not result in massive wastage, i was seriously upset at my ability to walk out of that place upright. i mean, i should have been peeled off the floor if there was the proper amount of alcohol in those bad boys....WATERED-DOWN! oh well. be warned, get a cocktail - straight up or take shots! *not of soju.   Service: came with a smile and didn't rush my chatty dinner party. prompt and friendly. food came fast. drinks didn't.  Atmosphere: Loud and Asian. not so asian that you couldn't take any white folks wit cha tho. Loud enough that you wouldn't want to take complainers or whiners.  Overall: something different and fun. perfect friday dinner with friends!

6rVoU6TfbwPI0bhutDKeNg.review_text: I couldn't care less about singing in the norebangs (for which all my friends should be eternally, forever, continuously and redundantly grateful).  Now, the food, however!  Great!  It's some of the better Korean food I've had in San Francisco.  First off, they have soondae! (Blood sausage: I think some other reviewer called it gross...yeah, it's an acquired taste but I love it).  Then, they also have a pretty good haemul dolsot bibimbap (seafood mixed rice in a hot stone bowl...don't touch the bowl).  The one at Ohgane is better, but this is good.  Also, a very delicious ahltang (codroe stew) with tofu.  Nice.  Not too spicy, and lots of codroe.    We also ordered some fried mandoo (for those who are more used to Japanese food, gyozas), which I love.  I was too full to eat more than a couple.  Near the end, after we had sat there for hours eating and drinking, they gave us fried octopus as "service" (free).  I realized at this meal that what is different about octopus at Korean restaurants is that us Koreans tend to prefer octopus that definitely has a more "fishy" taste...so it might not be for everyone, particularly those who might not like fishy seafood (which always amazes me; what's the point of eating seafood then?).  Oh, yeah, the banchan.  This isn't a big banchan sort of meal, so don't expect a lot of the small side dishes.  There's a few, but it's not a huge spread (after all, this is a norebang/drinking establishment).  However, I do like that corn/butter/cheese thing they serve.  It's so Asian let's-take-American-processed-food and make it weirder.

UspnrHsJen58iyn7zQ9v7g.review_text: I didn't go here for a night out drinking or karaoke, so it might be a different experience otherwise.  We had the seafood pancake, rice omelet, and the wet fried shrimp.  The rice omelet was decent.  I've definitely had better seafood pancake!!!  Theirs is heavy on the batter, more saugy than crispy, and doesn't have much seafood or veggies.  The wet fried shrimp was okay, but it kinda reminded me of orange chicken or sweet and sour shrimp or something.  HOWEVER, the silverlining is definitely the yogu!  Very delightful drink--especially if you enjoyed drinking the yogurt drinks as a kid.

N9CrBkTkDZFqQoL64e5USA.review_text: I love the yogourt soju mix!

2H6gAvXrIwMTsXhixfKMrw.review_text: Another review.  Came here on my birthday, got completely trashed.  The yogurt soju is pretty good, but i prefer to drink it straight.  This place is good if you have a large group or small group.  I say do the karaoke, it's a blast.  The tangsuyuk is good too.  I got to stop coming here, it's putting a dent in my pocket.  I do have one recommendation though.  Get the gan poong sol gogi, you won't regret it.  Order a few bottles of cham il sul, few bottles of OB, the larges bottles, and maybe some of the flavored soju for the ladies, you are guaranteed to have a good time.   Better than porno bar in Oakland for those that have been there.  It's well priced too.  For a party of 10-12 people+4 hours of karaoke and food was only $367.00

IIRFv4Q-O_aDWgwnRgxN1g.review_text: Went here for a friend's semi-go-away celebration (It's complicated). We had dinner and did the whole karaoke thing. It was pretty empty at first, but I gotta give them slack since it was a Wednesday.  Eventually, I think they filled up half of the place.  The place would have look better if I was drunk. That is all.  There's only 3 rooms for karaoke and I imagine it gets crowded during the weekend. Book ahead! Two complaints. One:  the machines don't offer an option for a singer to sing simultaneously with me. I need help with singing and it was kind of hard without it. Two: the songs are organized alphabetically by song titles. I wished it was by artists! It was very overwhelming.  Now, on with the food. I ate so much that I totally went to a larger notch for my belt. I was ridiculously full and almost considered hurling. But I didn't. Food was surprisingly good. I got the seafood pancake--not the best I've had, but pretty darn appetizing. Tried all of my friends' food and all were equally good AND SPICYYY. Also, the waiters got confused about our orders and ended up giving us an extra big bowl of noodles with crab. Freebies are awesome. And oh yes, the corn and cheese were tasty.   Lastly, I have to note that the waiter spilled a pitcher of water near us. Um, I screamed terribly loud and I am ashamed. I forgive them because they gave me a pack of Melon gum every time I asked thereafter.

TzSFCbZoi3Ohs9hqDmoQDQ.review_text: Decent, but nothing to write home about.

VdUjcjZeSF7sH8Z-OZfIag.review_text: I'm not a huge fan of karaoke but when some firends wanted to stop at Playground on a weekday night I decided to go along. Surprisingly they weren't too busy so we were able to get one of the larger rooms without waiting. They have a 1-item food/drink minimum per person and rooms run about $30/hr. I wasn't impressed by their song selections as they were really dated. The remote controls were in Korean so it took us awhile to get it going. The staff were really nice.

WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA.review_text: It's the night of high school prom, and you're dining in a restaurant filled with promgoers from an unfamiliar school. Now, subtract the rental tuxes along with a few of the dresses, up everyone's age or give them McLovin cards, and - hey! - you're at Playground.  The menu is a mix of newer (cheese corn, fried chicken, omelets, soju cocktails, etc.) and older (altang, doenjang jjigae, jjajangmyeon, golbaengi muchim, etc.). Other things like budae jjigae and froyo ("plain" flavor only) x Fruity Pebbles make appearances, along with just a few exclusive items, identified by names starting with "noriteo" / "playground". Funky things can come "service", like cheese corn, fried chicken, etc.. Sansachun is available, for the aficionados.  I've been here with group sizes ranging from just 2 people to the entire restaurant (rented, reserved... I didn't a$$k). The whole restaurant version had mics for people to sing (and give speeches - whatever) among the dining tables rather than having to go to the private rooms.  The waitstaff are in baseball t-shirts, some saying "Playground", some Lincecum. As hip as this place is, I only find myself here on notable occasions... like every other time I'm about to graduate from high school.

VkWLAauzPyCSXhhXAPhH4g.review_text: The menu and remote were all in Korean so it was a bit annoying trying to figure out how everything works, but the Sojuu was really good

QmuVIiNqn8e-8yna6la1eQ.review_text: i was there on friday, december 13... there were 8 of us, and we got a room for karaoke. they held my credit/debit card, and we got our room for 2 hours. somebody tried to charge $343.55 on my card! what the fuck??? somebody needs to be fired!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! good thing my credit/debit card provider knows this is not a normal charge on my account & declined the purchase! when i tried to pay our bill... it was declined! i won't be going there again!!!!!!!  visa figures my card was lost or stolen!  some people will try and take advantage of people after a few drinks! if you go there, then bring a designated driver & someone to handle the money, etc...

XXPSbeYgEWQzZL0A-W1LQQ.review_text: I stumbled upon this place when I decided to book a private karaoke room for my birthday party.  I was walking around trying to find a another praivate Karaoke place, 'Do Re Mi' and saw this place.  I decided take a look.  Immediately, when I walked in, the staff was friendly and once I inquired about the private karaoke rooms, they took me on a tour, and helped me book a room at the last minute. Not only is it cheaper than the other place, but you can have food an alcohol delivered right to your room through the courtesy phone.  The rooms are nice and the cong selection is pretty good.  My friends and I had a great time!!!

3roJp-RoqKVoMgdtuJFM9Q.review_text: seafood pancake. soju soju soju karaoke room  food isn't all that great but the place is great for big parties. can get pricey....  oh and JIN is awesome. attentive and didn't mind the crazy drunks.  have been back many times...even blacked out on my bday! whoohoooo

70aCUk-YIZSasoHfoe-LVw.review_text: This spot is a fun place to go for drinks, as the name really says it all. :) I've been here a few times, and every time I leave I'm usually pretty buzzed. Last weekend after eating some sushi, we still felt like drinking more so we ended up coming here to play! That night we ordered: - Large Yogurt Soju (static4.px.yelp.com/bpho…) - Seafood pancake (static3.px.yelp.com/bpho…) Yogurt Soju (4 Stars): So good, delicious, and it totally sneaks up on you.  This is an alcoholic dessert drink at its finest. YUM! Seafood pancake (3.5 Stars): A flat pancake mixed with seafood that is full of crispy deliciousness. It's pretty good, but a bit on the expensive side.  I think it was around $15 bucks or so. Cheese Corn (4.5 Stars): They give you complimentary Cheese Corn dish, and it's so good and delicious! Canned corn has never tasted so good, you have to try it. Summary (3.75 Stars): A fun place to hang out with delicious flavored soju drinks and food (try the cheese corn)!

V5Th21KjUiYLJQyV-vGtpg.review_text: My last karaoke experience was at Pandora before I came to Playground.  When I reserved a room there, it was mostly billed as a fixed rate per hour.  At Playground, they put in a minimum dollars per person charge based on our length of stay.  In our case, we had 10 people and we had to spend $20 minimum per person during our time there.  I wish it were simpler because usually with hourly rates, I know how much extra I'm paying if we stay longer.  In this case with the minimum spend per person, then how will I know how much I'm on the hook for?    The guy who helped to set us up in the room was nice enough although we ran into a couple issues during the night.  There were a lot of food orders that came to our room by mistake.  One of the microphones kept giving us static when we used it.  And finally, we were not happy with the English song selection.  The foreign language selection is a lot more robust and varied but the English songs were relatively small in comparison.  A lot of people in my group were looking to find the songs they are used to singing(Jessie's Girl, She Drives Me Crazy) and they weren't in there.  Considering its J-town location, I don't doubt that they have a large loyal fan base that comes here but based on my experience and how much we eventually spent on the night, I think I'd rather go elsewhere next time I want to do private room karaoke.

B9_M5qoWA5tHXQWHfoW0tg.review_text: My friends and I came here to eat only. I didn't know this place was also a karaoke place too. The food was good mostly spicy. I really like this shrimp dish we had which, it was heavly sauce and was so good with rice and beer, Hite. The Jia Jiang Myun was good but too spicy for me. I like San Tung's better. Dumplings were really good. Service was friendly and prompt. Overall good experience, I have to come back and try the Karaoke!

npZu3OtrDH4wmdTU2JNNcw.review_text: This is a great place to go with good friends. The music is a bit dated but they have a decent selection of English songs. I came here last weekend twice for two different parties and the service the staff provided both nights were stellar. Thanks for everything and thanks for making sure my two friends had awesome birthdays.

Z9bOjahuxvMju3mO3ac9_g.review_text: love itttttt so honestly i'm gonna be a little biased because i usually run into friends here and i always have fun.  food is good, and u can sing karaoke upstairs too. u can just order food upstairs if u want, so thats a plus. sing some songs, eat some jok-bal, drink some soju, sing some more songs..  weekends can get really crowded...

e3YrxFrI3ufMsz7wsJTu4g.review_text: I love stopping by whenever I get a chance to visit SF.  I can always count on Playground to have a fun and lively atmosphere with great Korean music.  The food is always on point and drinks are definitely stiff.  Good food, fun vibe, great service at an affordable price.  What more could you ask for?

e1FuiYSV1v29q2OTR9ojBA.review_text: I LOVE NOREBANG NIGHT!  We took over all three karaoke rooms upstairs at this bar/restaurant/karaoke spot and sang for FOUR HOURS, fueled by Korean food and yogurt soju shots.  Who knew this spot above Denny's in Japantown was so happenin' on a Friday night?  I felt like I was back in Hawaii!  We really only came for the Karaoke, so I probably should come back for a meal, as the food looked and smelled really good.  Will update when I get a chance to try the goods. ==== UPDATE:  5/23/08  Got invited to dinner with some friends, so I finally got to try the food :)  Their banchan is really yummy (I am partial to odeng and the corn and cheese), and they gave us two rounds.  We also had dukbokki, bulgogi, daeji bulgogi, ohjingo bokkum (spicy sauteed cuttlefish with noodles), and soon du bu chigae.  I wasn't that impressed with the soon du bu, but everything else was tasty.  We had so much food, there was a ton of stuff to take home.    Next time, I'm dragging everyone upstairs for Karaoke.  w00t!

EwadMhTHfOh_ntXyaOCnTA.review_text: Corn and cheese? Yes please!  The owner/staff are SO nice here. The wait for the food was a bit long for our group of 6 (it was super busy and I'm sure the kitchen was working hard cranking out the food), so the owner threw in free yogurt soju, on the house! Yay!  I just wish they had lychee soju. Where can I find this in SF?  Food is not bad. We ordered A LOT of food.   It's too dark in here though. I couldn't read the menu. Oh well!  This is a fun place for a small get together/bday shinding.  $200/6 people. A bit expensive but keep in mind that we ordered a ton of food and soju/drinks!

rVJOGjuv9RDmN04V9fNk2g.review_text: decent korean BAR food. a tad overpriced, but a good place to go for groups. im partial to their yogurt soju (not that it's any different from anywhere else...)  their spicy shrimp is good, and so is their fried rice in an egg (omorice)

433taelNYZ6xJlTDTGy1vQ.review_text: First of all, WTF is a Ddukbokki?  and secondly, why does it taste so damn good?

VwtdVLXenWgk9JMYUwZQOw.review_text: kinda feel like i'm in LA when i come here.  janet is always nice.  when i don't feel like making hae-mul pa-jun i go here.  the soon-dea bokum isn't bad either.

JbQnuMvo0NdlKVWIn-3wIA.review_text: Although the lines get sort of long, it's worth it. I feel like I'm in LA when I'm here. The lighting and the Korean atmosphere makes you feel at home. The la bbok ki (ramen dduk bbok ki) is really good here. Yogurt Soju is gooood too.

QxPxxPjgcQ-MDM6OMYMFCg.review_text: When Playstation Karaoke boots you off for bad singing, you know you don't belong at a Karaoke bar.  It is a widely known fact I am a horrible singer, so it's been years since I've been to one.  But C, who is a wonderful singer, wanted to belt out a few and I somehow managed to find this place.  $30/hr is steep for 2 but I guess with 4+, it's pretty reasonable.  C managed to find a bunch of songs he wanted to sing for the hour we were there but I reckon if he knew Asian songs, we would have been there longer.  Food and drinks are available too but we didn't get a chance to sample as I was too busy trying to figure out the space size remote and mood lighting.

7CWRoP0f4TLwRkYR5syiqQ.review_text: The Kan Poong Prawns dish is really good. I've had it a couple times and the first time I had it it was spicier than the second time. The first time I had it a friend brought the dish to me and the second time I ordered it in person...maybe they though since I'm white I couldn't handle the spiciness. I think it tastes much better spicy so make sure to ask your server to not take it easy on you with the spices.

RnmPWWPhYdi6iKkLF4gzVQ.review_text: I've actually never had Korean food before this....but I am now a fan! Food we ordered was nice and spicy - my fav was the fire chicken dish i believe? The flavored soju was pretty good too, only complaint was dish's could be a bit bigger but they aren't too bad. There is a karaoke upstairs, but there are cheaper places down the street. We were a group fo 10 so the wait was quite long, the place itself isn't too big.   haha I can finally say that I have had Kimchi!

fiAtggeGGinY6UnHI75NcQ.review_text: Honestly when I walked in here last night.. my first thought was uh... how do I call my friends to go to the Berkeley karaoke instead... but I decided it was too much trouble to rearrange everything and give this place a try...  If it wasn't for the food, I would've gave this place a 1 star.  This place isn't setup for non-Korean speakers/readers. The remote controls were in korean.. the waiter was korean but didn't know how to read korean to help us with the remote. There isn't that many English selections to choose from... Also the system is pretty ghetto... the tv was broken for 15 minutes until they reset everything.. All the videos were the bootleg ones with weird backgrounds.. we were singing to guys doing hula and some naked kids running around th beach... (yes I'm not kidding. WTF!).... for what it provides the hourly rate was pretty expensive.   The food was pretty good though. One of the main reasons why I picked this place in the first place was that it's one of the very few karaoke places that have private rooms and serves alcohol. We ordered the usual korean selections like galbi, black bean noodles (their noodles were chewy just the way I like it!), spicy rice cakes, bibimbop (not very good, it was cold), cold spicy noodles with egg, seafood pancakes (yummy!), and corn with cheese (this was free).  Honestly with the limited song selections, it's really not worth it.

HdIoytNZpETuqW5-ELcicw.review_text: This place is great, the beer is the best - I personally  don't think u can beat OB or Hite, and the big OBsor  the 'pitcher's are great 2 liter screwtops. Like a 40 but classier. Do share with a friend.  I think the food is top shelf, I recommend the potsticker salad, its sooooo good, and the battered shimp with sticky sweet chili sauce is so tastey.   The free yummies you get are really good and I'm sure you have read about the corn n cheese, y u m.

cQ2i-3GXwTiQ-vrCXDwMCA.review_text: I love the cheese corn here.  One time I was walking by and I told my friend I wanted to order some to go and he reminded me that it was a free plate that they give you while you wait for your food to come.  How do you order something that is free.  The food is good here and you get to sing too if you get a karaoke room!

Jttbzh-88m_9mly4mNLBlA.review_text: I really liked the food here, and the service was great. Plus it was late on a Sunday night and I was starving after walking around all of SF looking for places to eat.

eQJtcM6rK0-x2F2UlZaNJg.review_text: I had one of the best Thanksgivings ever at this place.  Not expensive, great rooms, great selection of drinks and food.  The service is excellent, the place is clean and there are plenty of bathrooms so you don't have to wait long and miss you opportunity to belt out "Living on a Prayer."

G92-0bLe_si4wFADShldBA.review_text: This place has excellent korean food and I love the side dishes they serve. But whenever I head here its mostly for some soju cocktails. It's delecious! I really love the Yogurt flavored Soju!  The atmosphere is a typical night bar/restaurant but it's easy to get comfortable. My ideal night in Japan Town is getting some soju in me at Playground and then heading out for some Karaoke! So much fun!

X9UXFXx16gdq0F3JYUhKbA.review_text: If you book providing your credit card, then you are screwed. First, it's 30$ per hour and then minimum charge per person 25$ plus tips. They use your credit card for downpayment of the time (30$ x number of hours) at the moment of booking. Usually, people commit for karaoke but most then cancel at last minute so you are screwed with your downpayment. Then, the private room for 8 people was actually a kind of creepy attic transformed into karaoke with very old karaoke equipment. Food was not that good and impressively overcharged, same as their cocktails. We had just 4 large plates charged 20$ each, same for the fruit plate. The plates look large but actually there is not that much. Large dumpling plate were like only 10 dumplings... We had fun cause we were a group of friends, but we were really disappointed by the place and will not recommend it. It's way cheaper to buy a karaoke machine (60$ on EBay) and do it at home!

ijlvPzIfjLeKeKiLnKy5ww.review_text: This 1 star review is left not because of the service, food, or drinks! This review is left because of poor upper management, and by that, I mean the owner!   After sitting at the bar for over an hour with friends enjoying drinks and food, the night turned ugly. A friend of mine sitting next to me was looking over the bill and mentioned, "Man, this place is pretty pricey for what you get. I have gotten more food and better drinks for that price." (Which is very true BTW)!   The owner was behind the bar and started yelling at my friend, "If you have a problem with the price, you can bring it up to me.
